Service was great, our waitress helped me find a wine sweet enough for my taste, which was great.

For two glasses of wine, soda, two main dishes, dessert and coffee, the total was $65. We were really surprised, by the quality of the meal we expected to pay a lot more. 

We'll definitely be back next time we visit the city!
author: Haley S.

description:
This is a neighborhood spot - small, cozy, simple foods. 

- the Beet Salad ($9.50): diced cubes of red and gold beets with arugula leaves. very light complement of goat cheese. simple, normal portion.

- the Endive Pear Salad ($9.50): chopped endive is tossed with arugula leaves, paired with 4 slices of pear, some raw walnuts, and very light dusting of gorgonzola cheese. not enough i say.

- Cappriciola Pizza (~$15): mushroom, proscuitto, artichoke and olive toppings on a hand tossed pizza dough. honestly, not a fan. the mushroom was the garden variety. the olives still had the PITS inside. they didn't even take out the seed! overall, seriously lacking flavor.

- Taglieri Pasta (~$17-$18): salmon, pancetta, olives, with spinach pasta. This was better. Interesting mix of ingredients but again, everything was done super lightly so flavor was not at the forefront.

Dessert was the only saving grace.
- Lemon Mascarpone Cake (~$6): pretty layered cake with mascarpone cream in between, coated with white chocolate shell.

-Tiramisu (~$6): Very nice and light, traditional italian style.

Oh and the basket of warm focaccia bread was tasty. If it weren't for dessert and bread, I don't think I'd have given 3 stars.
author: Cindy W.

description:
This is more of a 3 1/2 star review than a 3.  We enjoyed our meal at Pazzia, but it lacked that "wow" factor that I look for in restaurants in the city (since there are so many options!).  

We called 15 minutes ahead and the hostess told us that we could be seated without a wait if we came right away.  I really appreciated that and thought the service throughout our meal was pretty good overall.  

For dinner, we ordered the margherita pizza and the gnocchi with the "pomodoro" sauce.  We were a little surprised that the gnocchi came out dressed in a creamy white sauce rather than a red sauce, but we both agreed that the gnocchi was quite good.  The sauce was very flavorful and I enjoyed it.  The margherita pizza was decent as well, though it was far from my favorite of the pizzas I have had in the city.

Based on the other reviews, it appears that maybe Pazzia is better for pastas than pizza.  I probably would not return, but only because there are so many other restaurants in the city that I want to try and, while we had a good meal at Pazzia, nothing about Pazzia is drawing me back.
author: Julie S.

description: honest italian meal. homemade pasta. personal service . almost felt i was in a small italian trattoria somehere in italy.
author: Nick F.

description:
Have eaten here twice now. Service has always been great. A special shout out to Julia who has made us feel very welcome both times.

The pizzas are delicious if a tad greasy. Certainly miles better than the similarly priced Zero Zero (also in the neighborhood). All the pastas we've tried have also been up to scratch. It can get noisy, but this can be passed off as Italian boisterousness, and adds to the atmosphere,

The house red is excellent. Skip the tiramisu though, Expect to pay about $50 for 2 with wine.
author: Chetan G.

description:
I am italian, and I have been living in San Francisco for more than one year now. The quality of the pizza here is decisely above the average of the italian pizza eaten in Italy.
Furthermore, I haven't seen in San Francisco so far restaurants treating so well their customers. You feel yourself at home here, and you can breathe italian culture and habits in this place.
author: Roberto V.

description:
Pazzia was a quick convenient stop for our group so we decided to try it out. The bread was really amazingly soft and delicious. I asked for balsamic vinaigrette however it was never brought.

The ravioli with meat sauce was very tasty, however a bit greasy. It was a great combo to dip the bread in the left over meat sauce. The staff was very polite, however my friends water glass stayed empty half way though the meal until the time we left.
author: Jason M.

description:
I am a true North Jersey Italian food lover this place is a MUST if you like Italian food.

This is more a local place, not glamerous however the food and service is excellent.  We are going back a second time tonight since I was going to order the Lamb Shank and decided to go with the Fetuchini and my Fiance had the personal pizza with brochutte.  Both excellent disches however I saw the lamb shank and it looked fabulous and since I live in Southern CA people lamb is hard to come by.

We met Massimo the owner, he is hard to miss since he always moving about making sure his customer's are receiving excellent service.

After our second visit tonight we will definently be back.
author: Martin O.

description: I love this place! We go regularly as its in our neighborhood and feels like home away from home. Massimo is always so welcoming; Julia is beautiful inside and out, and always goes out of her way to make us feel like family; and Serge is the most efficient busboy I've come across in the city! I've never had a dish I didn't like - the roast chicken and the lamb chops are probably my favorites....and the crispy potatoes are cooked to perfection. So grateful to have this wonderful place on my doorstep.
author: Vivienne L.

description: This was effing fabulous. Popped in with some local friends while visiting from the East Coast. Had a bottle of Chianti (an '07) and a delightful sampling of apps, salad & pizza. The service and owner were charming and the food was marvelous. I left full, happy and glad that places like this still exist. Very Old World.
author: Sammy D.

description: My favorite place....I love their  homemade pasta....
author: llando d.

description:
I love Pazzia.  I go there all the time for food on my dinner break at work because they're close by, but I also come here on my days off as well for dinner just because the food is so good!

Everything we've had on the menu is fabulous.  Tonight I had the spicy angel hair pasta with sundried tomatoes and it was fantastic!  The lasagna is divine as well, it comes out of the oven in a terra cotta dish bubbling and delicious, and the pizzas, calzones and main entrees are all great as well.  It's probably one of my favorite restaurants in the city.

Lastly, the owner Massimo is such a gentleman and takes wonderful care of us every time.

Can't wait till my next trip!
author: Genevieve M.

description: My family went by here for dinner tonight. There was no wait and we were seated right away. Out server was so friendly and the food was so delicious. We had the sausage pizza and tortellini and their pizza of the day with prosciutto and mushrooms and white truffle oil.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
We live a block away from Pazzia and either go there once a week or get takeout once a week. When we moved to SOMA from NY we were on a quest for good italian food in SOMA and good pizza. Zero Zero has good pizza but Pazzia is closer plus the rest of their menu is very good also. After going there a handful of times we are now treated like family. The owner, Massimo, is charming, pleasant and energetic. He always takes the time to greet us and make us feel very welcome. When family/friends visit from the east coast we always take them here.

It's a small restaurant so make a reservation especially on the weekends and especially if there is a large convention at Moscone. 

My wife is Italian and a fabulous cook and she also agrees that the pasta at Pazzia is made perfectly. All the pasta that I've ordered has been perfect especially the raviolli and the lasagna. 

The one negative is as soon as the wine shows up the fruit flies do too.

I love this place! So glad we found it.
author: Ed G.

description:
Very cute and charming neighborhood Italian restaurant that is always crowded and busy every time we walk past it come home from work. 

We finally gave Pazzia a try. Their pizzas have thin crusts and are just like the ones in Italy! I loved how they had reasonable portion sizes and have homemade pastas! Will definitely go back to try their pastas next time. My coworker says she thinks about their lasagna even days after she has eaten there =)
author: Betty C.

description: It's everything and more you could want from a family Italian place. It didn't take long before the owner Massimo and his lovely wife made us feel like part of their family. The Pappardelle is THE BEST I have ever had. The pasta is fresh. The pizzas are thin and crispy. They bake delicious crusty fresh bread daily and serve it to each table upon seating with a delicious fruit olive oil to dip it in. I was at a meeting in the Moscone Center. This place is around the corner. I managed to get about 10 of my coworkers to go try it out after I raved about it the next day and all of them loved it just as much as I did. Can't wait to go there again next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Kerry M.

description:
Terrible service. 

Waitresses that aren't communicating with each other (and it's a small place, and there's only two of you, so is it really that hard to do?) and asking us the same thing several times... it's fine if you share duties/ we have multiple servers, but that doesn't mean you should try to take our orders twice. Awkward.

Asked for vinegar for the bread and it wasn't brought out until I asked the guy filling our waters. He provided the best service out of anyone there.

I could barely hear the waitress as she read out the specials of the day... which she proceeded to do as soon as we sat down and before we even had a chance to like, pick up our menu or realize she was talking to us...

Lastly, when we were done eating, my friend asked if we could get 3 separate checks. If anyone asks that, rather than just throwing 3 cards in, it means that they would like each person's tab separately. 

Instead of informing us that they can't do that, the waitress was like "If you each put in a card we can split it 3 ways", which confused my friend, and when he asked again after the bill came to clarify, the waitress made it awkward for all of us by explaining that it'd be a difference of a dollar for each person paying and it's difficult to split the bill that way because their system is old blah blah blah. Honey, I understand that/ can do basic math, but that's not your role in this and you should have politely said "Sorry, we don't split bills" to begin with rather than give us attitude and a sob story.

As for food: My oven-roasted chicken + side potatoes were pretty meh. I understand I'm ordering a pretty simple dish, but it really could've used more flavor.

If I'm going to spend $14+ on mediocre Italian food, I'd honestly rather go to Olive Garden. F'real.
author: Richa A.

description: Wow, such a great dining experience! Not only was every bite if food delicious but the people who work there were just so warm and authentic and treated is as if they'd know us for  years. Homemade pastas were delicious and sauces were perfection!
author: laura f.

description:
I've been to Pazzia twice and I have to say that I've had the best Italian-style pizza here, period! The crust was thin and perfectly crisp, with a light yet savory sauce, and creamy mozzarella to top it off. Perfect!

The other pasta dishes I've tried have been good but not as good as the pizza. However, the owner, Massimo is the greatest host and makes everyone feel especially at home.  Throw in some of the most strikingly beautiful and attentive waitresses in the city and you have no real reason NOT to go!

More like 4.5 stars but we'll ratchet it up for Massimo's unforgettable hospitality and that petite brunette he has working for him! ;^)
author: Art O.

description: I think of myself of somewhat a pizza connoisseur and this place has the best pizza in the city hands down.... they don't deliver though and get pretty busy
author: Nolan M.

description: Came here on Valentine's Day for dinner with my boyfriend.  We had a really good time. The atmosphere is small and quaint, which made it feel very personable. I was surprised to find it wasn't a fixed menu.  We had reservations, but the couple next to us did not and they were able to be seated right away outside at 6.  We ended up next to them and enjoyed a fine evening with great conversation.  The food is excellent.  I ordered the spinach tortelloni with a creamy mushroom sauce which was heavenly.  They give you a full cup of parmesan cheese to go with your pasta, so you can add as much as you want when you want.  For dessert I ordered the cream caramel, and it could have been a little more caramelized on top.  But overall it wasn't too bad.  The service was a bit hit and miss.  Our waiter never gave us a chance to order drinks or appetizers first, he just came over after awhile and asked if we were ready for the whole order.  And after everything was done, and the couple next to us was gone, it took forever to get our check.  But we weren't in any specific hurry, and the owner did introduce himself and offer a drink to go.  Overall very pleasant experience, with quality food for not breaking your wallet.  I would love to go back and try the salmon.
author: Renee P.

description:
Really delicious.  
Seafood risotto was just creamy enough.
Pizzas were thin and the crust just a bit crispy.
The spicy sausage and mushroom was  my favorite.

Daily specials for each menu section such as sandwiches, pizza, entree, etc.

It got hot inside because of the pizza oven.  If weather permits, outside seating may be a good choice.
author: Ken B.

description: This is my hands-down favorite Italian place. Their tortelloni and pizza are both fantastic, and their tiramisu is the best I've ever had. The staff is incredibly friendly and helpful. I love Pazzia!
author: Rajesh S.

description: Some of the best pasta I have ever had! it wouldn't surprise me if someone's grandma, right off the boat from italy, was in the back making it by hand. Food came out hot and fresh...and we were a party of 13! Would definitely come back agsin!!!!
author: Samantha A.

description: My wife and I love this restaurant. One of our favourites in SF. Fantastic food, service and atmosphere.  Great prices too. By far the best Italian!! Massimo is fabulous!
author: Paul W.

description: This place has been around for years and I do wonder why I don't eat at it more. Driving by on the weekends, there's sure to be a wait. The last time I was here it was a Tuesday night with no real crowd. We were heading off to a show and decided to go for the quick and simple, which Pazzia is really good for. Somehow  we managed to finish 3 bottles of wine between the 2  us and then stumbled to the show. Let me say that seeing Goldfinger and 3 other ska-punk bands ripped on Barolo is quite an experience. Great simple trattoria fare at very reasonable prices.
author: Kim N.

description:
It's on the pricey side for a normal workday lunch but definitely a good option for a nicer, longer lunch.

We ordered the bruschetta which was topped with beautiful fresh tomatoes. I had the shrimp and risotto which I was concerned would be too rich and heavy for lunch, but it was perfect. The taste and flavors were light. The menu was pretty expansive from pastas to pizzas to meat-based entrees.

Lunch happened to be very busy (a lot of people from the office all decided to go there!), and the server did a good job keeping an eye on us.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I've loved Pazzia for some time, and can't believe I haven't written a review.

This is truly a family Italian place in SoMa - perfect if you're in the area and don't want to trek to North Beach. The menu is small, but very well executed, and the wine list is similar. On Thursday/Friday/Saturday nights there can be a wait as there are only a few tables (unless they recently opened the extension) - but they do have take away.

Personally, I prefer the pizza at Zero Zero a few blocks away, but prefer Pazzia pasta's, apps, and very quaint atmosphere. Different places for different moods.
author: Ben K.

description:
Wanted to go to a small local place for dinner and Yelp led me and a colleague to Pazzia.  Excellent Italian bread to start was an indicator of good things to come.  The beet salad was just average, a little under-dressed in my opinion.  I ordered the gorgonzola pizza, which I was worried might be a little overwhelming in the gorgonzola department.  Fortunately, it wasn't - excellent gorgonzola flavor without being overpowering.  I ate the whole thing.  Reasonably priced as well.  Including salads, pizzas and non-alcoholic drinks, our check with a little over $50 for two.  Service was casual and friendly - and really Italian.  I'd certainly return.

PS - I note they're expanding into the space next door.  Hopefully they can keep up the good quality with a bigger place.
author: Ryan W.

description:
Their sit-down experience can be a bit slow, since they're usually very crowded during dinnertime. (Their service is very quick during lunchtime, however.) They place the tables closely together, so you might will have to squeeze through other tables to get to your seat, making you feel a bit jammed, or cozy, depending on your point of view. It can be a bit loud. In my opinion, it's a place better for meeting up with friends than a date night.

In terms of food: I used to live right next to Pazzia, so I mostly got takeouts. Their gnocchi was pretty great and I ordered it pretty much on weekly basis. However, over time the quality of the food plummeted somehow: the gnocchi became extremely salty and no longer had any flavor, and their bread became dry and flavorless. I'm not sure what happened, maybe they changed the cook, but it just wasn't the same anymore, and I ended up drifting away from the restaurant. Other items on their food are ok, but I miss the flavorful gnocchi they used to have. :(
author: Angie S.

description:
dainty...petite...warm...friendly....home....some words to describe this quaint italian eatery...fully armed with high taste and satisfaction....greeted with an amicable handshake for the men..and gentle kiss to the cheek for the ladies....pazzia welcomes their guests genuinely...variety of wines to compliment the dinner...how can one resist?...

complimentary glass of champaign to start...only for "regulars"....thin..crusty...and toasty daviola pizza...simple cheese and sausage pizza....finest pizza had...bottle of pinot grigio to compliment...fantastic...el pollo...white chicken breast...soft as a portion of thigh meat...excellent....warm bread and olive oil served generously throughout dinner....great friendly service throughout....complimentary sweet white dessert wine puts a nice finishing touch to an marvelous quiet dinner....exactly $100 after tip for a dinner for two....always a nice welcome back to sf dinner after a business trip....
author: Hen A.

description:
One of my bestest galpals was in town (Mindy B.) and after her rave review, we all decided to come here for dinner. 

The restaurant is extremely, extremely tiny and squishy, there isn't even a podium thingy for the hostess. It was then that I realized how lucky we were to get a reservation for 6 at 8:30pm on a Saturday night, having called in at around 7:45pm! Anything more than a table for two is asking too much.

Every dish we had (carpaccio, bruschetta, lasagna, gnocchi, etc.) was DELICIOUS! This food is truly authentic Italian food, even the way it is presented. This restaurant reminds me of Italy in every way. 

Food was consistently quality, made with skill & love, and hearty. One of our friends even scraped her plate completely clean. The food was amazing. I can't even dock a star for having to sit elbow to elbow and knee to knee at our table.

It just wouldn't be Mindy & Stella if dessert (in large portions) wasn't ordered - we had the creme caramel, tiramisu, and white pistachio gelato. EVERYONE at our table aggressively ate the dessert even after a huge meal, it was SO delicious. This was simply the best tiramisu that has ever met a plate and my stomach-- I would have easily eaten the whole thing, or ten of them. And the gelato was what truly made everyone happy that night. 

Dish after dish, everything pleased us so much and made for a fabulous, memorable dinner.

I would come here again, and again, and again.
author: Stella C.

description:
Fine italian food but nothing to write home about.  I had the vegetable minestrone soup, which was uninteresting.  Then I had a spinach pasta with salmon & pancetta which was tasty.  The cheesecake was also good.

It's more like 3.5 stars, and I might have given it 4, but it was at least 85 degrees in the restaurant.  Everyone seemed to be feeling it
author: Tim M.

description:
We had a craving for high-end pizza so stopped by Zero Zero only to find a 2 hour wait...yelped for an alternative and Pazzia to the rescue!  End of day -- the food was good, but lots of improvements can be made to the establishment.

The waitress was a sweet girl, but seems not all there from the very beginning.  Despite several tables being open, she left us standing for over 5 minutes with little instruction.  She never gave us clean/bigger plates after appetizers, and wanted a count of exactly how many we'd need.  She came by and smiled at us often, but was not good at observing what we needed (water, napkins, etc.)...we had to ask.

The decor of the place needs major work.  The artwork on the walls look like the default picture that came w/ the frame.  Looks like venue was not designed to be a restaurant -- so ventilation is poor.  They have to keep the door open to keep the place from fuming up...so on that cold rainy day...i had to keep my jacket on.

All that said -- I enjoyed the food:
--Bruschetta ($6) -- Nothing special, but fresh tomatoes.
--Funghi E Salsiccia ($13.5) -- mushrooms and sausage pizza  -- yummy pizza.  Crust is very thin.  Good size to share (~ 10").  Sausage tasted homemade and not too greasy.
--Calzone Romano  ($13) -- calzone with mozzarella, mushrooms, prosciutto, eggs and parmigiana cheese. Not the calzone i'm use to.  No tomatoe sauce -- only melted cheese.  Was very yummy though.  We were curious about the egg ingredient -- but ultimately couldnt find it in the dish.
--(Daily special) Spinach pasta with white wine sauce (~$15) - the best dish.  Too bad not a regular menu item.  Perhaps you can ask for it.  The spinach pasta had the best texture!!
author: Kendra W.

description:
The LASAGNA! Oh me, oh my, I have never had lasagna like this before! Ooey gooey cheesy baked pasta goodness with Bechamel sauce! I had wild dreams about this lasagna after my first time.

The pizzas are also very good and very very thin crust, true to the Italian style.

Delicious!

The first time I went to Pazzia, the waitress brought me the wrong pizza and actually looked unhappy when I asked to have my order corrected. She then told me that they would have to start all over and it would take too long, so I just agreed to keep the wrong order. I then kindly proceeded to ask for a side of sausage (since my original order had sausage on it) and she looked very unhappy, as if I had inconvenienced her. Annoyed as I was, I decided to be forgiving since the food was great. Service has been somewhat better since. Sooo, IF you happen to have a bad service experience, just disregard it because the food is all worth it!
author: Felicia C.

description:
I went to Pazzia last night for the first time in a number of years. I don't know if my memory is just getting fuzzy in my old age but I definitely remember it being much better.

The pizza was fine - cracker thin but lacking flavor. Service was great from the moment we walked in and I appreciate the fact that they split our Cesar salad for us without us having to ask. Wine seemed a bit pricey in comparison to the rest of the menu and my $9 glass was just 'eh'.

Three stars. Pazzia is definitely not a destination but if you're in the neighborhood (and/or aren't willing to wait an hour for Zero Zero) then you could do a lot worse.
author: phil h.

description:
**FAVE ITALIAN FARE IN SAN FRANCISCO**

This is one of my favorite Italian restaurants in SF, hands-down.

 It's quaint, reasonable, and customer-oriented. 

It's authentic, which I favor a great deal. 

The menu is in Italian with Engilsh translations. 

The wine selections are solid, more or less upscale Italian table wine. 

I have consistently ordered the lasagna and tiramisiu.

Pizzas are very popular here as well.

Overall, a pleasant Italian dining experience each and everytime in SOMA.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND.
author: Betty N.

description:
We came here after a LOOOOOOOOOOOOONG walk from my friend's apartment near the ballpark.  I was so tired that if they served a leather shoe covered in marinara sauce, I'm sure I would have ate it and gave it a 4-star review (hey come on, it's still a shoe.  No way a shoe is getting 5-stars!).  But, in an effort to give a fair review, I will try and empty out my head (shouldn't be too hard) and concentrate only on the restaurant itself.

After the aforementioned "trip" to Pazzia, we arrived here around 6pm on a Saturday night.  We promptly went to the host and asked for a table for 5.  "Do you have a reservation," he asked.  Oops!  I knew we forgot something.  We were told the wait would be about a half-hour.  We decided to avoid our urge to eat dessert first at Beard Papa's and just wait.  Good thing too because they rushed to get our table ready (i.e. boot people out) and it was ready in 10 minutes or so.  It was outside on a cold night, but who cares, food was on the way!  Yahoo!  We all ordered different things, from Pizza to Pasta to Carpaccio to Salad.  The food was way better than Olive Garden.  Yeah, I know, I'm actually comparing it to Olive Garden.  Not a fair comparison.  Sue me.

As good as the food was, I think the star of this restaurant was the service.  I don't remember what the server's or the host's were, but they were awesome!  The price wasn't too bad considering it wasn't Olive Garden (there I go again), but it wasn't bad.  As for going there again, probably not for awhile considering there are tons of restaurants I want to try around SF.  But, if I happened to be in the area again and I was hungry, I'd have to qualms about coming here (unless there was an Olive Garden around!).
author: Jamie J.

description:
For my week-long stay in SF, I was sure to pack plenty of workout clothes, my sneakers, charge up my mp3 playerâ"the works. It's day four: Have I worked out yet? No. Well, at least I can eat right... So where did I go for lunch? Pazzia, for a hearty helping of pizza! 

Okay, so it's not so healthy, but it's sooo good. (But give me some credit. I did order a salad.) I went along with other Yelptastic employees, Shenni Andrew C, which was an added treat to our lunch. With perfect weather, we proffered to sit outside,  but with limited seating for parties of two, that wasn't an option. No problem, though, because the inside was just as cozy. 

We started with warm, toasty bruschetta topped with yellow tomatoesâ"something I've never tried but highly enjoyed. True to Italian food fashion, the restaurant also served up fresh bread and olive oil for dipping, though some garlic Parmesan or red pepper could have boosted the wow-factor. Keeping with the carb theme (bruschetta and bread) I topped off my cravings with pizza. I kept it safe with the Margherita, The pizzas are very sizable for one or two people, but don't let the pictures fool you: The crust is super thinâ"which I love!â"so if you're famished, I recommend ordering one for yourself. I managed to scarf down three slices. It wasn't the best margharita pizza ever, but the crispy bread, herbs, tomato sauce and low-grease factor make it one worth trying. I also had a serving of the mussels, another recommendation for an appetizer or meal.

Overall, I have to say this would be a perfect spot for a cozy lunch, first date or even you and your S.O.'s "spot."
author: Farrah A.

description:
This is a nice Italian restaurant located near the financial district. I couldn't really tell by the yelp reviews that everyone dresses up to the restaurant, so we showed up super casual but it was ok anyways. We ordered the capaccio, spaghetti vongole, and the chicken breast with potatoes. The chicken was pretty good but the rest was pretty bland and could've used more flavor and sauce. The tiramisu was delicious though.

I had to minus a star for the bathroom. It was pretty nasty... there was pee all over the place... blahs... gross..

I'd probably just check out all the other restaurants before I would come back to here.
author: Cynthia C.

description: Pizza was delicious. I am from New York and have a high standard. That being said the pasta with truffle oil was average at best. What I was concerned about was the decor. wooden chairs that were not comfortable and tables that seem like they were going to tip over. The outside seating was literally metal fold out chairs.  For a place with a slightly higher price I expected more.  There was a party of 15 when we got there and the whole restaurant seemed a little overwhelmed by that. They were trying to be high-end but were kind of faking the funk. Pizza good. Probably wouldn't go back.
author: Kazzi F.

description: Came here for dinner last night, and it completely lived up to my expectations! The food was amazing, the service was impeccable, and the environment was so warm and welcoming. The homemade pastas were absolutely delicious, as was the pizza we ordered. Can't wait to come back here asap!
author: Rinki S.

description:
Solid italian restaurant in soma.

Prices are reasonable and dishes are very honest. No terribly fancy plating or sophisticated flavoring. Dishes tasted fresh and as they are supposed to. Bo surprises - and I mean that in a good way.

Does get busy so remember to make reservations.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Again, the boy and I were babysitting my pregnant sis (she's on bed rest so...she's immobile) and she wanted food. She ordered 3 pasta dishes and a chicken with prosciutto and mozzarella for the boy. The boy and I walked there and it's a very small place. It was pretty crowded for a Tuesday night. The owner or what not was straight up Italian and he was really nice. He kept saying "Prego!" 

Anyway, my dish was the tortellini with mushrooms and it was good. The cream wasn't over powering and it was just right. The boy's food was good, he devoured it...alongside the bread that came with it. My sis just picked on the two pasta dishes that she ordered...one with shrimp and the other with salmon. 

I told boy that we needed to go back there and he agreed...overall the food was good...the ambiance of the place was quite nice though since it's small, it can get pretty darn hot and crowded. Oh--the price wasn't bad either!
author: Cath M.

description: I came here because of all the great yelp reviews...but honestly it was NOT GOOD!  Maybe we just ordered the wrong things, but we were really really disappointed for what we got for the price.  My husband had salmon, and it was literally a small piece of grilled salmon and like 5 pieces of roasted vegetables on a large white plate.  The salmon wasn't even that great.  And it cost like $25.  Really?  I could have gotten salmon from trader joe's and it would have been just as good.  I ordered pasta, which was OK, but not great.   There are just so many great italian places in Soma...there is really no reason to go here.
author: Cindy K.

description: I had a great experience at this restaurant this past weekend.  I saw it on Check Please with my mom so when we were toying around with places for her birthday she mentioned going here.  All in all the experience was wonderful and we had a great time.  We started with the Bruschetta which had great heirloom tomatoes and I had a pasta blognese which was very tasty.  Everyone was very pleased with their dishes including my mom.  The place is small now but it looks like they will be expanding in to the store front next door.  I would definitely make it a point to come back.
author: Kirsten M.

description:
Just got back from a business trip.  My hotel said to try this restaurant and SO glad my business associates and I did.

The service was superb, the food was delicious and real italian.  The atmosphere was great!

And most of all I would tell you that our waitress (Laura) made sure that every part of our experience was perfect.  it was so good that we went a second night.
author: Troy W.

description: My work group went to a convention at Muscone and wanted to have lunch on the way back to the CalTrain station. This restaurant was great! The bread and oil and vinegar brought to the table was really delicious. We could have easily shared a pizza between 2-3 people. I had the smoked salmon sandwich and loved the salmon and having a little salad on the side was great. I could only eat half but it was really good. I didn't want to pay $15-20 for lunch, but would enjoy going back and trying their pastas....maybe for dinner.
author: luann B.

description:
Wow, this is what Italian fare in America should be.  The individual wood-fired pizzas are just like the better ones I've had in Italy... and I find the casual but candle-lit environment and attractive, pleasant wait staff to be similarly authentic.  

B+ grade overall.  A for being the best option in a sea of blah SOMA dining.
author: Geoff D.

description:
Went here for a surprise early birthday dinner and it was very nice. It's a small restaurant with lots of flavor. I really enjoyed the authentic Italian waiters and dishes. We had the seafood risotto and sausage pizza. It's nice to savor a true Italian pizza in SOMA. (I know authentic - I was in Italy for a month and I tried pizza in Milan, Rome and Sicily.) The service was very prompt and inviting!

This place is such a gem!
author: Lisa R.

description: The best thin-crust pizza I had outside of Italy.  When you pull off a slice, the cheese just goes on and on and on - yep, just like in TV commercials -  and you literally have to scoop it up and cut it off.  Everything tastes fresh, with a real Italian flair.  I can't say enough good things about this place.  I'm completely sold and won over!
author: Kristen S.

description: Lasagnie was great. Full body taste. We had lunch for 6 , everyone enjoyed their food. Deffinetly recommend it . Good ratio on price / quality
author: Roman S.

description:
Did Pazzia just go through a change of management? I just had a Margherita pizza there that came with no fresh basil (??) and the crust was chewy instead of the authentically crispy crust I'd come to expect. All of the staff that were always there before were nowhere to be found. 

Hopefully Pazzia bounces back because it used to be one of the only five star places near Yerba Buena.
author: Aaron V.

description:
I really didn't find anything particularly memorable about this restaurant.  Pizza was fairly alright - spicy sausage, tomato sauce, and mozzarella.  (Please don't make me go look up the Italian name.)  Much too much oil though... I did like the thin crust.  Not too much sausage on the pizza however!  The taste had some sort of licorice-y thing going on.

Lasagna was sad.  I really wanted to get lasagna as I was watching the Food Network and I just had an utmost craving... but I wish I had chosen something else.  Not enough meat in the filling.  Was surprised to see carrots there!  Interesting touch I suppose, but I prefer more tomatoes in my sauce.  Didn't feel very flavourful at all.
author: Carolyn L.

description:
Still my fave pizza place in the area... Thin and crispy. Salami, mushroom, and garlic!

The one time I did dine in for pizza was not a good experience since the pizza still seemed doughy and soggy. Eww. I'll just stick to take out.
author: Helen V.

description: I have been going here for a few years. Great kcal trattoria type restaurant with authentic italian food. First introduced to this place by an italian friend of mine. The owner is great. They are working on an expansion for awhile now and not sure when that will be ready but great pasta and pizza and entrees. Try the tiramisu and lemoncillo! I have never had a bad experience here!
author: Tina L.

description:
Solid authentic food (owners have another restaurant in Italy). Caprese salad was small (three pieces of mozzarella) but tasty. Excellent bread. Entrees are flavorful. Good service (though they seem to have staffing issues at times).

My one complaint is this place gets crazy loud when it's busy. I mean yes, the review summary says "Loud", but this is loud like a packed bar on a Friday night (even though there's no bar here) rather than loud like a restaurant. Everything else about the place would say "bring that special someone for a nice meal", but if you attempt that when the place is busy? You'll be lucky to hear each other, much less put the moves on your sweetie.

Highly recommended for the food and the service, but heavy caution on the atmosphere if it's not what you're expecting.

As a side note, they are in the process of expanding into the space next door. It's possible the tables will spread out and the place will quiet down. We will see.
author: TJ P.

description:
Solid meal yet still affordable?  I'll take it! Nice work, Pazzia.  

Our party of 5 sat outside, even though it was around 55 degrees (welcome to SF summer), but we figured it would be better and less noisey since half our party was French and the other half English; therefore a lot of franglais was spoken.   NO HEAT LAMPS! They should add this amenity, for sure. 

Unfortunately, we didn't split anything, which I think was a mistake.  This is probably the type of place you want where you split a few pizzas between the entire table, but not everyone in our party wanted pizza.  We had an order of the chicken stuffed with prosciutto, which looked great and came with a plentiful helping of potatoes and broccoli.  The mussels, which I ordered were pretty good! The light tomato sauce was a nice change from a white wine sauce, which is what I'm usually served when I go with mussels.  The mussels themselves were on the smaller side and had there not been bread on the table, I would still be starved.  We also had a margherita pizza and an order of spaghetti bolognese.  We all thought everything was good, but nothing spectacular.   

Service was fine and they were right on time with our reservation.
author: Jenny W.

description: It looks like a mall shop from the outside, but you will think you are in Florence after your first bite!  Excellent service and beautiful servers.  The gnocchi pombodoro was very fresh and flavorful as was the chicken marsala!  Dessert choices are excellent.  Make this a nice long date night choice!  Good pandora channel in the background at an appropriate volume.
author: April M.

description:
OH. On the same level as Tommaso's but without the warm loving ambiance. However, they have SUPER HOT waitresses.

The raw beef is very yummy. Gives you a different take on raw beef. Well-marinated and melts in your mouth. Thinly sliced.
author: Betty W.

description: This is one of the overall Italian experiences I've ever had. Food was amazing. Coffee was fantastic. Atmosphere perfect, even down to the bathroom being in the kitchen. A must see in San Fran!
author: Dave M.

description: Excellent food, especially for the price.  Best veal chop in the city! Excellent thin crust pizza. Fresh salads. Great pizza. Very small, so get there early.
author: Jim D.

description:
OMG delicious food, tremendous service, I'll be back for sure.

We showed up later than we were aiming for, 9:05, with a hard deadline to be done by 10 to meet a friend around the corner.  There were NO seats inside, but the hostess went above and beyond to get us drinks outside while we waited (luckily it was a nice night and not too cold) and the menus so we could order before actually being seated.  As soon as a table was available, they cleared it right away, got us moved inside, and our food arrived within 5 minutes.

I had the Pollo alla Medici and it was divine.  I felt a bit sacrilegious not getting pasta at an Italian restaurant, but the mushroom gravy was rich without being too thick or heavy, the asparagus was cooked to perfection, and the potatoes were excellent as well.  I had a Florette or two of broccoli but it had garlic in it and I'm not the biggest fan of heavy garlic.  Not that it mattered - I was stuffed after devouring everything else.

My one complaint was the noise level.  There were a couple of larger birthday parties going on and the restaurant is currently not that big (they're in the process of expanding into the space next door) so it was rather loud and a bit hard to hear my friend's conversation.

I went with friends tonight, so I'll definitely be back with my husband.  Conveniently there's a parking lot on the corner for just $10 if you plan to hit one of the many lounges or clubs in the area after dinner as we did.
author: Trisha F.

description:
Cute little Italian place.

I came here with three other people on a Friday night at 6:30 pm without reservations. Thankfully they were able to seat us right away. 

We ordered three pizzas - I don't remember the exact names, but one was the sausage with mushroom, one had artichokes, mushrooms and olives, and one had prosciutto and arugula (my fave and my choice!), as well as a carpaccio. Despite coming with two hungry boys, we still had leftovers. The food was served in reasonable time, and the pizzas were overall pretty tasty. 

The only comment I have to make is - I was a little disappointed with their service. They were a little brusque and were definitely not warm with their greetings. I'm not sure if it's because we didn't order wine or enough food - although it was plentiful for us. 

I would come back again, but it would only be for their food!
author: Kimberly F.

description:
Food was decent. But after receiving our meal, we were ignored. Nobody came by to check on us, even as the place became less busy (the place was super busy when we arrived, but it became less busy, so they should have had time to check on us). After finishing our meal, the waiter didn't talk to us for the next 30 minutes? Besides not checking on us, he didn't ask if we wanted anything else from the menu. We were simply ignored. Not entirely. Our water was refilled and our plates were cleared by the wait staff. We finally asked for the check, and waited an extra 20 minutes and asked for our check again. In the meantime, all the other tables seemed to have been taken care. People came and went.

Fed up with waiting longer and being ignored longer, we simply got up to leave, hoping this would get someone to hand us the check. We could have just walked out of there and no one would have noticed, but that's not like us. My husband said to the owner or manager, "I would like to pay, but I asked for my check 20 minutes ago and no one brought it." The owner/manager asked who we had told. He started arguing with us that we hadn't told anybody. We said we didn't even get our left over pizza. We argued, but the owner didn't even try to listen or resolve the situation by even trying to find out who our server was to ask what had happened. He accused us of making a scene, but the only one making a scene was him. We could tell he didn't want it to escalate any further and he just gave us our left over pizza that had been sitting on their counter. We were resistant of leaving without paying. That's not like us. Anyway, he threw us out saying "Get out of here! I'll remember you both!" Why would we even want to come back with the way we were treated. We don't want anyone to go through what we went through. Do yourself a favor. Skip this place.
author: Kate C.

description:
This is probably as close as you can get to a trattoria here in SF.  They serve pretty genuine Italian food and the waiters are Italian, which only adds to the atmosphere.

The pizzas are pretty good.  The crust is cooked to a nice chewiness.  So glad to see they don't overcrisp the crust so that it cuts up your mouth when you chew.  I can tell they put a lot of care into making this crust.  Better than Goat Hill in my book.

The toppings are also nice.  Good combinations and good ratios of sauce (thin layer so the crust doesn't get soggy), cheese (a good even layer), and toppings.  I like how they don't overload on the toppings, which usually ends up overwhelming and defeating the crust.

I think I just like Italian style pizza.  And Pazzia does a decent job of it.  I can see myself coming here regularly for lunch.
author: Jean K.

description: A small local place with great tasty food and very nice and friendly staff. We got couple of dishes, pizza, pasta and salad, all very tasty. Went there the first time randomly, found on yelp and been a fan since then. Recommended.
author: Haleh H.

description: Everything I have ever had from here has been delicious. Wine, antipasti, pizza, pasta, everything. The staff and owner are accommodating.  The prices are also reasonable, considering how good everything is. I took my team here and everyone loved it. Definitely check it out.
author: Kelly J.

description:
Came in with friends without a reservation and luckily for us a table just cancelled so we were seated immediately. Free warm bread + olive oil is always a plus. I got the funghi pizza and it filled the entire dinner plate. For $13, I think it's pretty cheap considering the location. Everything on the menu is pretty much until $20, so it's very doable to spend about $20 per person on a nice meal.

As for the food, I think it's ok. It's good but it's not amazing; for my pizza that was true. The crust is thin but it's also a little too hard and it was rather soggy in the middle. The flavor was "eh", again nothing special. Delfina pizza is much better. My friend's risotto was tasty though.

The staffs were friendly but overall, I don't think this place was spectacular in any way except for the price. We had a decent meal but didn't think too much of it. Don't get me wrong, this is a great place to frequent if you're in the area often, but it's just not for me.
author: Lucy D.

description: Pazzia has been around for a long time and hasn't changed much. Which is a good thing. It's an unassuming, down to earth little place with fantastic food and excellent service. The staff is always very friendly, happy, and welcoming. I've eaten here countless times for lunch and dinner, and everything I've ever ordered has been delicious. Beware of the bread, it's addictive.
author: Jen M.

description:
I think I'm actually going to give this place 5 stars! Maybe it was cuz I was  with my girlfriends and we just went cake tasting? Service was great - really friendly.

Appetizers:
burrata - YUM. creamy mozzarella, salty prosciutto, perfectly dressed arugula
carpaccio - a bit too meaty, but I still ate quite a bit.

Entrees:
mushroom penne - surprisingly good! deep mushroom flavor.
potato gnocchi - tender gnocchi, great sauce, great cheese!

Bottle of white was perfect, and tiramisu was delicate.
author: Carol L.

description: I was a frequent customer for lunch and dinner, both for business and personal outings from 2000-2007. Just went back for the first time in 7 years, still amazing! The customer service here is incredible. The food is so flavorful and filling. Perfect for anyone who prefers naturally cooked meals vs food doused with sodium or fried and tasteless. True northern Italian delight. And the staff are never hard on the eyes lol! Massimo, the owner, puts a ton of love and passion into his restaurant and it is very apparent. Last night I had the Fettuccine, which was amazing...the Saffron sauce was made to perfection. I also love their Pappardelle, Lasagna, Risotto, Gnocchi, mussels, bruschetta, etc. so much to love! Yummy Prosecco too. The best thing is their Tiramisu. Delicious!!! Parking can be tough, be prepared to pay. Noise level is low. Outdoor eating during nice weather reminds me of Italy. Love this place, still my fav Italian restaurant ever.
author: Miss B.

description:
We found this little gem on Yelp and it was great find. The food was as good as the reviews described it. We had the clams and pasta along with a sausage/tomato pizza. The service was a little ho hum, but I think it was because we went for lunch on a quiet day. Otherwise, we enjoyed ourselves and felt like it was a great little taste of Italy.

If you go there, you have to use the restroom. It is right in the kitchen, so you can get a peak at the staff cooking.
author: Emily B.

description: This place is GREAT.  It's a cozy little restaurant that is really convenient to get to, and the food is amazing.  I ordered the spaghetti alle vongole (clams), and it was really fresh and simple -- the ingredients really stood out themselves.  So delicious.  The staff were also really friendly and accommodating.  I'd like to come back for dinner here sometime again soon.
author: Mel G.

description: Great place outside of crowded areas of the city. We were there for a dinner. My measure of pizza quality is margarita and it was top notch there. Lasagna was very good as well. I also had a glass of Chianti, it was served perfect temperature, very aromatic. If you're looking of a great food and not too many people this place is worth checking out.
author: Timur F.

description:
We had a great dinner al fresco last night. The place was crowded but we made some no hassle reservations. 

We went with bruschetta, split a house salad w pine nuts and for entrees went w the pepperoni pizza and marghaerita pizza. We each had a glass of Classico chianti. 

The service was great and the flavors were also great. I especially appreciated the fresh flavors of the local produce tomatoes and basil especially noticable on the bruschetta.

I would recommend this joint as a break from Italian that you find in north beach.
author: Rich B.

description:
We came here for lunch one day from work, and had a large group, probably about 8.  We were seated immediately and their service was quite attentive.  I was impressed with their ability to handle the large group, and even more impressed with the calzone I had for lunch!  Admittedly, I was terribly hungover and craving a calzone like it was no one's business, so this may be a completely biased review, but the calzone really was just delicious.  They added an egg in it, which I hadn't had before, and it really just made the calzone.  It was also HUGE... I ate half for lunch and had the other half for dinner, and was stuffed after both meals.

My coworkers got a mix of pastas and pizzas and everyone enjoyed their food.  Definitely somewhere I'd like to return to.
author: Samantha B.

description: This place came highly recommended by a good friend of mine, and it lived up to the hype! Massimo and his staff treated us like family and the food was incredible! We had this experience over a month ago, but we are still talking about it today! Cheers to Pazzia Restaurant and Massimo...of course with Fernet. We will be back.
author: James B.

description: The manager of this place is terrible. All the great reviews and crowds from the convention has created an arrogant and rude treatment of customers. There may be many friends of the owners and staff who cover up the worst management in the city with the great reviews they post.. Do your self a favor and go to one of the many other restaurants who care about the treatment of customers instead of  profits
author: Lawrence F.

description:
They don't seem to know how to properly staff for busy times, and the pizzas are WOW expensive.

However, for thin, thin, thin crust pizza... this place is great. Yummy cheese, not too much sauce, fresh toppings.

Recommended if you want to spend $18 for one individual person's pizza after tax and tip. I, however, do not often wish to do so.
author: Zach S.

description:
Mamma mia this place will make you one happy bambino. Afterwards you and your "gumar" can pop on by the bad-da-bing and drink some vino. Ok enuff with the cliches :)   

This place is great though ... the food is flavorful and they keep it old school and basic... fresh.  The staff is great and some are equally delicious.... a few should be on the dessert menu.
author: Jeremy R.

description: Absolutely delicious and they do take out!  What keeps them from being a five star is the prices are a tad high and the menu on Yelp/Google/Etc for Pazzia is out of date...  So my $9 pasta was $17...  Pazzia needs to send new menu's to review sites to mitigate that issue.
author: Chase W.

description:
I'm currently on a "all-things-Italian" high. I have had urges of learning Italian (which I am), reading Italian poetry, and drinking italian wine (tasty). Luckily, I came across this resturaunt because a good friend had come into town and saw the many good reviews on yelp - and let me be the first to tell you that the stars on Yelp are well earned. 

We had arrived a bit later in the evening, without a reservation (which I highly recommend you get), so we had to wait for about 20 to 30 minutes. No matter, the moment a group left the table it was cleaned and reset for our group. While we waiting for them to set up the table the manager (a very personable and  sincere man) asked if we would like some wine while we waited and gave us the menu so we could get a head start on the ordering. Afterward we were seated we were greeted by a very knowledgeable waitress who helped us with our wine selection and food selection. 

Now comes the part where I attempt to describe the food with words to entice you to come. Two of my friends shared a spaghetti dish with clams, which happened to be amazing! They have a very fresh supply of clams (no fishy smell). My other friend got a vegetarian spaghetti with sea bass - also fantastic! I personally love salmon, so I get this ravioli dish that had this crazy orange sauce and fresh salmon stuffed inside each one. Each bite was one to die for...unfortunately, the portion was a bit tiny (about 8-10 pieces), and I had consumed the food in a matter of minutes. 

With the food aside, the restaurant itself gives off a very "homey" feel to it, which I personally enjoy. It's not one of those italian or french restaurants where you need to dress up and get all fancy. To me, it gave off more of a warm, comfortable, and relaxed vibe. When you enter the restaurant the place was bustling with families and friends just drinking wine and having a good time. It's not too loud where you can't hear yourself, but it's also not so quiet you can hear the chef breathing - it's just right. They're were couples having a romantic evening together, tables of 10+ people laughing and sharing stories, and elderly individuals just sitting and enjoying a glass of wine - like a said, very relaxed. :)

So please, do yourself a favor and check out this restaurant. It's a great place of almost any occasion, and honestly, I didn't rave too much about the food because - well - it's just damn good. There's not much more to say than that. I figured, if a place is always packed, then it must be good. :) So please check this place out if you're ever in the area, it's worth your time.
author: Alfred B.

description:
I've been here a couple of times, and this has definitely become a pop spot among my group of friends. I always order something seafoody and this last time I got a linguine with clams, mussels and shrimp. There was a healthy serving and it was very well spiced. We had the house wine (they have good picks and you can't go wrong. Hess, if I remember correctly). 

Surely, a bit pricey but I think they have a good spectrum of antipasti, pasta and dessert (+wine) that'll give you an excellent dinner experience.
author: Dilip R.

description: A really decent Margherita pizza. Not Italy quality but fresh with great crust and sauce. Tiny, crowded but the server was working her ass off and I really appreciated it. I'll be back.
author: Tim R.

description: The best Italian in San Francisco! Linguine and clams is the best!!
author: Mackenzie M.

description:
I come here for one thing:
The calzone larger than your plate that's soooo fabulously over the top they have to serve it to you with a steak knife. 

Every once in a while, when life gets me down and I feel like indulging in an emotional eating extravaganza, I head here to get this calzone. There are two different options, the one I always get has cheese, egg, prosciutto and mushrooms. Pretty much all of my favorite foods in a not so little bundle. When you cut into it, the egg yolk oozes out and the cheesy goodness combines with the salty meat and savory mushrooms for an insanely delicious experience. This restaurant is now two blocks from my new office and I've already stopped once on the way home for a calzone to go. Now out of fairness, I've tried other food here as well and it's all good. You'd never expect this tiny place to be so wonderful, but it is.
author: Shoshana D.

description:
Yum! I can't wait to go here again!

This is a small restaurant and gets pretty loud, but it's a fun atmosphere. The servers were all very friendly and attentive. The food was delicious and unique!

Great apps, we had the burrata, which was very fresh, and the carpaccio, which was very flavorful.

For main courses, the mushroom penne was delicious with big chunks of mushrooms and a sauce I wanted to wipe up with my bread. We had a pizza too, but I don't remember much about it.

Tiramisu was a great way to end the meal!
author: Mabel L.

description: One of my favorite pizza joint in SF. They have the best pizza and good quality food. Awesome service too. Their pizza taste like the ones you eat when you go to Italy. I love this place everything in the menu pasta and salad dishes are just too good.
author: Joiera C.

description: I've been here a couple of times for dinner and have not been disappointed yet. The pastas and pizzas are all pretty good. The pizza crust is thin, not like your typical NY-style, but more like a flat bread. The grilled veggies antipasto is my favorite!
author: Amy N.

description:
This place is great! Truly italian food and very well prepared!
We were a large group and we sampled many dishes from the menu.
We started with some thin crust pizzas as appetizer: "funghi & salsiccia"  and "capricciosa", both delicious. 

After having read many misleading opinions on italian pizza, I feel like making a little comment at this point. There is no such thing as an "italian pizza". In fact, there are different kind of italian pizzas:

(1) Napolitan pizza is THE original pizza, some of its variants (margherita and marinara) are D.O.P. products (Denominazione di Origine Protetta) and, among other predefined requisites, they are supposed to have thin crust in the middle and thick on the edge;
(2) Roman pizza is the traditional "overall" thin crust;
(3) the thick focaccia-like Sicilian pizza;
(4) several other variants (focaccia genovese, pizza al tegamino, etc.).

The first two (the most popular in pizzeria's) are supposed to be foldable without cracking. New York style pizza is not very different from a Roman pizza, it is just bigger and typically more oil-ish. It was introduced in New York by italians, who basically kept the original recipes but made them larger and with different toppings.

After this short premise, I must say that Pazzia delivers a good example of italian thin crust pizza (more Roman than Napolitan) with a good choice of ingredients. In particular, the one with mushrooms and salsiccia (in this case a typical sausage with fennel seeds) offers a really rich combination of flavours.
   
As main dish, I had homemade spinach gnocchi with a meat sauce and it was nothing less than divine. The tiramisù was also worth to be mentioned: soft, creamy, juicy, not too sweet, with a strong espresso flavour and still, surprisingly,  relatively light.  

The service was impeccable, our waitress was very friendly and competent, ready to give info and good advices.  
They also have an artisan italian beer, called Menabrea (from Biella, near Torino), which I recommend to anybody interested in trying an example of  good italian beer (forget Moretti or Peroni ...).

Everybody at our table was enthusiast at the end of the meal ...
Full score with no doubt!
author: Andrea L.

description:
I have to start this out by saying that: Christopher K is the sexiest man alive. He is my hero and I love him more that words can express. He is truly the most awesomest person I know. No, it's not because of his hair-do, or his piercings, or even his mysterious yelp picture. It's not because of any of these things.... It's because he is a yummy food finding god.

Ahh Yelp events. They are so memorable. So I attended my first official yelp event as Christopher S's  plus one ( I am not elite). I like to think that maybe one day I will be, but that is another story for another day. It would be an understatement to say that I was tipsy when Christopher K led me Jason, and Christopher S here. The food was so delicious, just sitting here writing this review is making me want to hop in my car and drive to the city just so that I can dine here again. I had the filet and the boys had the tortellini's and lasagna (which are even more amazing when you steal them off other peoples plates, than when you order them yourself, at least that's my story). The food was really good. I just can't describe how good exactly, it was like my taste buds began singing praises to the chef god. I was tempted to start licking the plates. Really I was. 

If you have not been here you should go. Get in a cab and ask for them to take you to Pazzia. It's so good you don't even need to be hungry to enjoy it. Really. Go now.
author: Camille A.

description: The pizza is delicious - just what I'd hope for in a thin-crust pizza. The dining room is a bit small, and the tables can feel a little cramped if you have the full number of people at them, but the food is quite good.
author: Amber Y.

description:
I thought this place was good, not great, but good. I'm not from San Fran, so I don't know what the place(s) to go to are for Italian, but if you're looking for a pretty decent meal, Pazzia is worth checking out.

We started off with the bruschetta, which was really tasty. Not sure where the olive oil was coming from, but it was very good.

For my dinner, I got the rigatoni with sausage and mushrooms. The pasta was cooked perfectly, but I wasn't overly impressed with the red sauce or the amount of sausage they gave me. I felt kind of skimped out. My friend had the sausage and mushroom pizza, which was very good.

Best part of the meal was the tiramisu. Definitely recommend trying it if you're not full already.
author: Jared D.

description:
I had a small salad here today. The added chicken was so crispy, fresh and tasteful. The menu said Arugula and that's why I ordered it but they put spinach instead and some other strange things. Everyone else ordered Pizza and it looked great: Thin crust and seemed like they really enjoyed it. 

Not a great salad place though. Although, I'd go back for that delicious chicken!
author: T I.

description: I had dinner here the other night on a recent trip to San Francisco. It is a small restaurant which makes for a very warm atmosphere. I had the bruschetta which was just like any average preparation. However, the pasta was very good. I had the spinach [pasta with salmon. The taste of that is still lingering fresh in my mouth. Service was good , certainly a good experience.
author: Ahana M.

description:
Warm atmosphere (especially given the chill outside), good service, and great food made me very happy we picked this restaurant for lunch. It's a splurge at $12-18 for most dishes, but certainly worth it. The complimentary bread was warm and delicious and was served with a very good olive oil. Most dishes are quite large, such that my sun-dried tomato pasta was both lunch and dinner.

The staff were friendly, attentive, and unobtrusive, perfect for a social lunch when you don't have a lot of time. I definitely hope to be back soon. Good food, good value, good company - that's Italian enough for me!
author: Bill B.

description:
I love their crispy pizza, probably the best in the city.
The food is great, the service gets a bit slow.
Friendly waiters, but the restaurant is very small and gets pretty loud.
One time I was surprised our waitress taking orders and pick up the phone at the same time!! Hey, that's rude, hire somebody to pick up the phone.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Surprisingly good pizza, salad, and bread/bruschetta. 

Service was terrific, food was very good, and it was an all around good time. 

The special, pizza bianca, was divine. Caesar salad, perfect for lunch or starter for din!
author: Art A.

description:
Lovely memories.

Tasty pasta (fresh and Barilla), antipasti, PIZZA, and fresh seafood.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
A smallish, bustling spot on 3rd Street serving good pizza and pasta.  Tables are tight so if you're looking for a quiet intimate experience this isn't the place for you. Pazzia was packed during a recent week night visit.  After we were seated, folks were waiting for a table.  Always a good sign.  Try to sit against the wall on either side where there's less jostling about.

The house salad was a good place to start - lots of romaine,  radicchio, arugula was a little sparse, vinaigrette with fresh garlic but not overpowering, rich nutty parmesan, Reggiano maybe, and crunchy house made croutons, I'm sure made from their yummy bread.  The Bresaola was disappointing, the beef mushy and coming apart, hard to describe.  The bread is wonderful by the way.

The Capricciosa pizza was a mixed bag.  The crust was near perfect - crunchy, chewy with good tug, some char, with nice palate pleasing flavor and scent.  The tomatoes. artichoke and olives all worked well together but the prosciutto hovered over the pie like Aladdin's magic carpet.  Tried to cut it into pieces and have a piece with every bite but it didn't seem to work.  Daily pasta with farfalle, chicken and rabe was tasty but nothing special, not enough of the garlicy rabe to my taste.

We had a tasty wine, a red blend recommended by our server and a good value at $30.  The wines appeared all reasonably priced.  The wait staff and owner were attentive, friendly and welcoming.  Of course as close as everyone is, seating wise, it would be hard not to be.  All in all Pazzia gets a solid 'Good' but not great mark.  Probably worth trying again.
author: Boom B.

description:
Very nice neighborhood feeling, bustling and full of friendly people every night of the week.   Great service and good food.  We had a caprese salad -- very fresh, although one point of suggestion would be that they use meatier, beefsteak-style tomatoes rather than normal supermarket greenhouse tomatoes.   Had the sausage pizza -- amazing crust, and great flavors.   
It would be nice if some of these restaurant pages could update the prices.  The prices are way out of date.   Salads are $6-8, pizzas are $11-15.  
Overall, a welcome part of the neighborhood.
author: eric s.

description:
I didn't want to give this place 3 stars, because their menu looked so amazing, the waitresses were so friendly and helpful, and it's a neighborhood joint....but, the roasted chicken that I ordered was dry and overcooked (although the rosemary they placed on top as seasoning was very fresh).  Perhaps it was my fault for ordering a meat dish and maybe they are more known for their pastas and pizzas, but I had had pasta for lunch and needed my protein.  

Anyways, the red wine they recommended was full-bodied and amazing, although a bit steep, I thought at $32 a bottle.  I'll give this place another chance, only because I was dying to try their risotto but wasn't in the mood for it and I want to believe that not all of their meals are disappointing.
author: Nina B.

description:
After our party of 6 were told that Zero Zero would be an hour and a half wait, we Yelped and found Pazzia about a block and a half away. Sold!

The wait staff was sweet and the place is cozy and cute. The bread that came out before our salads and entrees was pretty good too.

But that's all the nice things I have to say. The $8 house salad was disappointingly small and obviously overpriced for greens, pine nuts, and ONE slice of tomato.

But I should have cherished that one tomato....

Because then my Margherita Pizza was delivered. I looked in disbelief at the CHEESE PIZZA sitting in front of me. Let me back up - the staff here is Italian and I was falsely under the impression that that would have an impact on the authenticity of the Italian cuisine. But here I was staring down at a $12 slightly-larger-than-personal size CHEESE pizza labeled as a Pizza Margherita. I asked the waitress if this was indeed the Margherita or their had been a mistake. She assured me that it was the correct pizza. I asked about the lack of basil and tomatoes on top. She asked if I'd like to have some fresh basil on top .... well DUH - that is half of what makes up the pizza I ordered. She brought it back with some sliced up pathetic basil on top of this greasy thin-crust cheap cheese pizza.  

I was pissed. I should have sent it back or asked to speak with the manager. But I didn't.

My boyfriend's sausage and mushroom pizza was also sub-par. Their are only 2 beers available and they are both $6/bottle. Or BYOB wine with a $20 corkage fee. Whatever!

For 6 of us (two non-drinkers, and the other 4 having 2 beers each + salads + entrees) the bill with gratuity added automatically (dick move) was ~$225. Ridiculous for awful pizza, small salads, and semi-decent Italian beers.

I'll stick to Pizza Orgasmica.
author: Whitney M.

description: Again in San Francisco Pazzia is my favorite stop. I had the lasagna this time, it was incredible.
author: Richard B.

description: The space was packed and just bursting. The service was excellent and definitely was very chill, almost that European feel. The servers were attentive and came back to check on you but never made you feel rushed. The food was delicious. I am not sure if the pasta we ordered was fresh but it was cooked perfectly. The cream sauce and the mushrooms were such a great combo and add some chicken and that gets you a happy tummy. The bread was so soft and great to snack on while waiting for your meal. The house white was more on the dry side but had a really crisp and nice finish. Great meal.
author: Eve C.

description: Superb fresh food. Small space but worth the wait. The owner puts a lot of attention into his food and service
author: Karyn G.

description: Everything was generally good here - but nothing was great.  We made a reservation for 7 on a Friday, and had no problem getting right in.  The restaurant is very small, and actually it was only about 1/3 full when we got there, it did fill up with a wait by the time we left about 8:30.  The atmosphere and decoration seems to be lacking, but the big open window to the kitchen was neat.  Our waitress was aloof and when asked what wine to pair with my gnocchi the response was "well, white or red would be good."  Really?  Anyway, the wine I ended up blindly picking was very good.  Next time I sm in town I would try some place different, but I would come back to Pazzia if some one was inclined as everyone in our party enjoyed their food.
author: Shelby B.

description:
[Review by Kel]

I do [heart] this place so very much. The pizza is a different style pizza than Zero Zero (which I also love dearly), but they serve very traditional Italian food, remeniscent to what I ate in Italy this summer. Consequently, there is a Pazzia sister restaurant in Florence, so you know this place is legit. :)

I haven't been here in a few months, so I can't comment on the current state of the food, but of the several times I have been here in the past, I've really enjoyed my meals.
author: Kel S.

description: We had a delicious dinner last night in this crowded but super-friendly place! The bresaola was wonderful, as were the minestone, sausage pizza, and salmon with kalamata and pancetta on homemade spinach taglierini! The grilled veggies were just OK, and maybe there could have been a bit more gorgonzola in our Medici salad. We loved it though, and look forward to going back!!
author: Susan S.

description:
good:- bread and pizza were good. simple basil pizza tasted very nice.. and raviolli was quite awesome. 
not-to-expectation:- gnocchi -- pasta itself was good.. but sauce was undercooked..tasted like just tomatoes..but it had mozrilla which was quite nice ; fettuccine with prawns -- was not flavorful enough.. almost bland. 
overall.. way better italian restaurants in the city. will come here just for pizza and ravioli. !
author: vix a.

description: Disappointing.  I chose the restaurant based on favorable Yelp reviews but my experience was terrible.  My entree still had not arrived 15 minutes after my wife's entree, so I sat watching all of the bugs on the wall.  I ended up canceling my entree once my wife finished hers.  Bummer.
author: Russ H.

description: Fantastic.  Brought a 6 month old and a 2 year old to dinner - very family friendly, yet still upscale enough to be an enjoyable meal.  Ordered bruschetta, sautéed broccoli, and 3 pizzas.  The Daviola pizza is excellent.  Very friendly staff, good wine, great food.  Can't go wrong with this spot.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Their pizzas and homemade pastas are great. Their pizzas are the real itialian thin crust pizzas.  Their lasagna is probably one of my favorite things.  Their tiramisu is very good as well.

It's always tough to choose what to order since so many things look so tasty.

Service - the ladies are always pleasant and very nice and helpful.
author: Becca L.

description:
This trendy, hip and international place is always busy for a reason, it could be that you get the fancy restaurant experience without the price tag. Or perhaps a staff speaks a sexy , foreign language and is easy on the eyes.
Whatever the case may be, it's always a good time and maybe, like a Woody Allen film, you'll find yourself pining for a dalliance with one or more members of your dinner party.
author: G K.

description: Holy Ravioli! I had a great meal here Saturday night.  I ordered the ricotta & spinach ravioli with meat sauce and it was piping hot, rich and delicious. It was so good that I'm sure I'll be tempted to order the same dish when I come back BUT I am also dying to try the Tortelloni. The table next to me had it and it looked GREAT (and I could hear them oohing and ahhing over it). The portions are adequate (my meal was so good, I could have eaten more!) and the price is reasonable for the area. Our server was super friendly and efficient. I'll be back for sure.
author: K. H.

description:
$20 corkage fee. Really?

We had a birthday boy among us. Asked the owner if he could do anything to make it special. He said "I can put a candle on any dessert he orders." Lame-o!

Food was too expensive for a 'meh' taste. The only thing that gives this place any stars at all is the great company that made the experience tolerable. 

Oh, and Sorbet (Lemon + Raspberry) was eye-popping. In a very sour and upleasant way.

What is the Italian restaurant doing in the middle of SOMA anyway?
author: Tatyana S.

description:
We got lucky when we found this place last Friday night while walking from Cal Train to our destination. We were hungry and this placed seemed appealing with it's outside seating area and delicious smells. 

Our wait was about 10 minutes which was great for a Friday night about 7:30pm. When we arrived, we had huge backpacks on because we were heading out to go camping that weekend via bus from San Francisco. The restaurant manager Massimo was very accomodating and let us put our bags off to the side so that we could dine without bags under our feet. 

We started out with Bruschetta which was awesome! Loved the large pieces of bread loaded with lots of yellow and red tomatoes, garlic and basil.  The bread was toasted just right.

My husband ordered a chicken breast dish with a mushroom wine sauce that was pretty tasty. It came with a side of broccoli that was cooked perfectly! I ordered a fusilli dish with eggplant and tomatoes. I enjoyed it but it didn't wow me. Sadly my dish was bland and boring. We also ordered tiramisu to end our dinner date together and that was really good. They make it on a daily basis here.

I probably wouldn't make the trek here souly for the entrees but the bruschetta was amazing and so was the tiramisu. I would definitely come back for those. Plus the service we received was very nice and prompt. We had a really nice conversation with the owner Massimo who seems to really have a passion for what he is doing.

This restuarant is in the middle of being expanded so look for more tables in the near future.
author: Monica L.

description:
I've been here twice for dinner in three weeks, I think it's time for a review!

So, the first time I went I had the special pizza- the vegetarian (which, by the way, seems to always be the special. Along with pepperoni). It has eggplant, zucchini and mushrooms on it. The pizza was paper-thin with good sauce and melty cheese. The crust does get soggy, but it is super thin. I was pretty impressed.
 The second time I had the mushroom pizza- essentially the same thing as the vegetarian, but with only mushrooms. Still good, but now it seems like a repeat. We also had the beet salad. Yum! A nice combo of beets, goat cheese, walnuts and greens. I think it could have used a bit more cheese, though.
The wait staff is nice and smart enough to split your salad before they bring it out.
Overall, cute place with good pizza.
author: dina s.

description:
Love this place!  Just a block down from the W hotel, perfect walking distance on a chilly summer night.  Waitresses and staff are very friendly.  We were seated on a Sat night, full house with no reservations within 10 minutes.  The pizza here was so good we ordered out 2 nights later!

Dine in:  Pizza Diavola appetizer, entrees:  Pennette Ai Funghi (very tasty cream sauce), and Rigatoni  Con Salsiccia.   

Take out 2 days later:  Proscuitto and Arugula pizza (OMG so good).  

Pasta is al dente and the best thin crust pizza I remember having in a long time.
author: Tina W.

description:
So my friend recently had a really good experience here...this time, not so fabulous...our server was very nice and we asked suggestions...I was in the mood for big pasta...thinking ravioli...but I was floundering between ravioli and lasagna...she suggested lasagna...yeah, I think I should have gotten the ravioli. The lasagna is all bechamel, not a lot of noodle or innards...big fail for me. I'm looking for nice cheese, tomato, meat and noodles.  My friends ordered the salmon risotto (risotto and salmon cooked nicely, but under seasoned)....and the funghi & sausage pizza (toppings were okay but it was uber soggy)...I need a good thin CRISPY crust to make it in my book!
