Two of us are girls from Jersey need a really good Italian experience, and sadly, Pazzia didn't measure up to what we were hoping for. Really wanted to like this place after all the good reviews, but sadly, have to give this place a 3 star.
author: Steen H.

description:
A great neighborhood find! 

We just moved into the area and had passed Pazzia multiple times and always wondering how the food was, as it was always packed with people. We finally went last night with another couple and were so pleasantly surprised! 

The Ambiance: Warm, cozy, quaint. Nothing fancy but a great casual feel
The Food: Fantastic. We got the Burrata and Bruschetta to start. Great bread (i'm not sure if it was made on premises or not, but soft and crunchy); We then shared the sausage/mushroom pizza - the pizza was very good - great flavors, nice thin crust.  For main entrees - we all got some pasta dish. All were fresh, flavorful and exactly what you were hoping for. 
The Staff: Friendly and accomodating. They had made an extra dessert and brought it over to us on the house...

A great neighborhood restaurant when you're craving good food in a casual dining experience.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
I was surprised at how busy this restaurant was at 9 PM, so I assumed it must be awesome food. The servers seemed overworked, but they accomodated our group (5 of us) relatively quickly. However, after seating us outside, we were visited a total of three times - to drop off menus and order food, to drop off the food, and to pick up the plates and bring the check. We never had our waters refreshed, nor did she check back to make sure we enjoyed our food.

We shared a bottle of white wine, and when my friend - who grew up on a winery - asked the server for a recommendation "something dry, more acidic than buttery" the server looked at us blankly. Whatever - the wine we had was mediocre and overpriced, and it was one of the cheaper bottles on the menu. I was the only one of my friends who didn't order pizza, but instead had a special of taglierini: spinach pasta salmon, pancetta, and olives. When served I was offered fresh pepper, which I accepted, but after tasting, I wish she had also offered salt. The pasta was completely flavorless, so I pushed it around while I ate the salm and pancetta and olives. There was no salt on the table but no server to be seen to ask for said salt.

My friends said the pizza was pretty tasty, and I had one of the leftover pieces for breakfast - just as good as any other pizza.
author: Calli C.

description: Ordered the Pomodoro pasta- spaghetti with tomato and basil to go and came home with some seafood pasta! Bummer! Someone's not doing his/her job right.
author: Jen F.

description:
I must say I have to first thank all of the Yelpers.  We were visiting San Fran and had just arrived at our hotel very hungry.  I logged onto Yelp for the nearest restaurant that was at least 4 stars, and alas, this was four blocks from our hotel.
We sat outside to people watch and were surprised at how European the place felt.  The way they did everything reminded us of Europe.  The pizza was awesome.  It was almost as good as the pizza I've eaten in Italy.  Very similar style and very simple.  Just great.  You're missing out if you don't visit this place.  Don't expect Domino's, Pizza Hut, NY style, Chicago style.  It's not any of those.  It's Euro style without the BO.  Enjoy!
author: Jake L.

description:
I lived across the street for almost a year and I can't believe I've only been once. 

This place has great food. The pizza is simple but really fresh, tasty ingredients. The cheese alone made the pizza. The crust was thin and crispy. The pasta was pretty good too. They even dealt with my really high maintenance 6 and 8 year old brothers. 

The only bad thing I have to say is that I made a reservation and they lost it. So we ended up having to wait 15 minutes or so for a table and it was a little smaller than was comfortable. But, since they're expanding into the space next door, hopefully they won't have that problem anymore.
author: Kealie G.

description:
So, I went to this place AGAIN!  I do not know why I have repeat syndrome with some restaurants/dishes.  There are soo many great places to eat, but I keep going back to places I love.  Well,  LOVE justifies it, I think...  

Well another Friday night lasagna made my weekend.  Hats off!
author: Belina G.

description: Friendly but busy service, long long wait, quite pricey, not very tasty. Won't come again.
author: Leo V.

description:
I love me some Italian! And who knew this cute little place boasts some of the yummiest Italian food in SOMA?! I can't believe I used to live 2 blocks away from this trattoria and I'd never been here before today. I walked right past it nearly every day. We had a team lunch here, and it was lovely. The space is cozy, so I can see it being a nice spot for an intimate casual dinner date as well. 

Our group of six started with three salads to share: a caesar, caprese and medici (endives with pear). The medici was my fave. For my entree, I had the sausage and mushroom pasta. Instead of the rigatoni it came with, I asked them to substitute it with fettucini. It was a nice portion, and super tasty. One of us had the sausage and mushroom pizza, which was huge! It's certainly large enough for 2 or 3 people to share. For dessert, we had the tiramisu, affogato, and creme caramel (similar to flan). They were all delicious, but the affogato (vanilla ice cream in espresso) was my favorite. 

Good to know this place is in the Yelperhood.
author: Connie C.

description: Off the beaten path...local crowd. Fantastic food, service and atmosphere. Authentic Italian. Tried pizza, ravioli in meat sauce and lasagne...all three exceeded expectations. Small place, so make a reservation or be prepared to wait.
author: Marc K.

description: Authentic little Italian restaurant!  Love the baked lasagna in a sea of melted cheese!!  So rich, so creamy!  Look forward to coming back and trying other pasta dishes.
author: Michelle W.

description: My husband and I really enjoyed our dinner at Pazzia and the main reason was the exceptionally good service!  We had a main server, but what was great was that every server who passed our table took care to make sure water glasses were filled, etc.  Food was pretty darn good, but the service is really what did it for me!
author: Jenn P.

description:
I love the ambiance and the fact that their menu mentions (in fine print, at the bottom) that they have a partner location in Florence.  Authentic enough for you?

My boyfriend tells me that their pizza is among the best he's ever tasted.  Being somewhat lactose intolerant, I have no opinion on it, but the pasta wasn't anything to write home about.  Dessert was great, though!

On a Friday or Saturday night, be ready to wait a long time for a table unless you have reservations.  It's crowded as hell, too, and gets pretty noisy when the restaurant's packed.  The location is tiny, but last time I ate there, I noticed a sign about an upcoming expansion, so maybe they've solved that by now.
author: Sharon W.

description:
my favourite italian place in the city. 
Extensive menu of authentic dishes, pasta is always al dente, pizza is always perfectly baked. 
The ambiance of the place is robust, a little cramped and crowded, which I wouldn't usually enjoy, but it really adds to the 'italian' atmosphere. Wonderful waiters and waitresses. They're so friendly.
Even the bread here is good. 
Save room for the tiramisu!
author: Scarlet S.

description: Stumbled in here drunk after a Giants day game. Inventive pasta dishes, pizzas looked and smelled amazing. Decent prices. Friendly staff. Authentic Italian food. Great pasta with a mushroom medley in a cream sauce. Droooooool.
author: Shira O.

description:
One of my "go to" restaurants in SOMA. Walking distance from where I live, Pazzia serves unpretentious yet authentic Italian fare with a Florentine flavor. 

The place isn't that big and it can get quite crowded easily. The wall paintings of Florence, particularly the Ponte Veccio, really give the place character. This is slightly diminished by the owners penchant for trance music. Weird, I know.

The food is pretty good. The pastas and meats stand out and they don't suffer for San Francisco pricing. Pretty reasonable. 

All in all, this is a safe and easy place for me to go whenever I have a craving for Italian food in SF.
author: Joey C.

description: Good rustic italian.  Everything on the menu is warm and filling.  Service is wonderful.  great for lunch or an early dinner.
author: C W.

description:
still in search of the best pizza-locally...

called late labor day monday night to see if this place was open and i get "buonasera"...ahh...flashbacks....SOLD!

so during the walk there, i heard zero zero was nearby...so i thought it was worth it to walk the extra block.  FAIL!  i was pazzia to do such-shoulda went w/ the first pick- zero was closed that night so me & il mio ragazzo trekked back to pazzia.

the place from the outside looked like sbarro...so i was a bit discouraged.  ordered the pomodoro salad (tomatoes w/ basil in balsamic vinegar and olive oil), bruschetta (coz i swear bd got a thing for that...everytime bruschetta!), a Prosciutto e Arugola, a Diavola pie (spicy italian sausage) & tiramisu to share.

everything delizioso! they had the pizza i was looking for. i wanted to save half coz i wanted to experience the pizza for the next day...say lunchtime. CEPT-i forgot it!  im seriously bummed i dont have my leftover half for lunch today.  figlio di puttana!

grazie mille pazzia...i will return to taste every pizza on the menu!
author: Lady K.

description:
I got hit here.

No, not hit ON, but actually HIT!
By a homeless man.
He was walking by and decided to hit me and another girl who was on the sidewalk in the head, for no reason.  If not for the fact that he was about 6'3" and obviously not quite together in the head, I might have gone ballistic, but his size and the crazy ramblings made me stand there in stupor.  Of course, Rob took off after the guy and half the restaurant came out to witness the fiasco that ensued, but hey - this is what memories are made of, right?

In spite of the abuse I endured in front of Pazzia, I have to say that this is one fine Italian restaurant.  They have excellent food!

The pastas were good, though one dish I had was rather bland.  The appetizers were tasty.

But THE MOST IMPRESSIVE item was the pizza.

I often say that I don't like pizza.
The truth is that I love excellent pizza, but anything short of that, I can hardly eat.  It's a waste of square footage in the stomach.

Pazzia's pizza is fantastic.  It has the best crust, red sauce, cheese, and sausage.  Wow, the sausage on the Diavola is fantastic  The simple Margherita Pizza - outstanding.  Outside Italy, this is the finest pizza I have tasted to date.

Service was truly nice.  It was nice before I got hit in front of the restaurant, and it was even nicer afterward - making it almost worthwhile enduring the little bruise on my head.  Every server was very friendly and accommodating, and the lady (owner?) was very gracious offering us dessert on the house as well as a glass each of absinthe.  About absinthe - while it was truly appreciated, I have to say that was THE hardest concoction to down, EVER.  It went down like cognac with Listerine and Licorice.... 

I will go back to Pazzia, but next time, I am ordering 2 Pizzas, just for me!
author: Grace K.

description:
I ended up here recently after a failed attempt at La Briciola, which was unexpectedly closed. Overall, I liked it. The small restaurant has a fun, intimate feeling, and it manages not to be too loud despite being rather packed. The service was surprisingly slow for such a small place, but acceptable. They were, however, very kind about letting us wait for a friend who got lost on the way there!

Now, for the food. They didn't have any exciting vegetarian options on the menu. (Angel hair spaghetti with some vegetables? I can make that at home.) However, they had no problem at all with me requesting ravioli with pomodoro instead of meat sauce. Very good sign - some places can be so firm about their specials; Pazzia was very flexible and accomodating. My ravioli were delicious. My salad was so smothered in dressing as to be nigh inedible. The pizza was also very good. It's not a truly thin-crusted Napoletano pizza, but it's not as thick-crusted as a standard American pizza, either. The appetizer bread was terrific.

Overall: Good food. Many choices for the omnivores. Not so many choices for the vegetarians, but their cheerful staff are able and willing to accomodate requests.
author: Amanda J.

description:
Meal: lunch
Atmosphere: sat outside. sunny and more sunny
Food: lobster ravioli stuffed with steak (deliciously but deliciously tiny portions- who the f eat like 8 pieces of ravioli) + spicy sausage pizza (normal portioned FINALLY, thin crispy and lots of yummy cheese)
Cost=$33 ish minus tip
Cost/portion/quality= 3 stars
author: Skye W.

description:
The food is SOOO GOOD!

Pizzas are so delicious.  They have a great wine selection and they have homemade pastas!  The portions are nice and the food tastes very authentic.

The waitresses are really nice and I always see the owner in there helping!

Definitely a place to try!!
author: Ava L.

description:
Came here again for lunch today and definitely wanted to update the review and share the love for the Diavola pizza. This was my first pizza adventure here and it was great! Super thin crust with a nice amount of crispiness and the minimal sauce and cheese laid the perfect foundation for the spicy sausage to parade and shine on.

Also gave the Cesar salad a go and it was really light and a little on the bitter side, but then the cheese had a bit of sweetness to it that really made for a dynamite combination. A pizza and salad to share is the perfect amount for a lunch here, so enjoy!
author: Stephy S.

description:
Really small place, so either 1) make a reservation 2) get there early or 3) expect to wait.
Excellent service and really good food.  We had a bottle of wine, pizza, & a pasta dish.  The pizza was thin crusted and perfectly cooked....easy to split as an appetizer for 2 or as a main course for 1.  I  was in the mood for a specific pasta, which I didn't see on the menu so I asked the server if I could request it.  She said "no problem" and helped me put together what I was looking for.  It was EXACTLY what I wanted and tasted really, really good.  They even split it for us, which made it easier to eat.  Very tasty food and great service!
author: Autumn C.

description:
To those who say it's the best thin-crust pizza ever, I chuckle condescendingly.  

The special of the day was pepperoni.  Ours was underdone, too much cheese, bland sauce, generally undistinguished.  

For excellent thin crust, try La Madia in Chicago.

Pazzia's angel hair pasta was quite good.
author: Jedd J.

description: Food was very tasty. Salad and pasta terrific. Thin crust pizzas. Make sure to make reservations well in advance. When we called and left a message, they did not call back. For the most part they don't accept walk ins. We begged because they did not return our call. Success! Conveniently located near the Moscone Center.
author: Nancy D.

description: Wow this was great! Handmade pasta, homemade fresh bread. Yum. My daughter got the lasagna--not your average lasagna. The sauce was more of a creamy tomato and a little smoky. The best I've ever tasted. My son had mushroom tortelloni--another winner. I got spinach pasta with salmon, pancetta and kalamata olives. It was perfect. Tiny place, very friendly staff. Loved everything about it.
author: Sue M.

description: There are not many good pizza places in the area so it was nice to finally find a place that has decent pizza. I went in with low expectations and was pleasantly surprised. I will definitely come here more often.
author: Christopher Z.

description: Best italian pasta's I've had since living in Italy. I'm now a regular, eating lunch every 1-2 weeks. Great for team lunch, dates, or meeting friends. Tables outside with a chilled bottle of white = perfect.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I didn't think it was anything spectacular, just another italian restaurant. We ordered the mussels in tomato sauce, I've had fresher mussels and tomato sauce was ok. We also ordered the pizza, i like the crispy thin crust but again nothing special. 
Their free focaccia bread was yummy.
author: Lai T.

description:
Service was TERRIBLE. Perhaps they were just understaffed the night we went (a Saturday) but the wait staff was running around crazy. After getting our salads within a reasonable amount of time (Caesar was lackluster) we waited about 45 minutes for our entrees. 

After my dinner companion was served I waited another 15 minutes for my  entree and finally went up to the kitchen to find out what was happening with mine. Server charged us for three glasses of wine when we had only ordered 2. Wouldn't go back.
author: Joel K.

description: Fun Place, Great food!!!!!!, Romantic atmosphere light candles and I am happy When I can impress my dates talking to the waiters and Massimo (the owner) in Italian....
author: Daniela L.

description: Very solid pizza and pasta place. Pizza was a little greasy for my taste, but all the pastas were quite flavorful. Staff was attentive. This place offers family size entrees which was helpful for our large group of 10. Nice Italian restaurant that is cozy and small. It gets a bit noisy in here, so probably not the best place for a romantical date, but good for dinner with a small group of friends.
author: Caroline L.

description: If you didn't look out the window to San Francisco's 3rd Street, you could easily be in an upscale cucina tipica in any Tuscan city. (Except that the service was faster and and even friendlier than the Italian standard, which is already high.) The food was excellent and authentic - simple, fresh, tasty ingredients prepared perfectly without fussiness.
author: Nils D.

description: Very good thin crust pizza. Pasta dishes are good too. Fair price on the wine. Staff is also extremely friendly. Highly recommend this place for casual dining. It's also quiet for you to carry a conversation. If you're in SoMA, consider these locations too: http://bit.ly/pBRjIh
author: Captain G.

description:
I headed here today with some fellow yelpers for a quick lunch break. The pizza was very good, but I was deceived by thinking that it was thin crust.  It is, indeed, wonderfully thin crust but this is still something that I'd choose to split with someone in the future!

Luckily, my dining companion has a bigger appetite than I did, so kindly assisted me in finishing off my Pizza Margherita. Thanks goodness I wasn't eating alone!  Service was fine, quick and pretty attentive. 

This isn't necessarily a spot I'd seek out to return (with so many great places to eat in SF), but was nicely located for a quick (and filling) lunch.
author: mariah c.

description:
oh deliciousness! 

Pazzia is a hidden gem in SOMA and it doesn't look like anything special from the outside. We stumbled upon this restaurant on our way to the MOMA and was very happy that we found it. 

It is authentic, tasty and a good price for the really yummy food. I love the hustle and bustle of the place. There's a good wine selection. The minestrone is very good and so are all the different salads. The pasta are all house-made and I have not ever had a bad dish. 

Def a place to check out if you haven't been!
author: Gladys C.

description: Visiting from Phoenix found this place by accident while walking up 3rd St. After Giants/Nat's playoff game. Massimo set up table outside for me, wife and friend. Outstanding service, awesome pizza. Had a great time, highly recommend and will visit again
author: B M.

description: When i first moved to SF I lived round the corner for a while so this was really convenient. I now live miles away and still come back for really good authentic Italian food. Great pizzas and pasta even for fussy vegetarian. The service is personal and extremely friendly. Good wine too which is always a bonus :)
author: Rian L.

description:
I was here 2x in 2 months.  That is a lot when there are so many options to choose from.  A couple of reasons: its really good & its never a crazy long wait - I don't always have a week to plan out my reservations for pizza.

We have gotten salads, pizzas, and pastas.  All have been delicious.  Especially the sausage pizza, it is divine.
The service is quick and attentive.  You can usually find parking on the street nearby.
author: Kerry F.

description: Awesome restaurant! Pizza and steak are great. I take so many people here and they all love it.
author: Ryan L.

description: Loved our dinner.  The service was attentive and charming.  The Caesar was excellent and the lasagna and Papparadelle  With their homemade pastas were incredible.  We will be back.
author: KC P.

description: Pazzia is absolutely the best!  Go there every time I'm in the city because it feels like Italy with my family.  The staff, the owner, the food...  ...feels like a big family dinner.  Last trip my husband was on a diet because he was training for a triathlon and they were kind enough to make a dish that wasn't even on the menu.  Amazing!  Love 'em!  Fresh, homemade pasta...Yum!  In a city full of great food, Pazzia is a great local spot you shouldn't miss.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
So I've lived right by this place for over a year and just recently ventured over there... I'm planning on moving next month and thought it would be a good opportunity to have one of those ironic moments of finding a great place right before you move away from it.... yeah..

Anyhow, it was pretty good. Not the best Italian I've had but worth trying.

Tomaso is the best in SF by far still.. but like I said, this is pretty good.

Salad was bland.
Pizza was pretty good, a bit oily but good.
Ravioli was darned good. I'd have loved it if I hadn't had better at Tomaso.

A good note was that there was not such a long wait as my other Italian places.

On a bad note.. it's super small.. so that one really loud chick that laughs like a rabid horse... yeah she affects the whole room..  Don't ask me what a rabid horse laughs like... but I imagine it would be loud and annoying.
author: Amber F.

description: We went here for dinner one night last weekend. I had risotto with prawns and scallops. They were good but I guess I wasn't too hungry because I didn't finish my dish. It's more of a casual place and decent for groups.
author: K T.

description:
I went into this really wanting this place to be a 5 star joint for me. Most everyone seems to love it, and I was hoping to find a nice little place with some good, basic, true Italian pizza and pasta. 

Well now for reality. 

To start on a positive I loved the proprietor. He is a wonderful host in true Italian fashion. 3 of our party of six came in 45 minutes early, and he was happy to seat us with a flourish of hand gestures in a full house so we could have some wine to start. He could have easily seated someone else first to try to maximize his space. 

Sigh... the pizza. Wonderful flavors, excellent crust ;except the center third of the pizza was soft and soggy and could not hold itself or the topping. Again, the flavours were there, just not the structure. I don't expect a steel plate, but half the slice not even making it off the serving pan? 

Double sigh.. the pasta. I also ordered the Puttanesca. Olives, capers, spice, and a hint of anchovy. Did I say a hint of anchovy? As in you can't quite place that flavour that completes the dish, but would know it if someone said anchovy? I received anchovy pasta. Unacceptable. 

Am I being picky? I don't know; I have a long ass Italian last name that no one can pronounce so maybe I am. Bad day at Pazzia? Maybe. But I do know that the owner/proprietor needs to quality control his flavors and food a bit. Get everything back to where I am sure it started and is meant to be. 

I will be back. I really liked the hospitality and the feel of the place. I really hope next time the food is at the level of the service and atmosphere.
author: Rico T.

description: Overpriced, bland, weird atmosphere/layout. This place tries to be a full on restaurant and prices itself like it's nice when it's more akin to a diner and should probably keep it real.
author: Michael K.

description:
I work on the same block but for some reason just went to Pazzia for the first time.  Whenever I walk by, the place is packed so finally made my way in for lunch.  We decided to sit on the sidewalk cafe to enjoy the beautiful weather.   The seats were uncomfortable and I felt cramped in the corner.  The inside of the restaurant is a bit awkward too; it is one 'blank' room that has an off feeling.  

I must admit that the food was really good though.  I had a yummy risotto with super fresh seafood and it was cooked perfectly.  The menu was so long though.  Long menus make me nervous and confused sometimes.

All in all, I usually go to eat for the entire experience.  If i was rating the food only, I would have given 4 stars.
author: Philip D.

description:
in the past a favorite place, but as they have gotten popular the owner is no longer cooking and the food has declined.  
the noise level is impossible, so methinks best to find another favorite. Sent my dinner back twice tonight..had ravioli swimming in sauce that had been pan fried and burned.  quite a mistake
author: ira l.

description:
3.8 stars.  Not quite to the 4 star range, but overall I have no problem recommending this restaurant if you're in the area. 

Conversation can be a little challenging because the ambient noise is high for so small a venue.

The best service in the place...was ironically the bus boy who was ultra prompt on dishes and water.  I certainly can't say the same about the indifferent welcome, and seating, or the very busy waitress.
On the plus sides of the review, we have easy access parking, a pleasant decor, and an ambitious menu.  On the negative sides, the dinner was unremarkable, though tasty, but in a food-oriented city like San Francisco, you really do have to stretch for the exceptional to keep us culinary butterflies from flitting to the next attractive epicurean flower.

Always trust the Italians with lemons; nobody does them better, and Pazzia's lemon marscarpone sponge cake with a white chocolate frosting was worth the drive down there, regardless of dinner.

Overall, I would go there without reservation if I were in the neighborhood, but I'm not giving anything other than the dessert the rave review.
author: Theresa B.

description:
The paramour lives a block away from this joint. I've gained 25 pounds.
Coincidence? I think not.

For sublime carby, gustatory goodness Pazzia delivers in spades. Lasagna cravings seize me on the regular but nothing delivers like the gooey bechamel moat surrounding the castle of noodley satisfaction. Pay special attention to the xeroxed specials. We've been especially delighted with the spinach tortelloni in porcini cream sauce. For the win, for real. I'm also a fan of the Medici salad: pear or apple, gorgonzola, arugula and endive tossed in balsamic. Mwah! 

And the ambiance? Well, romantic might be a stretch as it's little seams are bursting with a boisterous after-work crowd. But its classy, and certainly tasty enough to impress.
author: Ligaya T.

description: Welcome to Italy!! There is absolutely nothing on the menue that isn't authentic. I really enjoy the food here and do not go often enough. The restaurant is not chic, but down to earth and has an outside seating area. I tried tons of Italian restaurants in SF, but most are simply too americanized and lack quality. Really love this place!
author: Angela R.

description:
Wow!  They really know how to do pizza here.  I had heard good things about the pizza here.  And with the Elite event around the corner at Supperclub, what better time to try it out before the event.  Judging from the conversations heard about dinner at Supperclub and elsewhere, I'm glad I picked Pazzia.  I got a group of Yelpers together to join me and my friend enjoy a taste of Italy.  I called up to make a reservation and spoke with Daniella.  I told her that I was looking to get a table for 10 for Wed nite.  She said she'd have Massimo, the owner, get back to me.  And sure enough, Massimo was very accommodating.  But I could hear it in his voice...he seemed a little hesitant.  Having never been to Pazzia before, I'd never seen the size of the restaurant.  When I got there, I could see why he cautioned that I limit the party size.  The dining area is about 20x20 (and as someone had mentioned, the kitchen is almost as big), so there really wasn't room for large parties.  The place was packed at 7:30...I really wondered whether we'd even get seated.  We waited about 10-15 min for them to get our table together.  I hated to tell them that we actually had 11 showing up instead of 10.  Massimo made sure that we'd all fit.  In the end, it all worked out.

Onto the food...I decided to come here because it was touted to have one of the best thin crust pizzas around in the City.  I had noticed the pizza ordered at another table, so I was ready to put them to my taste test.  I briefly looked at the menu.  Everything sounded good, but I was here for one thing...pizza.  I ordered a funghi e salsaccio pizza, and like everyone else at the table who ordered a pizza, we didn't think it'd be that big. When it came out, it reminded me of the pizzas that I had in Italy.  It almost brought tears to my eyes.  I wanted to dig in, but my friend reminded me to wait til everyone was served.  I told her that such a masterpiece can not be left to cool off...its meant to be eaten right out of the oven.  I tried to bribe my dining mates with a slice, just so that I could get started...they didn't fall for it.  When everyone was served, I savored the crispness of the crust and the fresh flavors of the mushroom and sausages.  It was not overdone with toppings, nor was it covered completely with cheese.  Everything was well proportioned.  This was Italian style pizza...unlike any East Coast or West Coast pies....just simple ingredients topped on a cracker-like crust with a perfect tomato sauce that had just the right amount of tangyness.  I've had A16's pizza and while they're comparable, I definitely prefer Pazzia's pizza.  My friend ordered the risotto, which came out looking wonderful, creamy, and full of seafood.  I tried a little and thought it was really good, but I was also busy concentrating on my pizza.  Luckily for me, my friend was trying to cut back on her meat consumption, so she didn't eat too much of mine.  Even with her helping me, I had to struggle to eat the last slice.  I only wish I had something to come home to...leftovers from Pazzia.

I had a peek into the kitchen , and was surprised to see such a small arrangement of appliances.   I expected to see an authentic brick oven in the back, but it just appeared to be one of those large pizza ovens, powered by gas/electric.  Maybe my eyes deceived me.  I know their stove was not one of those large commercial versions that a lot of restaurants use, but I was surprised how efficient they were with what they had.  

People in my party were a little surprised that their spirit selection was minimal.  I was hoping to sample a Peroni beer, but was left with only a Moretti beer to select from.  The Moretti wasn't a bad choice, as I recall having it in Firenze and enjoyed it just as much as I did back then.  Had I brought a wine connoisseur along, I'm sure the wine list would get critiqued, but I'm not that person.  I wasn't aware of the discrepancy in the bill, until someone mentioned it.  It was a little noisy in the small confines, but I seemed to look past it all, as we all seemed to have a great time.  I was appreciative to the staff and Massimo for making us feel at home.  And I was glad that my dining companions enjoyed the dinner and the conversations.

I'll definitely be coming back...albeit, in a smaller drove.  And for now...Pazzia will be kept at the top of my Italian style pizza heap in the Bay Area.
author: JeFF T.

description: The music was too loud, the food was not very good.  They get away with this because of the proximity to Moscone.
author: Mike R.

description:
Hell YEAH!

I'd like to thank the Fongster for suggesting Pazzia. :o)

Crunchy thin crust pizza delight. I love pizza and I most definitely love Pazzia's carb friendly pizza. But really, even if it was a bajillion calories I would still come back to this place and stuff my face with two pizzas because it's that good! Fong suggested Chianti, and although I'm not a big fan of red wine I trusted his decision. BIG mistake. Just kidding! No seriously - the waiter suggested a Nozzole risirva chianti, 2003 and it was superb! It had a buttery fruity taste to it. Quite lovely indeed! 

If you're a pizza whore get your arse here A to the S - A - P!

PS - our waiter had a sexy pendent on - yeowzaa! extra 1 star for that!


****** UPDATE
Music was way too loud and inappropriate for this time of restaurant.  I like Emo / alternative college music and all, but not at a restaurant! The music was more suited for a college coffee shop. LAME. Minus one star.
author: Aim E.

description:
This is the sort of Italian restaurant you wish you had in your neighborhood. Strangely, it's located in SoMA on a relatively non-local feeling block of Third Street. That said, I'm not complaining to have this as a lunch spot.

I stopped in for lunch today, and sat outside. My friend and I split a caprese salad and bruschetta, both simply but correctly prepared. They did both come out at the same time, but still, I can't knock good food.

The pastas sound like decent options but you have to at least try the pizza. It's thin crust, with fresh and abundant toppings, very Italian.

I'd recommend making reservations for lunch or dinner, since the restaurant isn't very large and there isn't really any waiting area.
author: Nish N.

description:
I have been going to this place for a long time! The pizza here is truly Italian just like how they make it back in their land. The Sicilian and anchovy pizza's are simply A-M-A-Z-I-N-G! The pastas too call for an applause :) 
Definitely stop here, next time you are around the area. You won't regret it!

Note: Its a small place and it gets extremely busy over the weekends+ nights. So make reservations before heading there!
author: sandhya ..

description: What a fabulous little treasure. The food is phenomenal, the staff are fun and welcoming and their desert is even good. I had the fresh bruschetta, white chocolate cake and the special meat fettuccini.  My son had the cheesiest lasagna I've ever seen baked to perfection. All I've had here is fabulous. The first time I've had  limoncello and discovered how strong it is. Their other location is in Italy. The staff gave us all hugs on our way out...what a festive hole in the wall
author: Mockalee M.

description: 3.5 stars. Overall a real good dinner was had here last night.  Don't love the space -- it's not real cozy, Italian like. However, for the most part the food was pretty tasty. I thought the burrata was average - I've had better.  The sauteed broccoli - I've had better.  But the home-made pasta is where they shined. The gnocchi and paparadelle were both almost like Grandma's. Nice portions.  And the sauce - I really liked the tomato sauce on the gnocchi - they made sauce how I like sauce. Oh, and the bread was great to sop up the sauce. Service was friendly - not overly attentive - just right.  Prices - fine.  I'd go back for the sauce and I want to check-out their pizza and cream sauce.
author: Carson R.

description:
awesome italian (neapolitan?) style pizzas here.  Avery G yet again chooses a winner.  The crusts are thin and "crackery" like they are supposed to be.  Well balanced sauce, toppings, etc.  I've gotten the prosciutto, artichoke, olives, and mushrooms (subbed with arugula, since I hate mushrooms) pizza, and I had a prosciutto pizza with additional anchovies before.  While the anchovies were a little too salty, the pizzas were still awesome.

Most recent time I came, we got a chianti classico risirvo, by Nozzole, 2003 by the waiter's recommendation.  It was gorgeous--well balanced, and jammy.  spicy, buttery, and fruity--perfect for pizzas.  Great service, great location, great food.  And of course, I was with Marie A and Luis M, so great company always makes a meal better ;)

My first choice for italian pizza in SF.  I hear that A16 is also good (also from Avery), but it's in the marina, and that's not my usual stomping ground.
author: Fong L.

description:
For the true Italian dining affect 
you sent me a hottie Sicilian waitress
I'd never reject

For the rumble in my tummy
you brought me gnocci with gorgonzola
so yummy

To clear my head of the workday clutter
you served me the house chardonnay
smooth as butter

An outdoor table with crisp white linen
A crunchy caesar, too
A little bread, with a lotta balsamic, don't forget the tiramisu 

I must admit, I've eaten more than I should.
But fat and happy never felt so good.
author: Madame X.

description: It's off the heezy Weezy...you can't top the pies in this joint.  Well, except for in NYC or old New Haven, but still.  Super fine crust, makes you wanna gobble it down...that 10" pie will be gone in no time.  Don't sleep on the focaccia sandwiches either.  One of my homies had a mortadella sandwich that almost made him cry.  The focaccia is not too thick and not too thin...  And the calzone's as big as your head, but light as a feather.  Add in the 'feel the love' service and you have the best kept secret anywhere near Yerba Buena Gardens.  Great for lunch, great for dinner.  Plus, they've been consistent for years.  You can find great pasta all over this town, but if you know of a better 'za, please send me a message
author: Ted R.

description:
Understated Italian.  Is that an oxymoron?  

One doesn't associate the country of Ferrari and Pavarotti with restraint, but the subtle taste of the lasagna my friend was enjoying really snuck up on me.  And the simple pizza with prosciutto and arugula was so restrained and perfect that it took me be surprise as well.  This is a very low key, even humble room.  The slinky hostess and sleek staff are perhaps the only over the top notes at Pazzia.

I won't lie, though.  That incredible tiramisu is vamping, big time--and it deserves to vamp.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Dude, this place is farking AMAZING. What can I say about Pazzia that is original? Probably nothing. So I'll go with the standard.

It is the most unassuming place ever. Somewhere on 3rd, with a cozy interior & outside seating, it is a place you would never expect to need reservations for. But both times I have gone, it would have been smart of us to do so. 

But whether you need to wait or you take a crap seat (think outside on a typical San Francisco night), it is oh so worth it. The pizza is fabulous, the pasta perfect. Even the dipping oil is nuttier than anything else I have tasted. I simply love this place and I have no idea how else I can say it.

Oh well. Simple sentiments for simply amazing food.
author: Alexis B.

description:
Why is it always that my favored little establishments have such a large, loyal clientele? STOP IT, these are MY businesses, stop taking up room at my dining table!

(breathe M, breathe) *obnoxious, hoarding episode passes*

Alright, I'll share Pazzia with the lot of you, seeing that my friend Dean was generous enough to share it with me.

Aside from the slightly hurried atmosphere I've gotten on occasion while dining, it gets pretty rustic in here. Our meals in Italy consisted of three-hour-long meals that gave plenty of time for digestion- here, they want to be able to seat the next set of foodmongers. The host is a gregarious character, scooting between servers, spending time at tables with O.G. Italians and greeting hungry patrons with his heavy accent. Actually, the whole restaurant staff aside from the bussers seems imbued with Italy, which I love, and the staff seems to have a good working relationship with the Host/Owner which shows in their attitude. It's a little on the louder side, and the tables are rather tightly packed, but it's not to the degree where you're part of your neighboring table's conversation.

The food is wonderful here- fresh, clean tasting and not Sicilian style (I'm allergic to garlic and onions but still love the Italian cuisine- leave me alone) like so many other places that are far too liberal with the  bulb. I believe the cuisine is closer to Florence, but at any rate it is more nothern style Italian, which means less garlic. The salads are lightly dressed and the daily special salads reflect the season's bounty. Their vegetable antipasti is not premade and cold like many other places do- it's warm off the grill, and lightly salted for accent.


They have many wonderful pasta, flatbread (thin crust pizza) and meat entrees- I've had too many different ones to begin describing them but suffice it to say, all of my meals here have been fantastic.  I believe they make their own bread too, which has always come to the table warm and fragrant.

One thing that made me REALLY HAPPY- delicous affogato (ascoop of rich, creamy vanilla ice cream floating in espresso). I prefer this over tiramisu any day. Ok I'll fess up. Their affogato always transports me back to Venice to a tiny, romantic pincushion of a restaurant right next to a canal where my boyfriend and I sat next to the window and made everyone else sick, but really, affogato is delicious and you should try it. I digress.

I want to take away half a star for making me smell like food, but the alternative to that would be them installing a hurricane-force exhaust system which would make the place drafty and whistly, so never mind.  I'll keep the food smell- it's worth every spritz of Febreeze to eat here!
author: Mortiche W.

description: This fairly small Italian restaurant has great ambiance, a seemingly all-Italian-from-Italy staff, and amazing food. This is our favorite restaurant to celebrate or just grab dinner after work. The waiters can all recommend great wine pairings. Some of my favorites are the margherita pizza, pepperoni pizza, burrata, gnocchi, and the amazing affogato. You should get a reservation as they can fill up quickly. They're expanding so hopefully it will be a little easier to get a table!
author: Katherine M.

description:
I was quite impressed with our dinner here last night.  When someone suggested we find an Italian place, I figured we should head to North Beach, but we were closer to soma, so we decided to try something new.  This is such a warm and vibrant little hole in the wall amidst a pretty empty/quiet street on a saturday night.  The staff was very nice, and though there were a fair number of tables (all completely full) packed into this little place, we didn't feel like we were on top of the other diners. 

All three of us ordered pasta, and we were all very happy with our orders.  I got a special tortelloni, stuffed with beef in a porcini cream sauce.  It was freshly made in spinach pasta dough, and it was absolutely delicious.  It tasted fresh, and was the perfect richness for my taste.  I also had a bite of my friend's spaghetti (normally I don't order marinara sauced pastas at restaurants, but it was really good, and clearly fresh/homemade).

I liked the open kitchen, but I wished I could've seen the action at the stove more.  oh well.  The food is worth the trek to soma for me, so I see myself coming back.  I was admiring the pizzas headed to the other tables, and perhaps I'll try an appetizer next time as well.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
I've been here several times for lunch and once for dinner.  This is probably my favorite Italian food in SOMA--great food, great service, and reasonable prices.  

I recommend the Pennette Puttanesca  (warning: salt lovers only), the Fusilli Alle Melanzane, or the Pennette Ai Funghi.  I have not tried the pizza, but it looks quite tasty too.  The wine selection is decent, but not exceptional.  The only fault I've experienced in their food so far is the minestrone soup--it is incredibly bland and watery.

It's a great place to go at lunchtime because it is relatively quiet/intimate, but it can get noisy and crowded during dinner hours (i.e. can be difficult to have a conversation).
author: Alison M.

description:
The day after first eating here, I bought a learn Italian CD set.  I did the math, and the correlation is strong (r = .89). 

In an area where I don't often do dinner,  I never would have found Pazzia and its seriously good food (especially the pizza) served by decidedly charming staff without Yelp and Maptastic.
author: L W.

description:
Where to begin...  I guess first of all, what kind of restaurant has the public restroom IN THE KITCHEN?  I am by no means a "germophobe" but there is something inherently wrong with that.  And pardon my vulgarity, but smelling someone else's bowel movement anywhere near the kitchen where my food is prepared is not my idea of sanitary.  

We should have left immediately after that experience.  I'll preface my review by saying we tried pazzia after countless friends had made recommendations and we had some lofty expectations.  Fair or not, pazzia met none of them. Even with reservations we waited nearly 30 minutes.  When we were finally seated, by a very rude older gentleman, we hoped our night might start getting better.  It was a special occasion and we were really trying to have a great night.  

No server appeared for another 15 minutes.  We sat, and waited more.  When the server finally showed up we asked her for a wine list which we didn't get until literally one minute before our meal arrived.  When our meal arrived, my date's pizza was cold.  By now, things had gone so badly it wasn't even worth sending back.  My date and I shared my plate, an over seasoned and over-cooked chicken and pasta dish that would have had potential on a typical night. 

Once it was time to pay, I asked for the pizza to be taken off our bill; my date hadn't touched it aside from the failed temperature check.  I wasn't able to ask earlier because we were in the corner, (closest to the toilet) and hadn't seen our server since she delivered our meal.  Predictably, she made a fuss and said she'd send over the "manager."

What a character this guy was.  "Massimo," like the cheap t-shirt,  was coincidentally the same "gentleman" who seated us.  Cocky and devoid of any empathy whatsoever he became very defensive and argumentative about our meal.  Again, it was untouched.  I even told him he could put it back in the microwave and re-serve it, since it was as cold as a frozen DiGiornio anyways.  This guy was horrible.  Worthy of deportation without question.  What kind of owner argues with a customer about their opinion regarding his business?!  Its laughable.  

We won't be going back anytime soon.  I have worked in restaurants before and always did everything I could for the customer.  Especially on special occasions.  I wasn't even the owner or manager and I hated when customers had poor experiences.  I realize cold food, poor service, etc is the nature of the business, but how can you not take advantage of an opportunity to turn a horrible experience into a great one?  A simple apology and a smile would have sufficed just fine.  An argument with a pompous arrogant shit was not how I wanted to end our evening!
author: Sean O.

description:
I adore Pazzia.  I've probably eaten here close to 20 times (including just now) and have tried a handful of different things, but the dishes that keep me coming back are the pizza diavola and the lasagna - they are both divine but if I had to choose one, I'd go with diavola.  

Pazzia's diavola is one of my three favorite pizzas in the Bay Area (the other two being Gialina and Zachary's), and although I change my mind frequently about which one's my *favorite* favorite, I always feel like the diavola is the winner when I'm eating it.
author: Melissa O.

description:
As a vegan, my Italian meals tend to be pasta with tomato sauce (no cheese) and the like.  I've had a lot of pasta in my day.  And all I can say is that my fusilli pomodoro at Pazzia tasted better than the vast majority of pasta dishes I've had.  I was full half way through my meal but I ate every bite because it was so delicious.

I'm not a fan of the mural on the wall.  The bathroom was out of order when we were there.  But the food... the food was so good!
author: Rachel R.

description: Yummy! Great little Italian restaurant. Great service. The margarita pizza was so good. We ate here while staying at The Westin market Hotel nearby. A local couple we met while walking around recommended this place. It doesn't look like much from the outside, but inside it was clean and a nice atmosphere.
author: Sheri B.

description:
Wine / Beer = 100 / 2 (only italian beers)

Pizza: Superb

Atmosphere: quiet and loverly. 
Prompt service

We got a solid pizza and split it between us kids before a movie. The italian-speaking waiters knew the correct pronunciation and kindly corrected me. 

Bread was completely undercooked (gummy and nasty) but the outside of it was alright. Perhaps just a bad batch. 

Reminded me of solid pizzas I've eaten in Bologna. 

Five stars if they could get the bread right. Though who am I to say? I've only had ONE PIZZA THERE. But it was nice...
author: daniel m.

description:
Great local italian. I highly recommend this SOMA neighborhood place.  The food is always consistent. Massimo, the owner, is probably pound for pound the most approachable and friendly host in the city.

He works the floor like his job depends on it. He says hello to everyone. He treats you like a vip. You come in a few times and he'll send over some prosecco gratis!

The waitresses are all off the boat from italy, beautiful and know service.

The place is not fancy and it is very small. Who cares.  Massimo creates a fantastic vibe, almost club-like -- come in a few times and you notice it.  They play great music too, which is always a pet peeve of mine.

The pizzetas, the carpaccio, the pollo arrosto, it's all prepared simply, elegantly and without any froufrou.

I love this place!
author: Luis O.

description: Made reservations for it because it is small and it was the day before the San Francisco marathon that I was running so most restaurants were packed. I enjoy pizza as my pre-race meal! I'm not a thin crust person but they did it the best I've ever had and just the right amount of sauce. The bread they give you before is so soft and good and can dip it in olive oil. It was a friendly and open atmosphere.
author: Jessie B.

description:
After a walk through the SFMOMA on a Thursday night (as they're open late on Thursdays!), I found myself at Pazzia's, hungry, excited, hungry, antsy, hungry, my hands flying around with nervous energy I could not contain.

I was on a date with a boy.  And this boy was taking me to dinner.

I hadn't really given any thought to exactly how I would feel on this date until the moment we sat down and all of a sudden I felt like I had broken out into hives.  It's that odd "Oh Shit" factor that hits very late in the game.

The one that makes everything feel very real and palpable.

My palms were clammy and I'm sure my face was red. 

We ordered.  We talked.  Bread came.  I managed to dribble olive oil down my cleavage unintentionally.  I need to wear bib to dinner.  Like, all the time.

The fusilli was excellent though I couldn't finish.  The atmosphere was excellent.  The warm lighting, the tables full of excited diners, the friendly staff, all of this added to the experience, which I can imagine, is much more different during the day.

Said boy walked me to the bus stop and waited for the 21 with me.

Said boy handed me a mixtape he had made for me as the bus pulled up.

Said boy is the one I now affectionately call the dr.  and sometimes...monkey.
author: Jen I.

description:
You might think they were trying to spell "Pizza", but they aren't.  So I googled Pazzia, Italy and couldn't find the name of a city.  Can someone enlighten me on the meaning?  Perhaps a surname?

Came here for lunch with my manager, very nice of her to take me out on my last day.  Company and conversation were excellent.  The food was pretty good; I especially liked the eggplant pasta dish.  However, even though lots of people had ordered the pizza, it didn't hit the spot for me.  I guess I'm used to more dry pizza haha.

If I am in the area, I'd go back to try out some of their other dishes as the people there were friendly.

On a side note, we also got a mild scare when a guy decided to pull a donut with screeching tires in his BMW after going down the street the wrong way.  The things people do--crazy!
author: Christopher W.

description: This is the first Yelp review I've ever written but feel compelled to tell others about Pazzia.  This restaurant has perhaps the best Italian food I've had outside of Italy. We started wth the beet and arugula salad and it tasted like the arugula was just picked. The highlight, however, was the ravioli from the special sheet.  It was a homemade pasta filled with spinach and ricotta in a pink sauce along with baby artichokes.  We shared the pasta and, in the end, wished we had just each ordered our own.  We had a glass of a Chianti recommended by the staff and it was a perfect pairing.  For dessert we had some of the lightest, most delicious Tiramisu.  At the end of the meal we felt like we had a mini trip to Italy.  We will be sure to visit Pazzia every time we come to San Francisco. Our only regret is that we didn't find this restaurant sooner.
author: Lisee M.

description:
Not bad food at ridiculous prices given the quality. Pizza is pretty good, despite being sloppy and soggy, other stuff is pretty eh. $15 for a plate of unseasoned veggies with grill marks. Similar prices for bland pasta that I could make at home blindfolded.

Definitely nice service, and cute enough, but the bar has been raised for Italian in the Bay Area in the last ten years. I mean, what's with the pre-washed arugula tossed on stuff straight out of a bag? Compares favorably to Olive Garden, but doesn't compare well to any place that I'd call good.
author: YUP K.

description:
What the hell are the bad reviews about!?!?!? We went here last night for some wine and thin crust and I was surprised to find a charming, low-lit, smallish neighborhood Italian joint. The seating is a little claustrophobic but  the service is great - not too attentive but always there at just the right time. 

As far as the food goes, you get a whole lot for relatively little. This is probably the most reasonable restaurant in my hood. The thin-crust pizza with prosciutto and olives appeared to be well-enjoyed and smelled delish (I'm on a diet and therefore not allowed to indulge). My salad was so big, I brought most of it home to eat for breakfast. Our server recommended a delicious chianti/merlot blend that was spicy and yummy and blush-inducing for around $30. $30 a bottle!?!? That's a hard find in the Yerba Buena part of SOMA. 

Everything on the menu looked delicious, the smells coming from the kitchen were extremely seductive, and the wine list is great for a small Italian joint. There's a front patio and I think I saw a heat lamp...

I will soooooo be back. I hear it can get busy later in the week, but when we were there at 9 on a Tuesday, it was very quiet. This is definitely the most neighborhood-like spot in the neighborhood and I can't wait to go back.
author: Autumn K.

description:
My friend from Italy recommended this restaurant and I am so glad that I asked her about pizza here. 
Excellent thin crust, almost cracker-like. I absolutely agree with the other yelp review. My favorite Margherita pizza in San Francisco. When I first saw this pizza, it didn't look impressive but I was in love when I tasted it. The cheese and sauce are very flavorful. When you order a simple pizza like this, you can really focus on the flavors. 

For eggplant lovers, try the Fusilli with eggplant and mozzarella. The chunks of eggplant are not too soft and not too hard. And I love the seared in taste of olive oil.
author: Eve L.

description:
This is one of my happy places, if I don't make it here for dinner at least twice a month something is seriously not right with the world.

Someday I may even venture out to a different portion of the menu, but so far, despite my best "tonight I'm going to try something different" intentions I always end up ordering pizza, it's just that good.

And of course, the fact that everyone who works at this place is hot doesn't hurt either.
author: Renae H.

description:
Yummy thin crust pizza, the variety that I hear is "authentic", though I wouldn't really know, not being an Italian food aficionado, and never having been to Italy.  The anchovies on the anchovy pizza were stronger than I recall from other anchovy pizzas (like Gioia's in Berkeley)- I think they drizzled some of the anchovy oil on there too - whoo!  Sal-tay.  But still good.

This place is small and seems to fill up during lunch, so get there a little early to ensure a seat.

I can't vouch for the pasta dishes, but the Caesar salad was okay, not wonderful, but okay (I'm obsessed with Caesar salad, so I might be overly picky).  At least it wasn't that tasteless, overly mayonnaisey kind of Caesar salad you get at more white bread establishments.
author: Chalk A.

description: Really not impressed.  Pizza was ok, salmon was a little charred.  Everything was definitely fresh and the service was great, but it was too expensive for what we got.
author: Tasha D.

description: Great margherita pizza. You'll hear a lot of Italian spoken here by waiters and customers, so it's a good sign it's pretty authentic.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
Great neighborhood Italian spot.  Been coming here for over two years.  Love the fact that Massimo, the owner, is there almost every night greeting and chatting with the guests.  Hopefully the restaurant will expand next door soon.

The crowd is an interesting mix of locals, after work crowd and tourists at times (there's 3 hotels within 4 blocks).

We get the same dishes every  time:
1)  Insalata Medici - Love the apples and gorgonzola
2) Fusilli Alle Melanzane
3) Rigatoni Con Salsiccia

Their thin crust pizzas with the slightly burnt edges are also delicious.

Wines aren't great but decent. 

Definitely recommend this place for a solid, consistent Italian meal.
author: Joy G.

description:
If you want legit Italian food, go to Pazzia.  The owner, Massimo, also owns a restaurant in Florence, which really sums it up. 

For first timers I highly recommend ordering the pizza margherita and a glass(or bottle!) of chianti.  You will then see why it is difficult to go anywhere else in the city for TRUE Italian.

The restaurant gets extra credit for the staff of native Italians.  

While the Euro is still strong, cancel your flight on Alitalia and go to Pazzia instead.
author: Alexis T.

description: Simply amazing, home style, authentic Italian restaurant. I go here quite a lot and I haven't tasted better Italian food in the city yet. Their Margarita pizza is amazing and their pastas are the to die for. try it out.
author: Andrew B.

description: Order the Margherita Pizza.  It was definitely the best of what WE ordered. The burrata salad (with prosciutto & arugula) was extremely tasty too, if you need an appetizer. We also had the bruschetta and the Capricciosa Pizza with prosciutto, olives, mushrooms, mozzarella and artichokes. Good, not great. Would not order them again. The crust gets a bit soggy on the pizzas, just a warning. But the flavor is excellent.
author: Emily Y.

description:
3 words!!

TRY THE LASAGNE!!!!!!

I was speechless afterwards, and now I'm on a mission to beat them at their own game.  In my kitchen, of course.
author: Yelper A.

description:
Great little neighborhood joint recommended by my local friend, with good food served in a casual setting (and a well-selected Italian wine list).

We started off with the Diavola pizza - while not as spicy as I expected it was still delicious, with a nice thin-but-not-too-crispy crust and tasty chunks of sausage.  For an entree, I had the lasagna at my friend's recommendation.  It was dense and rich with a nice crust on it from the oven - quite good.  Dessert was a light-and-fluffy tiramisu; nothing to write home about but good nonetheless.

The atmosphere is decidedly casual and friendly; the decor is sparse and non-intrusive.  The acoustics are good too - you don't have to shout to be heard by the person across the table, making this a good destination for hanging out and chatting.  They have a nice outdoor seating area for warm evenings.
author: Nathan C.

description:
After living in Italy, I struggled to find an authentic and good Italian restaurant.  Pazzia is pretty good.  The pizzas are thin crust, handmade pastas, and good wine selection.

My fave Italian restaurant in SF.
author: HY L.

description:
The service was good, the wine selection quite reasonable, and the food a-mazing. Especially the diavola pizza. I can't figure out how they made something that simple taste so wonderful.

It's a little pricey, but much tastier and FAR cheaper than the over-priced tourist traps in North Beach.
author: Ryan L.

description: 6/21/11: One of our favorite restaurants on our list, family friends and I headed here for late lunch on a Tuesday weekday. Still a gem with daily specials that are well thought out. We normally come for dinner and oftern had to wait for a table, this trip was during lunch and the restaurant was not bust at all which was a nice change.
author: Jesse W.

description:
wow... so ok... I made a HUGE mistake. I seriously had no clue this place was so affordable and I blame my stupid brain for instantly seeing white table cloths, wine glasses, and a line for a table and automatically associating that with outrageous prices... and passing it up for 8 MOTHS... STUPID STUPID STUPID.

Now that I am over my pity party, I really do walk by this place daily and it has always smelled amazingly delicious. My ex and I still live together (SHUT UP... story for another time) and he was CRAVING pizza like no other, and he wanted it sooner than later. I casually mentioned Pazzia just because i always see pizza and he wanted to see the menu, so we looked it up. IT'S SO AFFORDABLE!

So we both ordered a pizza and it was ready in less than 10 minutes, walked downstairs and picked it up and we ate HEAVENLY pizza. A-M-A-Z-I-N-G... and more. One pizza goes from $7 to $9... which is far less than CPK for a pizza that is slightly larger and much more authentic. Amicis is peeing themselves as we speak... for good reason. The pizza hit every spot of my body that I thought food wasn't allowed to. I was satisfied. Thank you Pazzia for making my dreams come true... but sadly 2 months before i leave this area... boo hiss.

My ex ordered the - Capricciosa $8.50 - mozzarella tomatoes, mushrooms, artichoke hearts, black olives and prosciutto

I ordered the - Alla Diavola $8.50 - mozzarella, tomatoes, spicy sausage

YUM YUM YUM
author: Preston B.

description: Excellent neighborhood Italian for a simple pizza or pasta that is classy without being pretentious.  Especially nice on a warm night when you can sit outside, but great for a small group (4 to 8 or so) sitting inside as well for a good fun dinner.
author: Mike G.

description:
When the waiter handed us a crookedly photocopied handwritten menu on binder paper, I was a little concerned. haha.  It was so weird!   We arrived around 11:30am on a Friday and it was empty...I think it just opened.  I don't have any complaints on the service since we were the only ones there :)

We had:

Caesar Salad- average
Caprese Salad- average
Chicken Stuffed w prosciutto, mozzarella, and mushroom- chicken was cooked perfectly.  Juicy and flavorful.  Came with a side of perfectly cooked broccoli and roasted potatoes (crispy on outside, soft on the inside).
Gnocchi w meat sauce- OMG.  The meat sauce on this dish is so fricken good.  I licked this plate clean.

I don't mind that the salads weren't that great, the entrees are what I care about.  Next time I go back, I'll try the pizza.

They also have a cute little area out front to eat.  When we drove by later that evening, the place was PACKED!  I definitely know why :)
author: Vivian W.

description:
I have no idea why fellow reviewers rated Pazzia an average of 4 stars. No way. My sister and I went here tonight (4/2/08) for dinner based on the good reviews. I'm sorry to say that after much good luck with Yelp in the past, it let me down this time. I can say that the restaurant was quaint -- small space, a bit warm, but not too squished. We were seated right away and ordered a salad to split (it had pear, blue cheese or gorgonzola, walnuts, arugula, and endive) and a sausage and mushroom pizza to split as well.

The service was prompt, and after a short time, we ate the salad. Nothing too memorable -- and it didn't really look as fresh as it could have been. Then came the pizza. What a disappointment. The mozzarella was globbed in the middle, and it overtook the whole pizza so that the t-to-d (toppings-to-dough) ratio was completely off. The tomato sauce tasted as if the chef opened a can called "Tomato Sauce" and poured it over the pizza. The pizza was incredibly bland. Not what I'm looking for in a pizza.

The redeeming factors:
- The ambiance. Not too loud. Not too soft.
- The service. Never an empty water glass. Never a long wait for the food or table.
- The company. I don't get to see my sister that often, so that part was a treat.

Otherwise, skip Pazzia and hit anywhere else in North Beach instead.
author: Wendy K.

description:
Authentic Italian Fare at Fair Prices.

So after visiting Pazzia several times---both during the week and on the weekend---I decided it was time to write a review. 

Overall, the place rocks. The food is wonderful---great penne with mushrooms and cream sauce. .. also love the penne with sausage in red sauce. The pizza is wonderful. . .nice thin crust and just the right amount of cheese and sauce---very rustic.

My only complaints are the noise level and the wine list. So, to get around that I go there before 7:30 and I bring my own wine. 

If you're looking for authentic, flavorful and well priced Italian food---then Pazzia is one place to visit. 

Okay, a little update. . .went to Pazzia on 2/9/07----you have to try the Roasted Chicken. It was amazing!! 

Buon Appetito!
author: David R.

description:
I've come full circle on Pazzia. It's been here a long time, I remember when it opened in the 80s because I worked down the street. And three years ago, I asked for something not on the menu - carbonara - and they made one the best renditions I'd ever tasted. Incredible attention to food. 

Last night, I went back with a number of friends and was pleased to see carbonara on the special menu, so I ordered it again. I got a disappointing pasta with bits of cooked egg, the one thing every recipe warns you will happen if you screw it up. I pointed this out to Massimo, the owner, who let me know this is the way it's supposed to be cooked. Bull!

I noticed that Natalia the waitress, while beautiful and charming took our orders and brought them to the table (I love a place that doesn't segregate waiters and runners) -- but she couldn't remember who had what. In the case of the salads, five minutes had gone by, but she had no clue.  

There is a mural over the kitchen depicting a man who may have been the previous owner, not sure, but he isn't around and the place looks the same but the quality is gone. They are feeding off the steady stream of convention chum that strolls over from the Moscone now. If you're from out of town, expensing your dinner and too busy talking to notice your food you might think it was a good place. If you live here and know Italian, you will likely think it's a tourist trap now.
author: jim b.

description:
I love Massimo. He started this small, authentic Italian restaurant 10+ years ago with two brothers from Florence. Everything's memorable but more than anything, I go because it tastes the way food in Italy restaurant tastes. Massimo will dote on you and your friends and, if you should wisely become a regular, this is better than knowing the head doorman of a hot club (or security of same club many hours/drinks later). I love their specials + they serve a proper cappuccino (WARNING: if you are an attractive woman and Gabriele is waiting on you, you may receive an "offer" written in the foam. From the milk). 

Great parking in SOMA, too.
author: Lola S.

description:
So I am NOT really a fan of Italian food. Ok, curse me all you want, but I've just never really been into the whole tomato sauce, olive, parmesan cheese thing. Never really cared for pizza and always preferred Asian noodles over Italian pasta. With that said, it's VERY hard to impress me when it comes to Italian food.

Pazzia is one of the first restaurants to ever make me love Italian food. It's a very small, very intimate restaurant that carries a very upscale charm. I loved the waitresses at Pazzia -- our waitress had a beautiful, intoxicating Italian accent that made everything she said sound so sexy... including "The bathroom is through the kitchen." Yeah baby, say that again.

I thought they served very, very delicious table bread. A perfectly-baked foccacia-type bread that was great with some olive oil and balsamic vinegar. I could have probably eaten that all night (and probably would have saved me some cash). I got the lasagna, which was really good -- the flavor was awesome. It was, however, pretty tiny -- didn't really fill me up that much (thank God for the table bread). The medici salad was okay, but nothing to write home about. The bolognese fetteccini was really well-made -- nice pasta texture and hearty sauce.

For dessert we had the tiramisu (VERY delicious) and the affogado (vanilla gelato with a shot of espresso), which was also really good.

All in all, even though I'm not a huge fan of Italian food, I would definitely recommend this place to anybody, and if, by some chance, I'm in the mood for some Italian, I know Pazzia is the place to go.
author: Roy C.

description:
this was a yelp find for me. Its in a little subdued location near the moscone center. 

Service was pretty great (I think there are 3-4 tables per server). A specials list that keeps changing regularly makes me go back to try out different tastes. 

I like the idea of open kitchens in the restaurant and this is no exception (this might be more due to the lack of space in the restaurant). 

The flatbread is soooo tasty!
author: Alexei S.

description: Great pizza and variety of toppings, good prices. We had a room in the back for a private party, and the food tasted great, service was also attentive! There's two long tables as well as plenty of space to walk around to fit a large group for the private room.
author: Teresa Y.

description: Love the pizza Neapolitana and the gnocchi. I seen a sign that they're extending, it's about time since the space is a lil cramped. Good Service and a good selection of italian wines.
author: Sofie Z.

description:
Great pasta--Vongole to be precise, but turtle slow service!!!

It's hard to believe that such slow lunchtime service could exist in the heart of the SoMa!  My girlfriend was almost late to her post-lunch meeting.  We spent over an hour at Pazzia...our order included: 2 ice waters, 1 iced tea, and 2 pastas...1.5 hours for that is unacceptable!

The place is truly run by Italians...our waiter didn't speak much English, so he couldn't fathom that I'd want iced tea and water...but he was kinda cute so we forgave him.

I will give it another shot when I'm not crunched for time.  

Also, do eat the bread.
author: debbie h.

description:
There's certainly fancier places for Italian food in the city, but when it comes to the sort of everyday Italian that I had the pleasure to eat while living in Europe, you really can't beat Pazzia.

From the moment you walk in, it feels like the sort of simple cafe you would find anywhere from Munich down to Firenze... and I've eaten at dozens of these places. Bruschetta, Pizza, Pasta and some simple  secondi (roasted stuffed chicken breasts, mussels in broth, scallopine, etc...) is the name of the game.

When you walk in, it's very simple - square tables in a mustard colored square room with only a Monet-esque mural of the Tuscan countryside. As you peek into the open kitchen, you see plates being assembled, pizzas coming out of the ovens and the telltale blue boxes of Barilla pasta.

What? Barilla pasta like in the supermarket?

It's a myth that most Italian restaurants make their own pasta. Even in Italy, most cafes and smaller family restaurants don't have the time, space or skill to be able to produce enough dry pasta to feed their customers, so they find a brand they like and use it and instead focus on the sauces, where the real skill is. 

No offense, but let's face it, dry pasta is water and wheat - it's easy to make a good dry pasta, but almost impossible to make a great dry pasta. Unless you're operating a restaurant known for making your own spaghetti and you're investing an extraordinary amount of cash to get the best pasta maker, equipment, water and flour, it's perfectly acceptable to use a higher grade commercial pasta (De Cecco and Barilla are most common).

I've had Pazzia's simple cuisine twice. The first time, I brought home pizzas, and the fennel sausage was amazing. This time, I went with a Calzone Romana - a perfect dough brushed with olive oil and filled with fresh mozzarella, mushrooms, prosciutto, eggs and parmasan cheese.

As calzones go, this is one of the hardest ones to make, because the mushrooms and mozzarella will both give off copious amounts of liquid, making it a watery mess that spills out of the calzone shell once opened and makes the bottom of the crust turn into mush. Through a thorough understanding of the dough, the filling materials and the temperature of the ovens, the calzone ended up perfect - with a moist filling, crisp shell and fantastic flavor... and guess what? I cut it open and not a drop of liquid spilled out of the calzone.

For me, this is the sort of comfortable, every day Italian food that I crave when I think back to Tuscany.
author: Avery G.

description:
No other pizza/Italian place in The States has made me want to use the phrase "Friggin'!" more than this place: as in Friggin' good pizza, friggin' authentic!

The stars here by far are the thin, crispy, individual wood-fired pizzas that come to your table unsliced... just like in Italy. Didn't have any pasta, but my date and I had a really good, fresh salad along with our prosciutto and mushroom pizza and bottle of Amarone that didn't break the bank.  Another clue to the authenticity is the fact that many of the staff are obviously from Italy... really. I trotted out my college level Italian to explain why I was late for my reservation and the matter was cleared up as if I were a long lost cousin.

One note, the environs are very humble and nondescript just like any small trattoria or pizzeria back in the old country that is focused on one thing: making good food. Don't expect a SOMA/Marina high-end, trendy experience, but if you have cherished memories of "real pizza" from trips abroad, or if you are just curious to try real Italian pizza, this is the spot for sure. Did I mention it's really reasonably priced? Score!
author: Brian S.

description:
I went here based on all the rave reviews I saw after my friend said that he walked by this place one evening and it was packed. Unfortunately, we were all pretty disappointed.

First off, when we arrived, our reservation wasn't on the list - the guy running the show (host, manager, etc.) was pretty rude in blaming things on us but after we showed him our call log on the cell phone he suddenly remembered who we were and apologized for forgetting to write down our reservation. He promptly seated us at an outdoor table so that we'd be comfortable as we waited and stated that dessert would be on the house.

We ordered two pizzas and a salad to share, as well as a bowl of minestrone soup. The waiter came up to us about 3 times during the 10 minutes we took decide what to order and seemed frustrated when we asked for more time each time. Moreover, he wasn't helpful at all when we asked for recommendations or more information about menu items.

We decided to overlook the waiter's attitude as after all we were there for the food. The bread basket was cold but the bread was very flavorful - there was no fresh cracked pepper in sight. When the soup arrived, they asked if we wanted Parmesan cheese and then proceeded to sprinkle the powder kind that tasted really fake - the soup itself wasn't very flavorful at all. Our pizzas arrived within minutes of the soup along with the salad and we suddenly found ourselves juggling things for space on our table.

The $9 salad was about one and a half cups of spinach in dressing and a bit of toppings...VERY meager for what you are paying. It looked much like a side salad. Then, the much awaited pizzas were just as disappointing. Granted, most of the crust was pretty thin though in parts it was up to a quarter inch of chewy dough. Then, the sauce, cheese and toppings were only in the center of the pizza with about a 2 inch rim of dough around each pizza. Mind you, these weren't very big pizzas so the majority of it was crust.

Everything just really felt rushed and thrown together. I could see where the pizzas had lots of potential if someone stopped and took an extra 2 minutes to spread the toppings out and make sure the pizza was spun out evenly. Also, I know spinach isn't that expensive so they could have served a bit more of it. I just felt like they didn't care about me and my food as long as they got me in and out FAST. Perhaps their food is better on weekdays but I'm not sure I'll be going back to give Pazzia another try. Oh and not that we wanted anything else but the promised 'free dessert' never happened.
author: Kat J.

description: Eh, it was just ok for me. Went here twice and though the service & ambiance are nice, the wine list & food are just ok.
author: Shal J.

description:
Always walk by this place on the way to Giants games and thought it looked so cute! After seeing some crowded evenings and some yelp opinions, decided to try some dinner after a movie at metreon. 

For me it was almost a blur, such fast service- too fast! Enjoying some great prosecco, then right away comes the antipasto. It was the veggie mix, not much too it, but quite good. The pizza was the standout, very authentic and delicious. However, one of the few pizzas that wasn't good cold (too thin I think).  Alas, next time i will have to just finish. 

I think we were out of there in 45 mins tops. A couple next to us was even quicker.  Maybe next time I will just grab a to go pizza and go over to ybg. Staff was very nice! Pizza very very nice!
