author: Cassie C.

description:
I picked the place off yelp to have dinner with a friend from the east bay, figuring I'd pick a place where parking would be easier than my neighborhood.

gulp. Walking  there, the location is less than appealing. Empty office space across the street, and little non-descript businesses on either side. So I was praying, yelp, please dont let me down. 

And yelp came through! The dishes we ordered were excellent, especially the tortellini with mushrooms and the penne puttanesca. So when you don't feel like putting up with the Italian places on Columbus, this is a good choice.
author: Jan Michael K.

description:
When ever I want an unpretentious authentic Italian meal in the city, this is the place to go.  Don't be put off by the lack of curb appeal.  This neighborhood restaurant has some of the best pizzas and pastas in the city.  
I love the thin crust margarita pizza and the melanzane pasta with smoked 
mazzarella cheese!
The place can be a bit crowded and probably not great for a quiet romantic dinner, but this is still one of my favorite neighborhood places.
author: Michael A.

description: This review is based on the Tiramisu. My boyfriend and I were craving Tiramisu, so we decided to stop by Pazzia. What an awesome experience! The tiramisu was delicious!!! We saw some interesting plates that people had ordered. Looked yummy! Smelled awesome! We met the owner and he is such a great guy! This place is growing and expanding! Can't wait for the lounge/bar area to open up. Definitely coming back! =)
author: Leah F.

description:
This little slice of heaven is amazing and it's where I'm sure to visit every time I'm in the bay area.  The food is always wonderful and I've never been less than delighted.

This last time I was there (a couple days ago) they looked at me funny when I let them know we didn't have reservations (oops, first time they'd even asked) and so we were curious as to whether we were being rushed, but I'll be more sure next time to plan ahead better.  Ah well, that's what I get for living in Austin where things like reservations don't exist I suppose...
author: justin l.

description: My buddy and I were heading to the East Bay when we needed a quick bite to eat. We called this place and got a pizza to go. Our order was ready to pick up in ten minutes and the pizza was really good and thin. They also have seating inside.
author: Darius A.

description:
I have only eaten the pizza here and only been once. 

It was tasty, with plenty of red sauce and the crust was crispy on the edges. I hate doughy crust on the outside. And there were plenty of ingredients, they didn't smother out the tomato sauce taste, which my taste buds look for during pizza time. The regular sized pizza is enough for 2, even if they are both piggy.
author: Heather O.

description: If I could give this place 10 stars, I would!!!! I went here last night for my 30th birthday dinner, and prior to that, I was told by the concierge at my hotel complete opposite directions to this place, and was an hour and a half late for my reserved table. It really sucked. And 3 of my friends were already there waiting for us, so instead of giving our table away, they offered for my friends to sit at the table and wait. I don't know many restaurants that would do this. They were busy, too, so they could have easily said, "I'm sorry, we really need these table for other guests," but they saved it for me!!! Seriously, top of the notch service right there, and I was very grateful! The whole experience from the beginning was impeccable, from my first call to make a reservation to the end of our evening after dining with them. Everyone was sooo extremely nice. They also gave me the best tiramisu with a candle in it at the end of our meals and sang happy birthday to me! OMG, their tiramisu was A-M-A-Z-I-N-G!!! I don't even care for tiramisu, but they changed my mind of that real quick! The food was excellent as well. I got two things, because I deserved it after the night I had! LOL I had their margherita pizza and a pasta dish with sundried tomatoes and arugula and some other things and it was a bit spicy! Both were divine! All of my friends enjoyed their entrees as well. No complaints, and I am extremely picky with food!! Tiny lil' place, cozy and cute. Mom/pop type place, and that's precisely what I wanted! They always have the BEST food!!! I am extremely happy I chose this place, and I will definitely be back, and on time!!! Thank you soooo much for saving my table and being such wonderful hosts! You made the rest of my birthday soooo much better!!! :)
author: Tara F.

description:
After getting hopelessly lost on foot (Thanks a lot Verizon GPS, I told you i'm a pedestrian..not a car..stop telling me to only go down one way streets!!!!!) I finally made it into the place and met some awesome yelpers.

Even though they took a little long giving us our reserved table (not really their fault, more of a fault of the party of dudes before us who wanted to just hang out with the wine...) we squeezed 11 of us onto a couple of tables.  The place is TINY.  As AJ pointed out, they coulda fit more tables into the kitchen space, and I observed they coulda fit one into the bathroom, but noone would eat there.

Did you know there was a coat rack in the back?  on the way to the bathroom? It's so cute and tiny.

I ordered the plain pizza that I don't know how to spell.  it looks like Margarita.  It smelled like Chuck E. Cheese pizza, and that's a good thing for me.

In hindsight I shoulda just split a pizza with someone else, as half of my pizza became Mina's lunch the next day.

Which means that you could totally eat here for about $7 (including drink and splitting a pizza). 

The service was pretty good, they were very considerate (even though they forgot Brenda's salad), and accomodating (the guy grabbed an extra chair quickly when he saw the shortage..none of this "you guys have too many people" crap i've seen some people pull).

If you're gonna go through the trouble of having a liquor liscense, I don't know why you don't have more than 1 type of beer and maybe some hards?

Oh well, either way, i highly recommend this place if you're in the area...and don't park all the way at the metreon like my n00b ass did.  There's a buncha places closer...
Yay to my first ever mini-yelp-event!
author: Candice D.

description:
In this episode, a couple of out of town bumpkins stumble upon a big city restaurante with no reservations...

In town for a week on business, we searched out Italian food and decided upon Pazzia with hopes on an above average meal.  We arrived around 7:30pm on a Saturday night and there was a crowd waiting but some were waiting for their carry out meals to take home.   I waited at the front door and upon revealing my lack of reservations was told by the host it would be a 30 minute wait. They had already moved several of their sidewalk tables inside to accommodate the crowd and moved another one in while we waited. We sat outside and enjoyed glasses of wine and people watched.

Being a non local, it appeared the majority of the clientle were local regulars but we were made to feel welcome throughout our meal.  While outside waiting, two of the wait staff checked with us and they along with our assigned waiter continued to check in on us throughout the meal.  It had a definite New York feel with the tables placed close together.  We both started with the Minestrone which was fresh and tasty although a little cool for my taste.  I enjoyed the Rigatoni con Salsiccia and my favorite dining partner had the chicken with potatoes which I happily sampled also..   

Conclusion - A satisfying and delicious meal, friendly and professional service, a place to brings friends, family and business associates.
author: Lester R.

description:
I tried the margherita pizza to go, since I really wasn't into the atmosphere of the dining room; a number of patrons wearing Moscone Center name tags; not that there's anything wrong with that, convention go-ers are people too...I just prefer to enjoy my dinners without 'synergistic, highly-aligned, circle back and touch-base' speak.
The pizza had the thin italian crust, but the sauce and cheese was sweaty.
I'm sticking with A16 or Tomasso's for my thin-crust cravings.
author: Jason N.

description:
Wanted to have dinner with friends in the area and they took us over to pazzia. I had never been and they said it was super good, so I was into it.  We made a reservation but my friends said the place is always packed, so your time is more of a guideline than when you will actually be seated.  This turned out to be true.  Luckily, they have some good wine options to drink while you wait (try the Cabernet Franc).

We had some prosciutto pizza, some lasagna, some prosciutto stuffed chicken, and risotto. All of them were great. And I didn't even get to try a pasta. 

Pretty happy with it and excited to go back another time.
author: Amit M.

description:
Stopped by on a Wednesday night at 8pm thinking we'd beat the dinner crowd but no there was a small crowd out the door. I was really disappointed that we had to wait 20-30 minutes for a table. The place is really really small and I was starving so we decided to order out. I could barely make my way through the tables to the counter to place my order. Yes it's THAT cramped. 

However, I'm still giving it 4 stars because of the exceptional service. The waiter guy was really nice to me and even gave me one of their menus to take home. Sure we had to wait another 25 minutes for out take out (why didn't we just wait for a table then?) but the food came out piping hot and was still hot the entire 4-5 blocks home.

I had the fusili w/ eggplant.  It was really good. I like the tomato sauce and at first I thought the portions were kind of small but after finishing the entire entree i was comatose. Hubby had the spicy sausage pizza. He thought it was just ok but I thought it was fantastic. Reminiscent of my favorite NY style pizza. The crust & pie was thin & soft. Not too much tomato sauce and the cheese was delicious.

I would definitely come back but I would recommend making reservations.
author: Terry D.

description:
Driving down 3rd Street on the way to the Frida Kahlo exhibit at the MOMA, we passed by Pazzia and I thought it would be a great place to take our friend for a birthday lunch after.  

I'd forgotten how simply delicious the food was here as I hadn't been in a couple of years.  The bresaola starter is one of my favorites ever.  It's thin slices of dry cured beef served with arugula and flavored with olive oil and lemon.  (By the way, you can buy bresaola at De Lucca's deli on Valencia at 22nd Street... bresaola, arugula, olive oil, lemon cracked black pepper and shaved parmesan and... BAM! you've just made a great starting dish).  

The spaghetti with clams (vongole) is perfection.  The pizzas are just the way Iike them, very thin crust and straight from the brick oven.  The service is always attentive and I enjoy watching the Italian owner/waiters gesticulating emphatically with their hands while they speak Italian.  Bravo, Pazzia!  Ritornaro ancora e piu pronto la prossima volta!
author: Ric S.

description:
By far, the most authentic Italian experience you will ever have away from North Beach.  Cozy, warm, open kitchen with real Italian staff , and one charming owner (Massimo) whose middle name should be "amore~" - no frills or attitudes, which I tire of at some of the "in" restaurants.  The thin crust pizza is paper thin and irrisistable in every bite in every style.  (Just be aware of how many slices you chomp through before realizing that it is still pizza, not garden salad on soy crackers.)  A lot of us never get past the pizzas on the menu because they're so tasty and light.

It's a great stop over to and from the baseball games (when in season) and also a perfect solution for a bite before heading over to the W or St. Regis for drinks.  Last of all, not that it really matters, but even our New York folks agree unanimously that it's great pizza.
author: Staci C.

description: Wonderful food and the server was very attentive.  The gnocchi was fabulous!  However, the noise level was VERY high.  The disco beat music did not help. The owner did quiet the music (very accommodating ) but that helped very little.
author: M H.

description:
Absolutely Amazing!
The chx with mushroom sauce, amazing!  Also try the beef tortellini!
When in mood for good solid authentic Italian, try this place.
author: Nat C.

description:
I work right around the corner from Pazzia, so I go there a lot, This place is amazing! 
Their food is to die for! My favorites are the Chicken marsala, Bruschetta, and the Pizza, the best Pizza I have ever had! 
Great service! The owner is very outgoing, very friendly!
author: Farzaneh Y.

description:
I was surprised to see a line outside at dinner time because it always seems empty when I walk by during the day. The staff is friendly and accommodating, and the food was excellent. My gf and I ordered the combo pizza (I forgot the Italian name, but it's prosciutto, mushrooms, olives, and artichokes), which had a nice thin crust and just the right amount of tomato sauce, as well as a pasta with meat ragu. The meat sauce tasted really homemade--chunks of sweet carrots, celery, and onion with a savory tomato sauce. Mmm mm!

I would have given 5 stars except that the seating was a bit crowded. I bumped elbows a few times with the table next to us, and my chair was nudged more than occasionally by the waitress.
author: Richard Z.

description: This is one of my favorite italian in the city. Everything is delicious and the tiramisu it to die for!! Authentic italian! Can't wait to go back.
author: Joyce M.

description:
I think the location leaves little to be desired.  Though there is outdoor seating, it's not interesting (very little to see excepts cars rushing off the freeway). 

The pizza was decent - tho not as good as Pizza Delfina.  It was thin crust, but not baked long enough (little flabby).  The pasta was good - tomato sauce was good.  but nothing spectacular.  

Surprisingly, the best executed dish was the daily vegetable-broccoli.  Done perfectly with just enough olive oil, garlic and red pepper.

Good Italian food, but that's not saying that much since SF Italian food is very mediocre.  Pizza is good, but can get better elsewhere.
author: Madison W.

description: This is some of the best thin-crust pizza that I've had outside of Italy. Try the one with mushrooms and sausage (= WOW). I could eat one for breakfast, they're so good. The pastas are great too - especially the rigatoni and the gnocchi. And to make the experience even better, this is a super cute hole in the wall with a lively vibe, welcoming Italian owner and friendly waitresses.
author: Emily A.

description: Decent Italian food served in a casual setting. The staff is mostly Italian which gives the place an authentic feel and a mom/pop atmosphere. The place was pretty busy on a Wednesday night, so I'd suggest getting a reservation.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
You know how I know an Italian place is good?  When the waitstaff and my fellow diners are speaking Italian.  If it's good enough for the natives, then it's certainly good enough for me.  This is a nice place for a weekday lunch, although a bit off the beaten path for tourists.  When we went it was nearly empty, and we were served by a charming Italian girl who had just started the job.  She made a few little errors, but apologized profusely each time.  Hey, we've all been new at some point!

I had the salmon-marscapone sandwich, which was fabulous!  It's like lox and bagels with an Italian twist.  Delicioso!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
So my husband and I came to Pazzia because he's been on a pizza kick since Michael Bauer started Pizza Fridays in the Chronicle. I have to say that we both liked the pizza a lot at Pazzia. 

But first, we got an appetizer that needed help. I think it was a tomato salad with anchovies. Here's the thing, if the tomatoes aren't good, say kinda white and mealy, how about you don't serve the dang thing and offer something else? No one's gonna enjoy a mealy tomato, no matter how much you dress it. 

So then on to the pizza. My husband got the Gorgonzola and I got the mushroom pizza. The crust was incredibly thin and crispy with the trademark bulbous, charred crusty edges that comes from a wood-fired oven. His Gorgonzola pizza had melted, obscene amounts of oozy, gooey, sinful goodness floating around and pooling in the center of his pie. Mine was sprinkled heavily with white mushrooms and paired with a nice tomato sauce. I would have liked however for the the variety of mushrooms to have been better on my pie. I think that may be a product of my being spoiled from living in Northern California.  But all in all, we liked Pazzia for the really tasty pizza. 

For the atmosphere, it was kinda family like. Clearly the owner dude knew people or had friends stopping in all the time. As far as the service, I've read some of the reviews already posted and I kinda agree that you shouldn't expect much when you come here. They clearly do not have a host/hostess/front of house manager and instead rely on the servers/owner. That could be their downfall, plus we kinda noticed that when we left, people were starting to get overlooked as far as getting seated goes. Word to the wise, get there early and you might get lucky and get the pizza for sure.
author: cora j.

description:
I may not love Pazzia as much as my friend Monica (if you go there enough, she's the curly haired one that resembles Shakira...) BUT I must say that I am very happy to have a place so close to my work that I can enjoy both lunch and fun dinners w/ way too much wine at.  

Monica swears by the pizza (she has a special one that they make just for her) and the rigatoni.  I personally heart the cream sauced porcini mushroom pasta, because it just simply rocks.

Bread is awesome, though I do wish they would serve it on a place so you could mix the balsamic vin and olive oil together for a more "blended" feel.

Wine list is great but the thing I think I love MOST about Pazzia is the great welcoming environment you get when you walk in.  The owner, Mossi, is always a gem along with his team of Italian servers and hostesses.  Although our favorite, Leti, recently returned to Italy - this place will definitely continue to be a favorite!
author: Jen L.

description:
Just returned from a nice lunch with a friend on their recommendation.  We sat out front and received prompt, genuinely friendly service.  We split the mussels in tomato sauce as an appetizer (cannot remember the name of the dish for the life of me) and a pizza with mozzarella, olives, artichoke hearts, prosciutto and mushrooms.

The mussels were good.  I don't think they were P.E.I. but they were perfectly acceptable, tasty and not overcooked.  The pizza was delicious as well.  It was a very thin crust and had ample toppings.  My preference would have been for just a hair thicker base crust without losing the 'thin crust' status but there was nothing bad about it.  The toppings were all fresh and high quality.  There was no trace of the pie to be found at the end of the meal.

No wine but we finished off the meal with a nice espresso.  I'm tempted to come back for a dinner after work some day soon and try more of the menu.  Definitely worth a look.
author: Ross A.

description:
Before writing the review for this, my second trip to Pazzia, I figured I'd see what Russel S. had said about it; I came here for the first time with him at his suggestion.  Back in 2005, Russ described Pazzia as "...a pretty small place that seems to be not well known yet."

Times have changed.  With 4 stars over 237 reviews and nary a night when the place isn't packed, I think it's fair to say Pazzia has come a long way.  As far as I can tell the food has always been best of class, and it seems they've managed to persist the small - almost family-small - atmosphere.  In this department it's the little stuff that helps: the hand-written specials menu, the ever-present owner in a stylish suit taking turns talking to and occasionally sitting with his customers, the closely-placed tables.  Wonderful atmosphere.

I'm not well-enough versed in Italian cuisine to know if Pazzia represents a particular region, but whatever it is, they've got it nailed.  On this most recent visit I had the hand-made spinach taglierine with pancetta in a white wine sauce and it was liberating.  You see, through some fluke of nature I developed an early aversion to long, thin pastas; only by steadily applied effort and the art of places like Pazzia have I learned to overcome this crippling affliction.  To top it off our achingly cute waitress made an entirely reasonable wine suggestion that paired nicely.

5 stars all around.

Be aware that it can get decently loud, especially if you're at one of the middle tables that doesn't have at least one edge to the wall.  I mean normal-hearing people will be fine but, you know, just be aware.
author: Oliver N.

description:
So, I grew up in suburban Chicago with a lot of Italians.  They used to wear these white baseball type of jackets with the map of Italy on the back and a very I-talian name embroidered. Those kids were the coolest ever.  And so is Pazzia. (Please tell me someone else in Yelp knows about these jackets?)

Eat the pizza, the pasta, the bread. Drink some sangiovese. Admire the pretty Italian waitresses with nice smiles. Watch the super fast busboy.  Get kissed on the cheek by the host. It's my favorite Italian restaurant ever. And not just because I live across the street.
author: Nima K.

description: Great Itaiian. This place is always hoppin.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Before anything else. Dont leave this place without having their Tiramisu. Best I have ever had.

Now, entrees and maincourse. The insalata caprese was yumm, simple and inspirational- now i duplicate it at home. Or try to at least. I had a pizza  with gorgonzola cheese on it, and I must tell you- it was made just right! It is easy to mess up with that cheese, you know- but am glad they didn't. 

Ambience. Nice!
Went there with my brothers on both occasions but I do see a lot of potential in this restaurant to serve as a place for cozy and intimate dinner-dates for the we-are-not-super-classy-but-we-are-not super-frivolous-either romancers of SF.
author: Kirthana S.

description:
This little unassuming spot in SOMA has some of the best italian in the city, IMO. The menu tends toward southern italian and the waitstaff tend toward HOT! And friendly to boot. 

I go back and forth between two dishes although I always want to try something new but by the time my excessively indecisive Libran self gets there I order either the mushroom penne or the spicy rigatoni (these are not their proper names on the menu!). 

I have tried their delicious thin crust pizza and it is memorable and decadent. Great lunch spot and for dinner the parking is really easy. Nice al fresco seating on a warm day. 

It gets really loud in here but it helps make the ambiance feel bustling and exciting as you watch the italian waiters shimmy around the small the dining room while they flatter all the female customers.

Good prices on their yummy red wines and desserts are also tasty, sweet and rich but not overdone. Check 'em out!
author: Adrienne P.

description:
Food - excellent
Service - ok
Ambience - ok but difficult to hear each other talk.  Way too much noise inside.  A better option is to sit outside if weather permits.  At least you can hear each other without yelling.

I had minestrone and the anchovie pizza.  I thought the minestrone was pretty good except not hot enough for me.  I'm one of those old school guys who likes his soup HOT!  

The five of us were seated at a table that could only handle four so it got very crowded when our food came.  My wife and I managed to get about 2/3's of our plates on the table.  I guess they felt an obligation to seat us since we had reservations.  It worked out in the end.

Now back to the food.  My pizza was tasty but I think Amici's does a better job.  My wife had the pomodori salad which was very good and plentiful.  Two could probably split this one.  I had vanilla ice cream in expresso.  It was very good.  It was a scoop of vanilla ice cream dumped in a wine glass of cold expresso.  I would suggest that as something to offer at home when you have guests for dinner.  I would add a little more pizzazz to it by giving it a shot of whipped cream and a dribble of coffee liquer.

Someone else had tiramisu which besides being a generous cut, looked very good.

This place is worth a try.  The only negative is the same negative for any restaurant in SF and that is parking.
author: geoff k.

description:
The Italian in me comes out when pizza is involved. It could be that or something triggers the childhood memory of Friday night pizza and TGIF television. Either way, I like pizza; especially good pizza. 

I checked out Pazzia with a friend while visiting SF. It was right down the street from my hotel and it sounded promising. Plus it had pizza on the menu which was a good enough treat for me because while I have a love for pizza, I don't eat it as often as I wish I could. When we arrived, the restaurant had people in it and they seated us at a table in the back. It's not a huge restaurant and it had a homey feel with the warmth of the oven toasting up the room. The Cesar Salad was good and it had a hint of mustard to it which is a taste you're not expecting with a Cesar Salad but it wasn't necessarily bad. In fact, it actually started to grow on me with every bite. The pizza was phenomenal. It was thin crust but gooey and chewy all at the same time. The cheese oozed and melted in my mouth. The olives, sausage and mushrooms were fresh and filled with taste. It definitely didn't taste like an average Joe pizza parlor pie. 

Now, if this review was just based on the food, I would have easily given it a four, but with every restaurant experience comes the service as well. The service started out great. The waitress greeted us right away and brought us water and asked us for our beverage order. But, slowly (literally) it turned ... well, slow. It especially turned into a snail's pace service after we were finished with our meal and our drinks. We sat there for about 25 minutes (at least) before the waitress brought us our check. When I looked around to see what was causing the holdup, I saw them standing around in the back. Everyone seemed to have their food and while it was populated, it wasn't jam packed, so I'm not sure why the service was so incredibly slow. 

So in summary, the pizza goodness and cheese lingering on my taste buds wanted to give this a four, but the service and wait lowered it to a three.
author: Lindsey D.

description:
What an unassuming place when your first see it off the street or, walk in.

This is what good restaurants should be about. Sticking to the basics, no frills...just excellent food and service.

The dining room is small and on a busy Wednesday night with all tables occupied and people waiting out the door, the 2 servers never stopped to refill our glasses of wine or smile. That in itself is admirable.

The food from the paper thin pizzas to the entrees are all fabulous. The Diavola - spicy sausage pizza I could have again and again and then some.

The Lasagne in Bechamel sauce (even though quite rich) was fantastic. My friend had the Rigatoni which was great as well.

To top it up, the Tiramisu is one of the best I have had in a long time. Light and not heavy on the cream with all the flavors coming through just right.

I just hope this gem continues to thrive and not relocate to a "grander" location or look and feel. You are just perfect Pazzia !!!

This will definitely become a place I visit regularly.
author: Neil B.

description:
With a group of friends I had a dinner there yesterday. We enjoyed the food, but apparently me and my friend had huge stomach problem ( I couldn't sleep till 4am ). I definitely not recommend this place - food wasn't worth sleepless night.

Restroom in kitchen? What kind of sanitary standard is that?

We asked for table for 5 people - they said whey will have it in 15 minutes, we waited and then we were seated by table for 4 people - it was very inconvenient and rude (especially that they didn't inform it will be table for 4).
author: Inez K.

description:
This place was yummy.  The wait staff was amazing, two of our friends had to leave because they forgot something at home and had to cab back to nob hill and back, so she put plates over their food and tucked cloth napkins over them to keep them warm until they returned.  So nice.  But...we were there on a Saturday night...the place is small, so reservations are a must.

I had the homemade spinach linguini with salmon in a white wine sauce...I think it was a special, not on the normal menu.  The place reminded me of Osteria in Palo Alto (and I love Osteria) so I thought their fresh pasta would be super good.  It was good, but not super good.  I would definitely try this place out, and it looks like some of the glowing reviews are of the pizza, so if I'm ever back here, I'll try that out instead.
author: starrynight c.

description: This place is AMAZING!! Consistently exceeds expectations.  The marriage of flavors is perfection! Best pizza in the city by far! Try everything! I can't say what my favorite dish is because they are all FABULOUS!! Homemade pasta, desserts, wine, yum!
author: kelly l.

description: The pizza reminds of of a thin crust pizza reminiscent of pizza from Italy (even though I've never been there). It was so simplistic (thin crust, mozzarella cheese, tomato sauce and a little basil) but simple is key to this dish. The not so good part of the restaurant was my friend had to ask for butter not once, not twice, but three times. The door to the restaurant was kept open even though it was quite freezing outside and we were right by the door. We ordered two types of chicken entrees, one was rather dry and so was the potato wedges that came with it. Will try other dishes next time if I'm ever in the area.
author: Tossama C.

description: A buddy of mine knows the owner (who is a great, friendly guy) and we went here for a lunchtime meal.  I had one of their pizzas and it was good but I was hoping for something more out of it.  I'll have to go back sometime and try another pizza or one of their pasta dishes then.
author: Albie F.

description: The bruschetta was embarrassingly bad. The pizza was mediocre. The service was passable. The tiramisu was good. The coffee was warty. And it VERY LOUD!!! All in all, don't waste your money.
author: David G.

description:
Okay- I'm the one who makes up a dish in my head and craves it even if it's not on the menu.

And this is how I came to this sweet little ristorante.

I recently wounded my paw and have been jacked up on Vicodin, thus the morning gym ritual was pushed to the side for sleeping in. After 10 days of not hitting the abs, I'm feeling "fluffy".

So to battle the bulge, I have absconded from eating any carbs.

But then my client says, "let's meet at Pazzia."
Why torture me with a great pizza place! Damn!

They were very hospitable and sweet when i asked if they could throw some salmon on a ceasar for me. Very cool!

And after all that, I cheated with a chunk of their fresh bread and oil. 

Injuries suck.
Pazzia Rules.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
It was a big day in the office when we decided to skip the same ol' sandwich or burrito and go big!  We walked over to Pazzia for steak.  We are so having steak for lunch!  And yes, Pazzia is an Italian Restaurant!  It's a small but quaint place, where you can tell most of their patrons are regulars.  We'll today, we were crashing their party. 

We went in with a mission, 3 of us went for the filet with mushrooms and sides of broccoli and potatoes.  Although my steak was a bit more medium instead of medium rare...it was all very tasty.  We ended the meal with coffee and decided that we all would return again.  

I may go for the pasta next time, everyone in the place had pizza and pasta and it all looked delicious!  A nice change of pace for lunch, I'll be back to try more of the menu.
author: Valarie A.

description:
monday night dinner at 9:00 means no line what so ever.

had the gnocchi special, with the proscitto/arugula pizza. and of course the waitress was pretty cute too!
author: Ameer N.

description:
I was really excited to eat here for lunch today.  A co-worker and I walked a good 8 blocks to get here after reading an article on SFGATE about this place.  When we got here, we were seated promptly and then promptly waited 10 minutes for no service.  We just sat there staring at the table and other customers eating their lunches.  I tried to get the waitress' attention several times to no avail so I got up and helped myself to a couple of menus.  I had my head bitten off when I was caught doing this.  When I tried to let the waitress know I was just trying to help she proceeded to raise her voice at me and told me I wasn't supposed to be helping myself to the menus and that I'd picked up the wrong menus and she was sorry but she was the only one working and is busy.  What her eyes were telling me was:

"Who the hell do you think you are getting up and doing my job for me.  Go back to your table and sit down before I really get angry.  And I'm saying I'm sorry but what I really mean is you need to sit the HELL DOWN."  

My co-worker and I walked out.  The was absolutely the rudest "service" I have ever received at a restaurant.  If that's what you like at an Italian restaurant this place fits the bill. I for one will not be back until this waitress no longer works here AND I have forgiven the establishment for allowing someone who treats patrons this way to work there.
author: Spicy T.

description:
As another reviewer already pointed out, Pazzia is owned and run by Italians, and they have a sister restaurant in Florence.  By all accounts (I've never actually been to Italy), this place is authentic; and, more importantly, just damn good.  How lucky am I that since I live across the street, I can walk over and get take-out pretty much any night I want?  If you've ever been there for dinner and saw a brown dude walk in in sweats to pick up take-out, that was me.

It's a total hole in the wall, neighbourhood restaurant.  Tables are pretty much right on top of each other, service can be, well, european (read: slow, but constantly in motion), and you have to kind of cut into the kitchen area to go to the bathroom.  But the food, oh the food... fantastic thin crust pizzas (as an east coaster, I love the thin crust pizza.  Enough already with the big doughy impostor Californians call pizza), lasagna in bechamel,  I could go on and on.  The wine list isn't terribly extensive, but it has everything you would look for at an Italian place (Chianti, Sangiovese, etc.), and all reasonably priced.  And on those rare evenings in Soma when it isn't windy or cold, the outside seating is a God send.

Also, rumor has it that Massimo is opening a wine bar in the space next door.  Massimo himself has been propagating this rumor for at least 6 months, so I'm sure -- a little like the service some times -- he'll get around to it eventually :-)
author: Maneesh B.

description: Great place! Friendly staff, homey atmosphere and good, honest-Italian food you can always depend on. If you get the bread fresh out of the oven, you will be a customer for life--it is unforgettable!
author: Clay M.

description:
Eh.  Sub-par food, hideous decor, passable service.

The best part about my dinner there was the strange mix of people there at the same time.  Some cute 20-somethings on a date.   Some nearly naked chick with three guys.   A drunken table full of older guys, headed by two schmoozesters with blinding chiclet teeth, orange skin, open shirts and spiked hair.   I couldn't look away.

But the food is over-priced, inelegantly seasoned and over-greased (as others have mentioned).  Save this one for desperate times.
author: Ethan M.

description: A good place to have a thin crust Italian pizza.  The place is not so big, so the place could fill up really quick and form a long line, especially when it's too cold to sit outside.  Friendly Italian service could be good...could be a bit much at times.  We had their salad, pasta, and pizza, which were all pretty good.
author: トモ T.

description: Excellent Italian food from a pretty small place that seems to be not well known yet.  Handmade pasta, small pizzas, filet mignon.. it's all good.
author: Russel S.

description:
What a nice surprise!  The concierge described Pazzia as "a hole in the wall, pretty low end if that's what you want."  Excuse me??  Pazzia might be a bit out of the way, and small, but I wouldn't describe it like that.

In fact, I would describe it as a little slice of Italy: white tablecloths, a (real live!) Italian maitre'd, carafes of chianti, a great menu, and an attentive staff.

Lots of locals here, and it seems like a good date option as well.  Definitely recommended!
author: Foster K.

description:
I checked out Pazzia for the first time, and I can't believe it's taken me this long to find this hidden gem! I'm ashamed to say that I used to consider myself a San Francisco foodie. I must now hang my chowhound head in shame. Their pizza was the best thin-crust (almost cracker like) I've had in the city, and their pasta was also fantastic. Why hadn't I even heard of this spot before?

I can pretend to blame the somewhat random location; they're on 3rd St. between Folsom and Harrison. But I still should've known. Pazzia also isn't the cutest restaurant on earth, but it has its own charm. And the prices are very reasonable. Most dishes ran between $15-25.

All I know is that I must go back soon to make up for my gastronomic ignorance. It's worth it for the pizza alone.
author: jenn h.

description:
Wow, an Itialian restaurant right under my nose! Love it here! I work so close to this place and yesterday was my first time there. It was a last minute starving action. Got off work late... 9:45 p.m. on a Monday, who's open? Ah.. right across the street. Pizza sounded yummy!!! 

So we ordered and I believe it's the fastest dinner I've ever ate. Ordered Salad, pizza, and Veal, dessert Tiramisu... everything is delicious. Can't go wrong. Especially when you hear the Italian language being spoken... my heart just melted.. What is it with this language that girls absolutely go gaaagaaaa over... 

Will be coming back over and over again!!
author: Judi K.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised that this authentic eatery excels at handling a large group, despite is European size & quaintness. Our meal was served trattoria style, and nearly everything came with a stamp of authenticity (straight from Florence)! 

The margherite pizza stole the show, though the prosciutto pizza and the sausage pizza got plenty of attention. Keeping us hydrated was more challenging for the waiter, but there were over 20 of us, so we understood.  

The chef treated our team to one of the best helpings of tiramisu in the city, beaten only by cafes in Little Italy, three neighborhoods away. A serving of coffee and cappucino closed up this sublime Tuscan experience.  

What a treat!
author: Daniel C.

description:
This is an awesome place to eat pre-performance.  The food is good, prices are reasonable and service expeditious and courteous.   I'm not crazy about the lasagna that everyone else raves about (a little watery for my liking) but, yes, dear fellow yelpers, I love, love the authentic thin crust pizzas.  We get sausage and mushroom... mmmm...I'm salivating right now.  The antipasti platter, italian wine and delish tiramisu round out dinner rather well.

In the negative column, the decor is pretty bad...seriously: think chain fast food.  Honestly, had I not been turned onto Pazzia by Yelp, I would never have gone there.  In fact, I think I've walked passed it a gazillion times and never noticed it.  

I will definitely go back..it reminds of Roma and my Roman friend Roberto (sigh) Noisy, cheap but really very charming.
author: Shannon M.

description: A group of friends and I have informally called ourselves the "Check Please Bay Area Dinner Club" and are making the rounds to those restaurants that have been reviewed on the popular PBS show.  Well, this was my friend, Brian's pick and we thoroughly enjoyed it.  If you love homemade pasta, soft french rolls and great wine, check it out.  I read the other reviews, and have to say I agree with most; it is a very small restaurant (but they are expanding), with great service and a friendly atmosphere.  There is a parking lot right next door (paid lot), so it is conveniently located.  We had 5:30 reservations and were seated immediately. We ordered a variety of dishes and shared; here's what we liked:  We started with salads; Caprese, beet and then an apple and blue cheese, respectively.  The beet salad was deemed the best.  Moving on, we sampled the pizzas...if you come here for one reason only, come for the pizza; they are light on the crust and full of flavorful toppings and a wonderful sauce.  For entrees:  I had the tortelloni, filled with braised beef, served in a cream sauce with mushrooms that was wonderful.  My companions had the rigatoni (deemed very good), veal (which I don't eat, but my dinner companion enjoyed very much) and fettuccine with asparagus and prawns in a white wine sauce (again, a winner).  We finished off with the Tiramisu, which they are noted for, and the lemon cake.  There were raves over the Tiramisu; it was light and flavorful, and I thought the lemon cake was the perfect way to finish the meal.  Overall, this is a great place for authentic Italian cuisine.  We really enjoyed our evening here and would recommend it.
author: Wendy G.

description: When I worked at a hotel a few blocks away I sent our guests to Pazzia every day for many years. I always got great feedback. I love this place, the food and that fabulous owner & manager Massimo. The service is always good and the food authentic. They'll cater to big groups also.  It's a place you can keep going back to because the food is just so tasty. Massimo treats his staff well, he's genuine and so is Pazzia.
author: M H.

description: The Food was like a dream come true the Meat in this little place is Fresh try the Veal Rib Chop excellent the poultry is really good. this is the real flavor from Italy the homemade pasta and pizza Amazing. The Owner Massimo very Friendly Thank You.
author: Nino L.

description:
They do speak italian here!  That's a lot better than what they do in North Beach.  

I got the ceasar salad to split with Louis (Tori doesn't do ceasar dressing), and the mushroom and sausage pasta.  To be fair, I ordered this on a suggestion of the cute waitress before I remembered halfway through eating that I loath Italian sausage.  Maybe it was that guy I used to date, maybe it's the fennel.  I'm not a fan unless it's the cheap, questionable meat source type on pizza hut pizza.  

Rob has taught me: I like to see the meat part of the meat, not the conglomerate ground of anything is possible.

Plus side: they did remove it from the nasty casing before grilling it so it resembled lumps of ground meat and not sliced up tubes of meat.  Ew.  Tube meat versus spoon meat.  You choose.

The sauce was a little salty.  It was a tomoato based.  And reasonable in density.  It clung to the pasta noodles in a nice way.  But it was too salty (and don't say anything about my dehydration because we didn't start drinking until after lunch).  The mushrooms were tender and I ate all of that.

Tori got the margherita pizza.  I would have like to see some basil on it, some fresh mozzerella.  Louis got the arugala and proscuitto pizza.  He was well satisfied at the portion though he made a comment about wishing that they baked the proscuitto on the pizza instead of laying it on top afterwards (he's secretly wishing for bacon).  Is it a certain style where they lay stuff on top after the pizza has been baked?  Or is it an efficient way to bake pizza quickly?
author: Christina C.

description:
Stuffy and pretentious for a neighborhood restaurant. The tables are way too close. I am a tiny person and my butt was almost the entree for another table as I tried to leave.

Food and service were averge, but not worth the price (especially these days and with other choices close by).

The tiramisu was embarassing. The dessert itself was not inedible, but it is disgraceful to call it tiramisu. It was mostly sweetened whipped cream and cocoa powder (literally ... It took up 2/3 the height). The cake tasted like it came out of box. Where was the mascarpone? Strong espresso flavor? Lady fingers (or at least a better sponge)? Chocolate shavings? I LOVE desserts, and have been known to order two just for myself. I ate two bites.
author: Ginger K.

description:
I'm not sure I had a pizza here. I think I had a serving of oil with crust serving as the base. I'm no oil fan, but this was over the top. I could have been dabbing at the thing all day with paper towels to sponge some up and there still would have been more than your average pizza left. Disgusting.

Also disgusting was the pricing. $10 for a basic marinara pizza wasn't bad. I asked for no cheese, spinach instead, thinking this was a fair substitute. The bill was $13.75. I asked the waitress, um, did you charge me $4 for spinach? No she said, only $3.75, and I got a lot of it. Um, right, I stand corrected, now let me talk to a manager to find out how spinach that looks like it has been soaked in oil costs twice as much as a bag of the good stuff at Trader Joe's. She returned with a bill revised down to $12. Thanks. Look for a bill for the inevitable artery unclogging procedure later.

This is the part I curse myself for wanting to try every restaurant in SF even though I should know way, way better.
author: Jason B.

description: Great food.  Quick service.  Good price.  Limited bar.  Noisy but entertaining to watch humans interacting.
author: Katy A.

description:
Best margherita pizza anywhere. Bold statement, but true.
Only Italian Restaurant I dare take our friends visiting from Italy.. and yes, the Lasagna is really that good.
Now If only Massimo would open the damn bar next door!
author: don l.

description: Gutes Essen, hervorragende Getränke, guter Service, wir würden jederzeit dieses Restaurant erneut besuchen.
author: Christian L.

description:
Favorite Italian place in the city.  This food here is simple and authentic.  

The pizza is absolutely amazing.  It has a really light thin crispy crust with the best sauce fantastic mozzarella cheese.  The pastas here are all delicious as well.  

All of the waiters here are straight from Italy and the owner Massimo is always present in the restaurant drinking wine.  The service is excellent as well.  

Make sure you make a reservation here or you will be waiting on the sidewalk for a long time.  This place is popular!
author: Dan L.

description: A surprise, really.  I mean, this is SOMA, do I don't expect a small neighborhood Italian restaurant in the area, and I certainly don't expect it to make good food.  Wrong on both counts.  Other than the overly aggressive mob of waiters and busboys who were only too happy to refill my water and wine (whether I needed it or not) and take my plate away while I was only halfway through the meal, I had a great meal.  Really!
author: Laurence W.

description: Had some take outs, pizza with sausage and mushrooms,Gnocchi w meat sauce and Pennette pasta.  Thought the pizza was pretty good.  The gnocchi was way overcooked and the penne was "al dente" so ok.  The woman server was very cute :-)
author: Jim J.

description:
I've eaten here over twenty times and this place is the definition of a tuscan trattoria. The service is not the best but it is always good and friendly. This will not be the best italian food you will ever have but it's always delicious and dependable.  I guess I just like this place because it's not trying to be something it's not. It's just a neighborhood restaurant with a charming owner.

My favorite dishes: Pizza w/arugula and prosciutto, insalta di Medici and pollo alla medici. 

I've been to the owner's family's restaurant in Florence and this place is just as authentic as any place you will find in Tuscany. The only thing missing is an extensive wine list and alcohol.

I will continue to keeping coming because the quality of food for the price just can't be beat.
author: Roger H.

description:
This was actually the first restaurant I went to when I first got to SF. I wasn't expecting much by the looks of it but it turned out to be very good. I had a carpaccio, and a pasta (can't remember the type) with a cream sauce and porcini mushrooms. All that I finished with a refreshing moscato.
One of the best things about the place were the perfect portions. I hate going to a restaurant that serves huge portions (uhum... Cheesecake Factory): it kills the whole experience (though I've learned to deal with it and take home the left-overs).
It's a mid-priced restaurant, with a friendly staff and good service.
If you are ever in the mood for traditional Italian, at a good price, this place is a hit.
author: Esteban P.

description:
I've been going here so long it's surprising I never wrote a review.

Almost every visit here has been a sure fire hit except once. Once it wasn't. But let's not focus on the once, shall we?

The good:
- The service is really sweet and accommodating. Puts up with us when we have a large unruly crowd or when it's just a nice romantic dinner for two.
- the pizza is really good. Thin crust, not too heavy on the toppings, good sausage (if it's on your pizza).
- the pastas are also good. The simple tomato sauce is light, the pasta with sausage and mushroom is also really tasty. I have a friend who craves this place whenever he's in town and it's almost always pasta w/ ragu sauce (that may or may not be on the menu but they always make).
Can get cramped; is a cozy place. Outdoor seating when it's warm out.
author: Margie L.

description:
Pazzia is mmmmmmm good. This is one of my fav sit down lunch spots. The pasta dishes are really good. My favs are the Rigatoni with Sausage and Mushroom and the pasta with mushroom cream sauce. My only complaint is that the portions are a bit small. The pizzas are the thin crust kind and they are decently sized and really yummy. I like the one with the proscuitto. They have specials menu everyday. They had a lasagna special on one visit and that was really good, but again the portion was a bit too small.
The staff is really friendly and great. They are great about refilling water and bringing over cheese and pepper after the entrees are brought out. One annoying thing is that you have to walk through the kitchen to use the restroom and it isn't very clean.
author: Vanessa W.

description: Wow, the pizza here was really great.  The lasagna and tiramisu were also good, but I'd come back for the pizza.
author: Amjad S.

description: I live two blocks away from this restaurant and for the last 2 months there is either a line or every seat is taken. One night when my mother was in town we decided to give it a try, and boy what a disappointment. The pasta was straight up from a box and the sauce was straight up ragu !! We ordered a Margherita  Pizza and it had a thick layer of cheap cheese and the most miniscule slivers of dried basil. The crust was not exciting either. I don't understand why this place is always busy. There is nothing gourmet about this place.
author: Joe S.

description:
A while back my friends described the cast at Pazzia as stars in an italian soap opera - after each meal they left with stories of the latest episode. Rumors flew al dente about waitresses sleeping with the owner while the wife threw knife-like stares from the kitchen. Regardless the staff at Pazzia are fun, engaging and welcoming characters.

Pazzia's dishes are mostly always delicious. The squash ravioli in creme sauce is divine. Friends rave that the pizzas offer authentically thin, crispy crusts.

Tonights sampling included roast chicken with a bronzed skin matching those living under a tuscan sun. Sadly the skin wasn't very crispy and like many sun worshipers hid a thick layer of fat beneath. 

My dish of homemade spinach pasta with meat ragu was hearty and filling and would've paired nicely with a robust wine. Unfortunately it was too salty and made me wishing I had opted for the mushroom and sausage pizza.

Service from the owner was great, and he treated our friends with kids like family. All this despite the chance that his wife, dining at the table next to us, could go into labor at any moment! Salud!

(3.75 * stars)
author: Brady K.

description:
Come for the pizza, not for the service.  The Diavola pizza is simple (sauce, cheese, spicy sausage) but is hands down my favorite item on the menu.  The pastas are decent, the veal is usually good but nothing holds up against the pizza. 

As for the service...it's Italian....you place your order, you get your food but there aren't many frills.  

What really took away from this place is that we arrived at 9:45 to looks of confusion from the wait staff as if they haven't encountered people who wanted to eat "late".  After a few seconds and a few nods from the kitchen we were finally seated.  While the kitchen doesn't close until 10:30 they staff started placing the chairs on the table around 10:15 which was our signal to finish up eating and get out of there.   So, come for the food, not for the service and you'll leave with a good experience.
author: Joshua J.

description:
This place has much more of an authentic Italian feel than any place I've dined in North Beach.  I credit this to the polite and prompt wait staff  that was oozing with Italian charm.  I almost felt like breaking out the few Italian phrase I know...grazie, prego...just to complete the experience.  If you want handmade pasta, order from the handwritten specials menu.  I surmise that the standard pasta dishes are made using the boxes of Barilla pasta visable from the dining room.  (Hmm...i can buy that brand at safeway).  I'll have to go back for the pizza...if it's as good as other yelpers say I could adjust my rating. 

This is a good date spot if you are thinking dinner and a movie (at the Metreon) and don't have a car...just bart down and walk!
author: mandy f.

description:
Came here last night for some dinner before watching a ballet down the street at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.  The restaurant was on a list the center has on their website for restaurants in the area, and I had let my mom pick which one she wanted to go to.  She picked this one because it was closest to the garage she likes to park in.  Not necessarily the best way to pick a dinner spot, but it was her night so I didn't say anything.  

Walking in to the unassuming, glass-walled small restaurant, I did not have high expectations.  There was only one other party in the small place, and that was half children.  The hostess/waitress raised those expectations quickly, since she spoke with an Italian accent.  

Once seated, I had a glass of an Italian Merlot that was wonderful (and generously poured!), and we started with Minestrone Soup, Tomato Bruschetta, and an Endive Salad with Gorgonzola.  All were delicious, and I don't know where they're getting their tomatoes from in December, but they were perfectly ripe and tasty!  For entrees, we had the Roast Chicken, Fusilli pasta, and a Veal Shank Special.  All were perfectly cooked and tasty, though we all added some salt to our meals.  We later saw some pizzas that looked wonderfully light and thin crusted, we'll have to try those next time!  For dessert we split a Tiramisu that was very good, though it didn't have quite enough coffee taste for me (though my mom thought it was perfect).  

And by the time we left, there was quite a line waiting to be seated, so if you plan on coming here, make a reservation!  I'll definitely try to make it back to this place to try the pizza and have some tiramisu!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
The food here is actually surprising authentic and it's like wtf? do you ship your help in from Italy?  I'm down, I can't pronounce correctly, but I'm still game.

Bruschette is excellent, so are all the pastas I've ever eaten there - the one in the creme sauce w/pine nuts especially.  You know, you never find pine nuts as often as you'd hope.

It's a small place, nothing fancy - but it doesn't need to be.  Get the job done and everything here is really satisfying.

If you want to go out for Italian, go here, it's good.

My only complaint is the my stomach always feels this food a little more than it probably should.  So, I'm attempting a return, but on a day when I eat no fiber.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I've now been here 4 times in a month...yes. It's THAT good. 

Finally tried the pizza - light, airy crust, wonderful flavors. But it's still the pastas that keep me coming back...the spaghetti is perfectly cooked, the lasagna is to die for and I just can't get enough of the capellini. This place definitely deserves an upgrade to 5 stars!
author: Adrienne C.

description: Had lunch here yesterday and really enjoyed it.  Started with a bruschetta, which was good but could've been better, especially if they spread a little ricotta on it or something.  The ceasar was excellent, with wonderful little homemade herbed croutons.  We got the special pizza, which had proscuitto, arugla, olive oil and a bit of cheese on it.  It was excellent.  Service was friendly.  We got parking immediately in front of the restaurant!
author: Kevin M.

description:
Best pizza I've had since Grimaldi's in Brooklyn. Thin, savory crust, fresh ingredients. Had the pizza with prosciutto, olives, artichokes. also had the antipasto -- likewise very fresh and savory. Other people around us had various pastas, meat or fish entrees. Looked good, and I'm eager to return and try some. Desserts looked good, but we were too full! Wine was good, but expensive -- glasses are $8, and bottles start out at $30.  

When we walked in, they asked us if we had reservations, which we did not. Then, they said it would 15-20 minutes. They then proceeded to switch out some tables (1 round for a couple of 2-person squares) and seated us after 10 minutes. 

The restaurant was a little smoky -- seemed like they needed to turn on the exhaust. Would also be great if they had heaters outside to take advantage of the outside tables -- this is perpetually foggy SF, after all, even in SOMA. Decor is nothing special, but I guess they focus more on the cuisine -- which is probably better! 

Overall, yummy, and will definitely go back.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Ate here again last night with my niece and my sister ... never had problems finding parking here in the early evening and last night was no exception--sis managed princess parking right outside the door.  The sidewalk here isn't as well-lit as it could be, and I could see why someone would be intimidated by the external appearance.

We chose simple entrees and weren't disappointed.  Tasty food was served promptly.  Entrees arrived a few moments before we were ready for them, but not really a great tragedy.  

The big minus?  The tables here are seriously close together, and this place is *loud* ... ten minutes after we were seated the table next to us cleared and we thought we might get some relief ... but a minute later the table was cleared and had new patrons . . . if you can't beat 'em then join 'em, I suppose.
author: Henry M.

description:
My fiance and I came here for dinner on a recent Saturday night. Our friend's girlfriend was in town and she used to love this place when she worked in SF. From the outside, the place looks like it should be in a strip mall. Nothing pretty or creative about it at all. 

The menu is quite extensive. It reminded me of my local pizza and pasta restaurant growing up. My fiance and I ordered the Carpaccio and Buratta to start. The buratta was average, nothing special and it can't even compare to A-16's buratta. The carpaccio was good, but again nothing special. 

For my entree I had the arugula and prosciutto pizza. The prosciutto was very good and the pizza was tasty. I would have liked the option of putting a fried egg on it. My fiance had the linguine with white clam sauce. This was very good. 

Overall, this isn't somewhere I would go to impress anyone. If I lived in walking distance this would probably be a solid go-to on weeknights for take out or a casual dinner. No complaints and reasonable prices.
author: Katie S.

description:
If you want some of the best authentic thin crust pizza made and served outside of Italy, Pazzia will more than satisfy that itch you may be feeling in the pit of your stomach.  That and you don't have to deal with the hassle of battling the throngs of tourists in North Beach which is a huge plus if you are a SOMA resident like I am.

How they are able to accomplish an almost perfect pizza with an electric salamander and without the benefit of a wood burning oven is beyond me, but they do and i'm glad.
author: Deborah K.

description: Small cute little place. you walk in and am overcome by magnificent smells. I came here to 'carboload' for a race with about 8 other people. the service was great and everyone enjoyed their meal.  Everyone had something different so I will go on a limb and say everything is good! :)
author: Grace L.

description:
had dinner here a few nights ago with friends.  we all like to share so tried quite a few dishes, several of which were really, truly delicious.

the pizzas were fantastic, and both the insalata medici and the insalata pazzia were refreshing and tasty - but what really made the meal stand out was the homemade pasta.  i don't know about you, but i find it surprisingly difficult to find good Italian in SF, and i was very pleased to find that the pasta was fresh, well made, and really worth a trip to the informal, but classical trattoria where it was made and served.

if you go, definitely try the homemade lasagna, the salmon taglierini, and anything made with the fresh fettuccine.  a friend got the rack of lamb, which also looked amazing, but i didn't get a chance to try it...  sounds like a good reason to go back, to me!

incidentally, i saw someone mention bad service in another review, and i have to say i am very surprised.  the staff at Pazzia are honestly some of the most charming and attractive girls i've seen working at any restaurant in SF.  they certainly didn't disappoint me or my friends in any way.
author: Dr. X.

description:
It's incumbent on me, THE PIZZA MAVEN, to write about this pizzeria. Primo : I lived in Italy for 13 months. Secondo : I speak Italiano . Terza : I visited and ate pizza at the Pantheon of La Pizza Cultura : the Vomero neighborhood in Napoli.  Pizza was born there; it was defined there; and after you eat it there, you can expire in peace. The most cogent historic phrase that comes to mind : " See Napoli and die ! "

The Pizza here is absolutely " Pazzia" ( Craziness, Mushuggah ), in its quality, color , presentation and provenance. What shines the most , is the CRUST !!
It's the hardest element to get right and at Pazzia, it's " molto Italiano" : slightly burnt, super thin, and hint of smokiness on the tongue.  I like the traditional Margherita ( justa' sauce pomodoro ), but they do all the traditional toppings with aplomb.  Try the Quattro Stagione ( 4 seasons ) or the Al Funghi ( mushrooms ).In sum, all the pies have the Neopolitan quality.

The culture of the place screams of Tuscany. You are greeted warmly ; if known you get a double cheek kiss -- man or woman.  The Italians who run the place recreate an nice original experience-- cheaper than flying to Florence.  Once seated you get to take in the exuberant impressionistic murals of  The Cinque Terre ( in Liguria, artist : Sassone ) and view the energetic sud-Americano chefs working hard behind the counter.

This is a wonderful lunch experience, perhaps before MOMA ( 2 blocks north), as you can eat outdoors getting the benefit of the afternoon sun. At night, after 7pm, there is easy free parking ( try 3rd St or Harrison).

In addition to pizza, the diner will also be treated to wonderful tuscan trattoria food, at very fair prices.  

Evviva and buon appetito !
author: Jon H.

description:
The best thin crust pizza I have had in the states. Comes close to most everything I've had in italy. The spicy sausage pizza is the best.

Avoid the overpriced, bite-sized lasagna.
author: John M.

description:
Thanks to all my Yelp friends for making this decision easy.  

We're from LA and wanted something good and affordable (too much $$ on tours and shopping!).    Italian seemed like the cuisine most suitable for our prerequisites.  

Walked over and the place was packed.  There were a few large groups ahead of us and since we had no reservation the owner asked to wait 10 minutes.    I was positive from what I read here 10 minutes would be 30 but no in 10 minutes we were seated.    We ordered from the specials which was a page long list handwritten.   

Hubby had the lasanga and I had the chicken breast stuffed with mozz & proscuitto.   We shared the caprese.  

All the food was good not the bastardized Italian most restaurants are slanging out.   Nothing to write home about but good none the less.  We should have gotten the pizzas as those looked delish but next time we're in SF we will go visit Pazzia again.    Real close to AT&T park so when games end there are tons of fans waiting to eat.
author: Sara D.

description:
Woah was the pizza I just had at Pazzia ginormous and cheap!
It could have easily fed two people.  Warning though: I got the Capricciosa, and the olives have pits (you could tell before biting into them, so no teeth broken, but be on the look-out).  They're Italian-style thin-crust, so don't go expecting Uno/Pizza Chicago.

Solid local dining spot for anybody who lives in the SoMA/Union Square area.  I'm not sure I would recommend people travel long distance, but if you're seeing a movie at the Metreon, visiting with people on this side of the city, going to a ball game, or looking for a place to hand out after work, this is a good option.

The dessert was underwhelming, but they had an adequate list of Italian wines and the espresso was good, which weighs heavier in my book.

Also - MAJOR POINTS for not trying to rush my friends and I out after dinner.  We stayed for a good 30 minutes talking, and no trying to clear us out.  Very European and appreciated.
author: Tullia F.

description:
At first I already made up mind that I hated the place because of the wait. This is not a place for walk-ins. Be sure to make reservations. 

After waiting over an hour, we were approached by the owner and he was really nice and apologized for the wait and that he hoped we understood that the place gets packed during dinner. He gave us 2 free glasses of wine while we waited which was really nice. Anyways as for the food, two thumbs up for the pizza. The light crispy crust and fresh toppings made my anger into pure pizza bliss. I ate a whole pizza by myself. The pasta was good too. 

I definitely recommend this place if you want a good quality gourmet pizza; not to eat to get full, but to eat and enjoy your food and relax. View and decor is ok. Location is ok. Parking....bleh.
author: David W.

description:
Love to visit Massimo & Co! He remembers everyone and makes everyone feel so welcomed... I always take my out of town guests to visit my favorite friend from Italy in San Francisco. Gives me a good reason to visit SF, since I live in San Jose now!:)

Food is great, not to mention the atmosphere. I actually like the small place, as it gives the authentic italian "hole-in-the wall" feeling, not to mention the staff ! You will also not get italian food in SF that tastes like this, it takes a true italian to be able to make the food taste like it does in Pazzia. 

Massimo takes great pride in his restaurant and the fact that people will come back. There is always a line to get in, people become regulars and keep coming back week after another.  It becomes their "living room" as restaurants are to people in Italy. 

We always have fun dining here, it is like a mini trip to Italy when you visit Pazzia!
author: Nina E.

description:
I live in the apartment complex situated above where the restaurant is.  My townhouse is actually pretty much right above and when my room window is open I get to take in delicious smells all night.

I've only gotten take out from the restaurant a couple times because like all the previous reviews space is quite limited.  I recommend getting there before 7p if you don't have reservations because any later than that there will be a wait.

Delicious!  My favorite right now the capricciosa pizza, awesome toppings with an amazing thin crust.  I also love their bruschetta though it is a bit salty and you can't go wrong with the sausage rigatoni.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Place makes me smile....thats all I can say about this place. Once it gets its added extension, place will be 5 star. the staff is incredibly nice. I did have to wait alittle bit but that is only because it was dinner time. But the staff was right on it once I sat down. When you think of a great small mom and pops shop, this one should be what you picture. =)

Tips:
Make a reservation! I got to go infront of 4 groups for making a call 30 minutes in advance =)
author: Charlie D.

description: I'm behind on reviews and just realized I haven't reviewed Pazzia.  I've been here 3 or 4 times.  It's pretty darn good.  The crust is always nice and bubbly. The ingredients seem pretty high quality, and the atmosphere is nice and cozy if just a little crowded.  I haven't been in a few months or so and I think they might have been expanding their dining so maybe they can seat more now? I don't know.  I say give it a try if you like local made pizza with true Italian style.  I don't think you'd be disappointed unless you're expecting deep dish.
author: Rodney P.

description:
BEST PIZZA IN SF.

Or at least the best I've tried so far. 

The crust is thin and crispy, toppings are perfectly cooked... try the gorgonzola pizza... so good. 

I've also had their pasta with porcini mushrooms. Very generous with the mushrooms and so luscious. 

Mmmm... I think I'll go back soon.
author: Jacob L.

description:
Highly recommend this place.  I have had both pasta and pizza there and loved it.  Service was good as well--typically served by hot Italian waitresses. (a hearty thank you). 

So: Spicy Sausage pizza - yeah
Salads/all - yeah
author: Craig R.

description:
I just walked by here and the smell emanating from inside gave me instant olafactory recall (I.O.R) of Tuscany. 

Simple, well prepared dishes. Fabulous. Wine. Even more wonderful!
author: Eli B.

description:
I think Pazzia is great for pizza. Yes it's in my hood but they compete with another, errr place, just down the block so I've got options. 

I swear by the Calzone Romano. Cheese, mushrooms, and ham. Seriously the best with one caveat- you MUST eat it there. Don't take it to go. Even on my short walk home the quality suffers if it's not hot out of the oven. I have no idea if egg is supposed to be in it (not pretending to be a pizza/calzone/italian food expert) but lordy, I literally crave this food.
author: B S.

description:
This is a small restaurant that seems like it's always full of a mix of SF natives and tourists.  You should make reservations-- we got seated right away on a Friday night around 6:"30 pm but only because we got lucky.

The thin crust pizza lived up to half-Sicilian boyfriend's discriminating taste.  My glass of cab was delicious.  The penne puttanesca was a sexy workhorse that delighted my taste buds and quelled my hunger.  

Despite the blah location (on trafficky 3rd street across from some ugly utilities building), the charming and warm hostess and waitstaff make this place actually cozy and romantic!  Now that's Italian.

This restaurant is like my favorite pair of blue jeans of restaurants.  Good enough for date night when you don't want to make a big production of it!
author: Corii L.

description:
We had a nice dinner here with a group of six. Go early because there are actually lines out the door waiting to get in after 8pm. 

I had the mussles, minestroni soup (very different from what i expected...it was more like potato and cabbage soup), and the bread was tasty for dipping. The rest of the group had a variety of pasta and lasagnia and gnocci. Pretty good. 

I have to take a star away for having the bathroom in the kitchen...and my musscles had several cracked shells that i ended up crunching bits on.

It was about $45 a person including appetizer, main dish and a bottle of wine.
author: Kitty N.

description:
Three of us got in without a reservation at five-thirty pm on a Friday night. We each had a pizza (generic Margherita, Gorgonzola, and Sausage) and  split the Fiji Apple and Gorgonzola salad. The pizza was good, but not the best I've had (maybe I'm being too stingy, comparing it to NYC pizza?).

Prices were pretty reasonable. I guess it was a little loud, but I didn't think  it was as big of a problem as was mentioned below. The staff was friendly, but I was a little annoyed when they took the red crushed pepper from our table "because another table needed it". Really? Couldn't spring for more than one home-made red pepper crusher (one for each table)?

I'd probably go again because it's walkable, but it wouldn't be at the top of my list.
author: David M.

description:
I really like italian and so I'm really picky about which italian places I go. I don't want to spoil my taste for it by going to one place which is a disaster.  The smells that come out of this place are incredible.  It's a cute hole in the wall but very well decorated with outside seating available for those Global Warming "Hot " days in the city.

I ordered a Capellini alla Rughetta to go which is usually not recommended because it gets mushy when the capellini is ordered to go... But it was fabulous.  A bit heavy on the chunky tomatoes but the taste was awesome.  Just the right amount of condiments and flavor.
The portion was really hefty and they give a lot of bread.

Definately reccomend.
author: Diana C.

description: OK, I've now been back to Pazzia numerous times, and the place has grown on me. Well, most things have, except the non-pitted olive pizzas. I think my first few times, I didn't know what to order. Or it'd been overcrowded. But going to Pazzia at anytime other than noon is a much more pleasant experience, and the pizzas and other items seem to be given more care and attention.
author: Bee H.

description: I am def gonna come back with my husband.  Our group of four was completely satisfied with the food.  Three of us ordered pasta, and the other ordered the lamb.  Food tastes home made.  My lasagna was cheesy, maybe a little too cheesy, but I still enjoyed it.  I was going to dock a star for delayed service, but being my first visit here, I gave them a chance.  Next time if service is slow w/ the server, then I'll update my review with a four star rating.
author: Alice E.

description:
ok, this is one of those secret that I should keep for myself. To those Italians and non out there who loves the real/authentic Italian Pizza,the one that you can't even find in North Beach...this is the place ! Non only te pizza is so far the only authentic I have ecver found around but imported staff is really nice as well and greet you in Italian. What else to add when I want to feel like I am back in Milan I go to Pazzia.

For those of you who didn't lie this pizza...well maybe you are too used to non real italian food out here (please note that this pizza has half calories of those american ones)

ciao

fog
author: Biemme B.

description:
Pazzia definitely delivers on an authentic Italian taste.  The handmade pasta goes a long way in my book.

I know this place is known for the amazing pizza, but somehow our party of 6 managed to order all pasta dishes.  They were all tasty but I think the Rigatoni Bolognese w/ spicy sausages stole the show.

If you decide to come here - pass on the salad, expect your servers to speak broken English, and be ready to eat hearty, fresh italian food at very affordable prices!
author: Brandon C.

description:
Love the food here! The Pennette ai Funghi is to die for. The Pizza, especially the Prosciutto with Arugula is with the typical Italian thin crust and is delicious! The owner is extremely friendly and always greets you when you arrive and thanks you when you leave. You feel as if you are at a friend's home. Many restaurants feel impersonal after coming to Pazzia. I highly recommend this place.

My only complaint is that it can get very loud in here at peak times, but then most of the restaurants in SF are the same.
author: susan a.

description:
I went with a friend and we shared their margherita pizza and gnocchi.  They were both very good and big enough to share.  Paired with a good glass of wine and you've got a great Italian meal!

Just make sure you have a reservation if you don't want to wait.  This place is very small.  Also be ready to be sitting elbow-to-elbow with your neighbors.
author: Nina L.

description:
You don't have to go to North Beach to get good Italian food. The location of this place seems too unlikely to host just a lovely spot, but believe me it's true. Authentic Italian fare, menu items changing frequently, good wine list -- check, check, check. The waiters were speaking Italian and what's even more surprising is that kitchen staff was also speaking in Italian to each other (why do I know?  Their tiny bathroom is located through the kitchen.)

My husband had flat bread and I ordered tomato salad and seafood risotto (made without chicken stock, yay!) All plates were delicios and the service friendly. 

The only reason they're losing a star from me is because the dessert special chocolate cake was a chocolate cheesecake that tasted like it was sitting in the fridge for too long. Next time I will listed to the other reviewers and get the tiramisu.
author: Gina M.

description:
We came across this place before going to a club on a Friday evening. We had to wait 40 minutes. This place has a lot of business and from these reviews, most people really like this place. I would have to ask...WHY?

It was very crowded, and VERY loud. I could barely hear myself let alone my friends. The busboy brought us over-done bread with olive oil for dipping. (No basamic!?) It had a weird flavor. BUT...I have to agree the staff was very nice and attentive.

Pasta: I had spinach pasta with salmon, olives, prosciutto, and it had TONS, & TONS of olive oil. Way too much. The pasta was a bit too salty. They never offered me parmesan, I had to ask for it. ( a little stingy I might add.) Where was the pepper? I didn't see any. 

Pizza: gorgonzola pizza and a margerita pizza.  
Crust was .......interesting. It had a flavor of parmesan? it was thin and crisp, but in a way tough to chew. When it came out it looked undercooked.  Weird.
