I guess because it's not cooked in a wood burning oven? The sauce didn't taste like San Marzano tomatoes to me. It tasted more like "Chef boy R Dee". and honestly they hardly put any of it on. (Maybe that's why!)  There was hardly any cheese on it either.  1 more question: isn't margerita pizza supposed to have fresh basil and tomato on top? This one did not. 

Oh yeah the little pubic hairs on the kitchen bathroom's toliet  (oh, wait I mean the customer bathroom.) is a little nasty, you might want to clean it up every now and then.
author: T J.

description:
My wife and I were vacationing in SF and walked from the hotel to AT&T Park for a Giants game. We were starving and wanted to eat before getting to the game. We had looked over a few places on Yelp before leaving the hotel and when we got to Pazzia decided to give it a try. There are tables outside on the sidewalk but it was bit breezy outside so went inside. Pazzia is a small place but nicely decorated. 

I had been to Italy a couple times in my life and the pizza made here was the closest to Italian style pizza that I've ever had in the US. The pizza has very this crust and is served on a plate and was larger then the individual sized pizzas I remember from Europe so I was afraid it wasn't going to be big enough for two so we ordered 2 pizzas. My wife ordered a white pizza special with prosciutto, peppers and tomatoes and I had the Napoletana with tomato sauce, mozzarella and anchovies. Both pizzas very very good and like others have said in their reviews, it took me back to Italy for a few minutes. If we had stayed in SF and longer I would have gone back to try their Penette Putanesca, pannette pasta with tomato sauce, anchovies, olives and capers. It would have been my choice if we didn't go with pizza. Service was fast a friendly. Don't go here if you're looking for American style pizza. I'm originally from New York and I love New York style pizza, this was a very nice pizza to have while in California and looking for something different.
author: Robert C.

description: Maybe it was the booze talking, but I thought Pazzia was delicious. I ordered a ravioli with sun-dried tomatoes in a pink sauce (a special for the evening). I went with a group of 5 and everyone was satisfied. An unfortunate authentic Italian touch was that the plentiful complimentary rolls were bland.
author: Adam B.

description: Great pizza. Stopped in on our way to giants game. Bad service, waitresses just stood around and talked taking turns serving our table. Weren't sure who our server was.
author: Bailey H.

description:
Fantastic pizzas!!!!!!!! I would say these are the best replacements to Napoli Pizzas. As for Pizzas with 'Scaglie di grana', trust me, you will like it! Long wait, but then again all good restaurants have that issue.
Wait staff is constantly changing but key people remain the same. I would definitely recommend this place to whoever has had authentic Italian food in Italy. If you are used to the american version of Italian food then this will not appeal to you. Also order the Bresaola con rucola e SCAGLIE DI GRANA!
author: D P.

description:
Food--great (the pizza is the best in the city...yes better than little star).

Service--okay but can see how people can perceive as bad. (unfairly aloof and laid back service in an Italian restaurant is often misinterpreted as bad service....however it is generally a cultural thing as Italians treat the dining experience as a time to relax and enjoy rather than rush).

Atmosphere--decent.....overall it is great  for a quick/cheap bite to eat.  But if you are truly looking for the full dining experience go to Allegro.
author: Solbiato S.

description:
We were seated within 15 minutes, despite not having reservations on a Sat night. We arrived right before a tide of people (9pm - pre clubbers),  so I guess we got lucky. The waiter was a bit unfriendly, but the proprietor and runner were affable.

The 3 out 5 stars comes from my dish. I ordered the chicken w/ mushroom and asparagus. It was served with a generic brown gravy which smothered the entire dish. I couldn't discern any flavors in it. It just tasted like gravy, if that makes any sense. On the other hand, my partner's dish - a pasta with shrimp, asparagus, and white wine sauce - was delicious, though I wouldn't say that complex. 

All in all, I'd give the place another try, but I'll order the pizza next time.
author: GS M.

description:
This small tucked away pizzeria in SOMA is delicious!  Being Italian and all to unimpressed with most of the offerings in the city I didn't have high expectations.  However, after ordering a simple, rustic, thin crusted pizza I was hooked!  If you go there for one thing and one thing only make it the pizza.  If you decide to keep going back give their fresh authentic pastas a try.  I've yet to try something I didn't like.

It's a small space and can get a little noisy, (be prepared to get an earful of your neighbors conversations!), but it's charming and reminds me of my roots.  The staff is friendly, though you sometimes need to be forward with getting their attention.  It has charm in spades, and you know it must be good when you find the natives eating there!
author: Fabian E.

description: Four stars for food and service and maybe two for ambiance but you're coming here for the food, so four stars it is!  Get past the strip mall-ish atmosphere and enjoy the thin crust pizza at this little Italian joint.  The crust is crisp and chewy, just the way I like it.  Not a whole lot of cheese or an enormous amount of toppings, but just enough to allow you to eat the whole darn thing.  I had some of a pizza with olives, artichokes and proscuitto and split a pasta dish that had homemade spinach pasta with some delicious things in it (the fact that I can't remember what was in it but remember how much I enjoyed it is good enough for me).  Pretty sure it involved some pancetta.  How could that be bad?  I'd go back.
author: Carrie L.

description: I LOVE this place!! It is delicious, is made of ingredients from Italy, and reminds me of my visits to Florence. You should def try this out - both pizza and pasta and salads are fabulous. Also - YOU MUST get the gelato - yummy!! (It beats Ciao Bella by far!)
author: Denise B.

description:
good pizza.. 
would go back if i had something in that area.. but i probably would not drive out of my way to eat there...

a little noisy
author: Jippers C.

description: Yum!  The gorgonzola pizza is outrageously good. The funghi is my second fav...or the spicy sausage... We tried an excellent Sangiovese to complete the ensemble - perfect!!
author: A P.

description:
A friend and I came here and split bruchetta, a salad, and a pizza. The bruchetta and the pizza were definitely the best things we had. Not to say the salad wasn't good, it was, but I'm a sucker for bread, olive oil and cheese. 
The bruchetta was perfectly toasted with fresh tomatoes, basil, and whatever other godly ingredients they put in the mix. The Pizza dough was light and flaky but still soft in the crust. The tomato sauce was flavorful and tasted freshly made. They must use good quality ingredients to get this amount of flavor. 
The downfalls were that, we had to wait about 15 or 20 minutes to get a seat indoors, so I would advise making reservations. The place is small and gets crowded to the point where you can hear all that your neighbor is saying, so it feels more family style than intimate. And to my disappointment, I was hungry about an hour or two after eating, I guess I should have ordered my own pizza.
author: Shanna H.

description:
This place is in SOMA, which means that you, dear reader, are probably driving here. Please take my advice: keep driving. If you're in the mood for good italian, go to la briccola. If you are in the mood for good thin crust pizza, go to piccino in dog patch. The prices are comparable and the food is waaaaay better.

Anyway, on to the reason for this advice. Our dinner experience got off to a terrible start when, instead of seating us at the first open, cleaned and set table (for which we had already been waiting for 10 minutes out in the cold), the waiter had us wait, and wait, and . . . wait. Minutes later, another table opened up, was cleaned and set (first still sitting empty). Minutes tick by. A third table opens, was cleaned and set (now all three are empty). Each of these tables could have sat our party of two. We were finally seated at the last table. Mind you, it wasn't that they were saving these tables for reservations, as one of them remained open for the entirety of our meal and the other one was seated by another walk-in. Any good restaurant should know better than to piss off its paying customers by making them wait for no particular reason for a table that wasn't any different than the other ones. 

More importantly, the food was decidedly mediocre. I wanted pasta, but given all the poor yelp reviews of the pasta, I went with a pizza that I could not pronounce. Caraccio or something. It had olives on it. Olives with pits. Really? Pits? How are we supposed to navigate that  while eating your soggy, droopy pizza without losing a filling? 

But the most disappointing part of the pizza was the crust. It simply tasted like crispy flour. In other words, it was tasteless. 

All in all, the place had mediocre food, had terrible wait staff, was so loud that you had to holler to carry a conversation, and was overpriced ($32 for our two pizzas). Like I said before, you're best advised to keep driving.
author: A H.

description:
Really enjoyed this place. 
Rolled in 12 deep the day before Xmas weekend with my co-workers and had a good meal.

The pizza was solid, bruschetta as well.  I had the sausage rigatoni since I had a pretty decent version of it at another place a couple days earlier...wanted to do a lil comparison.  It was juuuuust fine.

My usual gripes about prices are N/A because El Hefe picked up the tab. Sweet.
author: Sean M.

description:
Had a really expensive dinner here the other night, but it was quite good, so I guess I don't mind the price too much. I had risotto with shellfish, which was very good, but $18. Kind of wish I'd gotten one of the nice pizza's though, because the risotto was a little small. I understand shellfish is pricey, but they didn't need to skimp on the rice. Anyway, the ambiance was nice. A group of 7, like I was with, was about the limit for the space - small little storefront dining area - and the ambiance was a little loud. It had a pretty hip feel to it though and was good to see the owner working the room. I'd go back for a group dinner or special occassion.

----------
I went back recently and had a pizza. That's definitely the way to go if you're hungry and don't want to pay extravagantly.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
Pazzia does Italian food well. The majority of the dishes on the menu looked simple yet delicious. I had a bit of a conundrum when ordering because I couldn't decide between the pasta with shrimp and asparagus, the risotto with shellfish, or the beef lasagna. I finally went with the lasagna and a side of asparagus. The lasagna, which came individually made in its own ceramic dish, had a tomato cream sauce which made it one of the best lasagnas I've ever had. The asparagus came steamed with a light drizzle of olive oil and was just perfect. I recommend the house red as well. I'm no wine connoisseur, but I thought this wine went well with my meal. The tiramisu -- one of my favorite desserts so I always have to give it a try -- did not disappoint. 

I was a little disappointed with the rolls that came with the meal. I was hoping for crusty bread instead of soft rolls. Also, only olive oil was offered -- where was the balsamic?

The restaurant itself is on the small side, so when it's crowded, the noise level can be on the loud side. (Then again, perhaps that was because I was there with a party of eleven.) The staff is attentive and friendly.
author: Unity K.

description:
For someone who is just out of college, doesn't have a lot of money, and is living in San Francisco, this place is a good find. It's not that expensive and the food is pretty good. The minestrone soup was one of the better minestrone's I've had, the salad with candied walnuts and pears left a bit more to be desired, but the proscuitto/olive/artichoke pizza was very good. Reading other people's reviews, I would like to try the pasta if I went again. 

One thing I would suggest though, if you do happen to try this place out is don't try to pronounce the names of what's on the menu unless you speak Italian or it's something very easy like "ravioli". My boyfriend and I tried to order a pizza and we got some cheese on tomato thing that looked very odd. Then proceeded to have to do the awkward "I don't think that's what I ordered" thing and the waitress did not look happy with us. How would we know though that you have two items that sound similar? So I would suggest clearly pointing to the item you want if you can't pronounce it.
author: Claudia T.

description: This used to be a fantastic Italian place.  And if you look in the back, you will see a mural put together by the owner that weaves in all the greats from Florence - from Dante to Roberto Benigni, who is a friend of the owner.  However, I understand that the food has started to go downhill a little bit; a shame becuase it was fantastic about a decade ago.  Still on my list as a potential option, but there are lots of great Italian places in SF to try...
author: Todd S.

description: Excellent food and service.  I visited with 6 friends and everyone enjoyed the meal tremendously.  The salads were crisp and so fresh.  Pasta and fish were on par. The gelato in expresso was a fine finish.  I will be back!
author: Diane M.

description: Now this is authentic!  Amazing antipasto selections!  Daughter and I each had a pizza.  The crust was thin, crispy and delicious.  Husband had seafood risotto, which was out of this world (clams, mussels and shrimp galore).  Great wine selection.  Fantastic dessert.  We only have one more night in SF, but we may be coming back for more.  Looks like the family also owns a restaurant in Florence- that too will be in my hit list next spring!  Amazing service with a smile from authentic Italians!
author: Suzi S.

description:
food was good, parking was easy, wait was short, but they threw away one of our friend's leftovers (a whole half pizza!)  

when he found this out (post-bill), they suggested he pay 50% of the cost), so that they could make him another half pizza.  um, pazzia, you messing up should not warrant my friend paying 150%.  long story short, they noticed his aggravation, and then refunded him 50%.

i hate to give a horrible score for something that was probably an honest mistake, so i'll round it to three stars.  i'm hoping this was just a one-time occurrence!
author: Jill k.

description: The food wasn't bad for a quick bite to eat.  We had one of their more meaty pizzas and a pasta dish.  The ingredients tasted fresh and it was entertaining to be able to see the chefs in the back prepare our food.  Service was ok but not great.  While I don't have any major complaints against the place, it didn't really stand out and I'm unlikely to keep coming back.
author: Kelvin V.

description: It's taken me a year and a half to "find" this place that's right around the corner but I'm making up for lost time! Pastas tend to be a little overcooked but pizza is terrific and you usually can't go wrong with the specials.  Lately we've had the linguini with clams and the seafood risotto which were stars, the puttanesca was not as flavorful as it could have been but it was still ok!  Good prices, lovely and accommodating wait staff, but the wine list is a little boring and the place is nothing to look at, but they are upgrading and moving into a bigger space so it seems like the bathrooms and decor will get a much needed makeover.
author: sasha y.

description:
Yummy, crispy pizza.  The salad and bruschetta were good, but not great.  The service is marvelous.  Always a smile on their faces and the drinks are always full.

We shared the appetizer, a salad and pizza between two people (the portions are generous) plus wine and beer.  The tab was only $42 plus tip.  It doesn't get much better than that.

I would make a reservation on the weekends.
author: Mackenzie O.

description:
Pazzia has been delicious every time I've eaten there, and this is coming from a Guido who lived in Florence a few years back.  My standards for Italian food are pretty high.

Food is simple, fresh, authentic, and plentiful.  Very laid-back, neighborhoody vibe to the place, and the waiters are wonderful.
author: Ethan H.

description: So this isn't a place I'd normally find myself at on a Saturday evening. Sure, during the week, lunch time south of Market, maybe. But I have to say, for a family dinner following a movie this is a great place. The food won't win a James Beard award, but it's solid italian and the atmosphere is fun and up beat. The Giants game had just ended and given the proximity of the restaurant to the stadium it was soon packed. Still, service was good and even exceeded expectations.
author: Jeff G.

description: Sheer bliss.  We got the Salumi plate as a starter, and then I got the spinach and basil Calzone.  I was in heaven.  The desserts were great too.  The waitress was very attentive without hovering.  We had to wait a bit to get a table, but it was well worth it.
author: Lucy S.

description: We went for dinner and it was great. I am italian, moved to the states 5 years ago, and I always love to find italian restaurants that for honest price don't throw the genuine italian food down the drain. this is one of them. really nice.
author: Chiara L.

description: i used to eat here a lot when i lived accross the street, i loved this place , nice people and the food was good , this was back in 2005-2007. man i wanna go again, but i saw one day it closed. this was last month i believe. i will go again once its open
author: Pooh W.

description: While the food did not send me into orbit, the owner was so nice and welcoming.  The filet was  good as was the veal chop.  Did not like the pizza.  It was doughy ,bland and too cheesy for my tastes.
author: Bleep S.

description:
Am loving this place.  Affordable prices, fantastic Italian food.  The pasta is always fresh and flavorful, and the bruschetta and salads are always tasty.  I have yet to try the pizza -- I spent some time in Italy, and discovered that authentic Italian is not my style.  

I had a white pistachio gelato one time that was divine, but my only complaint is that it took perhaps 20 minutes to get that and a cappucino -- now I leave and get my dessert elsewhere.  On that note, service can be a bit spotty, appears to be because it's a neighborhood place and sometimes the staff is too busy chatting with and catering to friends to care for the rest of us.  But, oh well, I suppose that's part of its charm -- seemed to be a regular occurrence in Florence as well.
author: Samantha R.

description: Was in the city for my husband's half marathon at AT&T park and was staying at the Intercontinental. This place was walking distance and was perfect! We needed pasta to carb up. We could've easily went to crappy Buca that was across the street from the hotel but didn't want to eat at a chain. The owner greeted us with a huge smile and a warm "Ciao!" Made me feel like I was walking into a close friend's home. So welcoming. The service mirrored the initial greeting and we were treated like family!! I forgot what I had but it was on the specials and was a recommendation from our server along with the wine. Both were so good. My husband has had puttanesca time and time again but this one was the best one by far and bursting with flavor. We also had the carpaccio which was tasty, fresh and not salty like others I've had. Don't skip dessert because the tiramisu was light-the best!  We aren't around SF too often but we will be sure to come as often as we can!
author: Kat A.

description: an italian restaurant FULL of italians?!  zomg!  definitely need to go back for their pizza, but the pasta was excellent!
author: Jeff N.

description: If I could  give it 3.5 stars, I would. We had quite a bit of food here. All of the pizza we tried was quite good. The pasta was decent, although not to die for. Portions were large, and wait staff attentive. It's not to die for, but worth trying. Location is convenient, and parking was easy to find.
author: Anderson L.

description: Having driven by this place, I wanted to check out what the hype was all about.  I made sure to make reservations as it seems this place is always crowded.  Anyways, the food was quite good, seems pretty authentic.  My girl ordered the baked chicken, I ordered the spinach pasta.  Both were yummy.  The brushcetta appetizer was a bit lacking- too much bread, not enough tomatoes for our taste.  We loved the olive oil, interesting how it's served without any balsalmic vinegar.  Good non the less.  Just be careful not to load up on bread prior to your meals being served.  We wish the place had better ventilation, for it can get quite stuffy in this cozy place.  Service lags a bit, but it is genuine.
author: Mike K.

description: Pizelle is magnificent. The owner is always frenetic and intense, definitely amongst San Francisco's 10 best 'za houses. I just wish they delivered, but I can't complain, they are in my building! They're docked 1/2 a star for not delivering, and 1/2 a star for wafting into my home office during the day, making me want to break my year-long pizza fast!
author: Michael H.

description: Good pasta, exceptional Neapolitan-style pizza and gorgeous Italian waitresses.  I recommend getting there unItalianly early for dinner, because the wait can be epic, even on a Tuesday.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Ever since I heard about their pizza crust, I've been dying to check this place out.
Holy Gods it was all it was made out to be.  I only knock off one eensy weensy star for being sort of unattractive and making me walk into the kitchen to go to the bathroom.
But the food?!  We started with the Capricciosa pizza which is just like my beloved Quattro Stagioni which I lived on in Italy (olives, mushrooms, pancetta and artichoke hearts, but only like four of each thing).
The sangiovese we had was fantastic and complimented the food really well.  We shared a bunch of pastas - the tortelloni special, with beef and mushrooms in a sherry cream sauce, the fettucini special with prawns and asparagus, and the rigatoni con salsicce.  All were amazing, but I think the rigatoni may have edged out the competition a bit.  The caprese salad looked amazing, but I didn't get to try it because some hot, feisty redhead fought me off.  We were too stuffed for dessert, but that was our own fault.  No matter, they brought us a little glass of dessert wine at the end of the meal.
The service was impeccable and how can you not love a place where Massimo gives you a big hug and due baci and thanks you for coming.  If you go in enough, he'll know you by name even.
He mentioned that he's taking over some of the space next door to expand a bit and getting his liquor license and will serve some cocktails soon.  Yay!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
got two pasta dishes to-go.. so this is just a rating based on take out. sitting in may be different but i doubt it...

got the vongole and the fusili with eggplant

Vongole- clams were large and well cooked 
the pasta that was used, was either not cooked properly or poor quality pasta....kinda like getting one of this pizza hut pasta dishes =/
the sauce was bland - needed more parsly

Fusili - nothing special, not delicious - more like a college students home recepie or something
and again the pasta was bad quality.

wouldn't go there again.
author: Shadi N.

description: this place has definitely gone down on its quality, in both food and services, the price however, has only gone up.  I ordered a Lassana, a caprese salad (which had only 3 pieces of tomatoes and mozarella cheese), just these two basic items totaled to be $29.00.  The food was not bad, only about average I would say, it's not one of those exquisite, fine dining places, yet it surely charged like one of those high end/fancy restaurants.  I haven't seen the owner for the last 3 times I was there, so I am starting to think that they changed owner or the owner no longer manages himself, therefore the decrease in quality of food and services.  I wouldn't want to go back to this place again, there are plenty of good eats in SF that are much cheaper.
author: Shanna W.

description:
You KNOW that a place gives great customer service if a big black woman can walk in and be treated like a queen.  Likewise, the reverse is true.

OK...I hate to pull the "race card".  But, if the glove fits....

When I walk into Pazzia, they look at me like I am the Abominable Snowman and they treat me like that as well.

The only reason I patronize this pretentious little pizza joint is because my boss LOVES this place and anytime we have an event he wants some of this itty-bitty pizza.  Well, I don't give a crap anymore!!!!  The last time, he requested that we go to Pazzia for a business meeting and it took SEVEN phone calls and a visit from this big black woman and they still would not give me a reservation; I took our GREEN money to Rose Pistola where they EAGERLY accepted it and gave EXCELLENT customer service...even to big black woman!

Furthermore, I prefer a big, greasy, cheese falling all off of it kinda pizza anyway and Pazzia can kiss my big black butt!

...unless Pazzia is like owned by the mafia in which case "love you...love your pizza"
author: Karla F.

description:
If I lived near this place, I would come here every once in a while. The food was solid and their menu has all of the typical Italian food you'd expect. The ambiance is a little stark, but it is clean and tasteful. 

So while I wouldn't make a trip for this place, it would be nice to have in the neighborhood.
author: Matthew C.

description:
mmm...the pizza here is so good.  the crust is super thin and chewy.  the toppings are simple and that's what makes it delicious...just good, fresh ingredients.  i had a glass of sangiovese w/ the pizza and finished off the meal w/ the affogato, and it made me feel like i was in italy!

there is quite a wait for this place.  even though we made reservations for 7 pm, i don't think we were seated until about 7:30.
author: Helen T.

description: For once I didn't come out of an Italian restaurant cursing and yelling VA FAN CULO!
author: Daniela L.

description:
This is a very charming and authentic restaurant at first glance. The space is very small, there's an open kitchen where you can watch the chefs prepare your meal and the owner is Italian.  We made reservations for dinner on Friday night and were very promptly seated upon arriving. (I recommend making a reservation as there were people who didn't and waited for quite awhile before being seated.) However, upon entering the restaurant, we realized that the con of eating in a small restaurant is the very high noise level that tends to affect the level of conversation one can have. There were more "what did you say?" than I've ever had in a conversation at dinner. Additionally, we were seated in front of the door which was open, which naturally meant we would feel the draft. It was also the first time I had eaten in a restaurant where I needed to wear a jacket. I do understand that had the door not been open, people seated further in the restaurant would probably feel extremely stuffy.  Overall, a 2-3 stars for ambiance. 

The service was very good and quite attentive for a place that was bustling. Everyone was working at top speed including the owner. 
Definitely 4-5 stars for service. 

Now for the food...Unfortunately, it didn't quite deliver. The bread was fresh, warm, and crunchy. I ordered the handmade spinach pasta with salmon and bacon. My friends ordered a pasta dish and a chicken with potatoes dish. Although the pasta tasted very fresh, it lacked flavor. I was pretty disappointed with my dish to be honest and had expected something more from an authentic Italian restaurant. My friends enjoyed their food but we all left with a 'je ne sais quoi' feeling. 
Food: 3 stars
author: Lan Y.

description:
abundance of delicious thin crust pizza: +3 stars

beer selection of one: -3 stars

great group of yelper (and non-yelper) companions: +4 stars

pretentiously large kitchen (later reported as possible 
illusion): -2 stars

a.j. breaking out the art supplies in support of a fellow yelper: +5 stars

mia patronizing me with praise for my third grade drawing of a lobster: -1 star

buying her pizza anyway: priceless (actual cost about $10)
author: Trevor F.

description:
I knew this commercial would come in handy one day- 
Do you remember the one with the Barilla pasta commercials- where the gorgeous Italian guy ends up taking the lady (his neighbor from across the building) to an authentic Italian restaurant after seeing her cook with a no- good- pasta? And of course they only use the Braille brand to advocate its authenticity and how well loved  it is by the Italians? Well this should have been the restaurant he should have taken  her to:- genuine Italian fare-from the native Italians who dined here to the waitstaff and owner who welcomed the guests...plus I'm sure they don't use Barilla pasta!
I came here upon reading a review posted by Jeff T on this restaurant and well because-I'm starting a new list- titled "Pizza- Italian style"...  So this is the first one I am writing about ...
The place is indeed  small and a little cramped for space- but that didn't detract from the cordial and vivacious waitstaff and manager.  To our amazement we were promptly seated at our waiting table ( we called to tell them to move our reservation because we were arriving an hour! late- this they fully accomodated! ) The menu had wonderful offerings and judging from the camp seated next to us- looked delicious and satisfying as well! Given that we were going to be  bar hopping after- we just ordered the Pizza Margherita and the Seafood Risotto. 
The Pizza was quite generous- crisp and thin crust- it arrived hot with melted fine Italian mozzarella- and just enough tomato/ basil sauce. 
This is truly the best Italian Neapolitan style pizza in the city!!!
The risotto was just right- and not  too starchy- the saffron was buttery and brought out the freshness and sweetness from the scallop and shrimp seasoned with fine Italian parsley for added zing factor.  
Since we were feeling the festive nature of the evening and from our surroundings- we rounded it off with their Prosecco Italian Sparkling wine and the Tiramisu Delizioso!!!  Thanks again to our waitress- who gave us (yes gratis) two glasses of Muscat because they were out of the Port!  
I was so ecstatic about the dinner I would have shouted like Roberto Benigni..Grazie! Splendido! Molto Bello!!!
Per favore- I agree about the music selection (-1 star)...I wouldn't mind a little Italian opera music just like in the commercial ;-)

UPDATE: 9/28/2007

Dined here last night with my date- it was his first experience and my second time here.  We tried the Misto Antipasto- a mixture of cured meat- salami, mortadella, prosciutto with green salad and mozzarella- a generous plate enough for two!  I had the risotto once again- excellent and still fresh and rich- rice was right not soggy or runny.  The Capellini  (angel hair pasta with bell peppers, tomatoes and herbs) was light and even- my friend who was not a vegetarian would have wanted an extra punch with prawns or prosciutto.  I gave him a couple from my plate as it had a generous helping of seafood :-)  
The service was a little slow but they had a busy night (Thurs.). The music hasn't changed (not Italian) and a little on the loud side!  
I'm still holding them at 4 STARS :-)
author: Arissa C.

description: Good Italian at reasonable prices in downtown. The service can be a bit inconsistent and frentic, but the food is above average. I love their pizza pies and great pastas. If you don't want to pay an arm and a leg and you are in the SOMA area, I would reccomend going here.
author: Nick H.

description: This is my favorite place for a lunch pizza.  The plain cheese pizza is so good that I don't even bother with adding additional toppings.  The ingredients are just so flavorful. For a little less than $10, you get the biggest and best individual size pizza I've had so far in the city.
author: Josh K.

description:
Food was decent, middle of the road (or slightly above average) Italian. Service was moderate.

What wasn't cool - they overcharged us by $40. Pay attention to the line items on your bill when you are paying at this restaurant. It dawned on us after we  left the restaurant - when I added it up in my head, I realized there was no way had we eaten/spent what they charged us for. We walked back and they fixed our bill. But I have a feeling, given they are near Moscone with lots of conference tourists who are drinking & not paying attention, this might not be just a mistake (they did not even itemize all the items we had on our bill when we went back & asked to see the bill again). 

Just saying ... watch out. Too many other wonderful Italian restaurants in SF that won't overcharge you.
author: Victoria O.

description: I love this place. The staff is eye candy, especially the owner. The fusilli melanzane is delicious. It's not much to look at from the street, and it can be really noisy, but it's a true hidden gem. And I'm picky.
author: Cindy M.

description:
Being a Sicilian and growing up with Italian food my whole life sort of makes me an expert on the authenticity of Italian food. Mark is Polish, so his comments on this review don't have as much validity as mine do. 

We had dinner at Pazzia last week and I was overwhelmed with how great this restaurant was. Not much ambiance and very LOUD since it is literally a small square shaped room with a bunch of tables crammed in, but man alive the food is good! We started with the antipasto plate and it was one of the best we have tasted. The prosciutto melted in your mouth. We had a wonderful bottle of Chianti Classico that was perfect with the meal. If you are going to eat Italian, for God's sake have an Italian wine. I had the rigatoni with Bolognese sauce. It was the best dish in the house. Mark had lasagna which you just can't go wrong with, however I think he was slightly jealous of my plate (which I cleaned by the way)!

What we loved most is the way the owner welcomed us in and the waitress acted like she had known us for years. When we left, the owner gave us a hug and welcomed us back. It was such a great experience and this hole in the wall restaurant might just house the best Italian food in the city. Get there early because the line forms quickly and you don't want to have to fight a hungry Sicilian woman!!!! Trust me, Mark can attest to that!!!
author: Melissa P.

description:
This restaurant has the best thin-crust pizza I've ever had- and this is coming from someone who has had plenty of pizza, both in Italy as well as in the US.  

It's a small restaurant, but their food never disappoints, and their service is prompt and friendly.  I was told that the family who runs this place also has a restaurant in Florence- I'd say that explains the authenticity with their food.  Very fresh, very yummy, and reasonably priced- I try to go there whenever I'm in the area, and it's well worth the trip.  Next time I'll save room for dessert :-)
author: Tina P.

description: After making reservations we were told to wait for an available table at the door. After waiting about 30 min outside, we were seated and left alone. No water, no bread, nothing. The food was decent, but not amazing, and it certainly didn't make up for the rude reception or the wait.
author: Alex L.

description: Yummy pizza and fantastic crust that's really thin and not too filling.  The crust doesn't absorb the flavor of the great toppings.  I didn't order any pasta but the tiramisu really is that good!  We had a huge group of almost 20 people and the service was great.  You know how it is with a big group, no one ever knows what they want and someone is always missing from the table.  The waitstaff was very patient with us.  Massimo is quite a character.  He arrived towards the end of our meal and danced to the music as he greeted diners.  He's a sweet funny guy!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
This place may deserve three stars for its pizza, but the service is really subpar.  We were a relatively large group (read: automatic 18% tip) and the waitress had no qualms about trying to rush us out the door.  She brought only 3 menus for 7 people and when she came back to take our order, she was visibly annoyed despite the fact that half the table did not even have menus.  When she came back to take our order, she looked huffy again and when I started to order my entree, she said, "so you are not having a salad? I am taking appetizer orders".  I was a bit confused, and then she moved on to the next person, who ordered a salad and entree, an order which she happily accepted. The next person ordered an appetizer and entree as well, so then I asked her if it was appropriate for me to order my pizza. She told me to hold on until she got the rest of the table. Finally, I repeated my pizza order and asked her if she could take my order now. Again, she looked at me as if I was crazy, but wrote down my order.  It was bizarre, unnecessarily confusing and rude. 

The restaurant was unbelievably loud and there ended up being a miscommunication of one of the orders at my table, a pasta had shown up instead of a pizza.  The waitress was insistent that my friend had ordered the wrong dish and that she had written down what he had said.  She made no apologies and got the manager to back her up. Again, strange, not what you would call good customer service.  

The pizza is decent, but I can't accept the mediocre service. 2 stars.
author: Marie K.

description:
This is the perfect date restaurant. It's small, and very fun. The food is amazing, and the staff if excellent. 

It doesn't get any better than Pazzia.
author: Richard H.

description:
My wife and I went by based on the positive reviews. Unfortunately, I didn't pay heed to the negative feedback which I found to be pretty much on target. When we arrived, we stood around waiting for someone to acknowledge our presence. The host/mgr passed us by a few times without saying anything more than "excuse me". There were 3 tables for 4 people available inside - NONE with reservation notices upon them though later we were told that they were reserved.

After waiting a few minutes, we ventured inside all the way to the kitchen/food counter to try to get someones attention (one of the 4 or 5 wait staff/host/mgr) --again we waited for another few minutes. Finally, my wife asked the host/mgr if we were to seat ourselves and he spoke to her with a look and attitude like "Oh! (No way!) We just don't DO that here! Mind you, he did not say these words, but that is the attitude that her conveyed. Some people might call it a charming Euro/Italian attitude, I call it STUCK UP!

The host/mgr ushered my wife out and asked us to wait on these chairs lined up against the windows outside (one of them was broken and an accident waiting to happen - I hope their liability insurance is current). He told me that a table was finishing up and paying and it would by about 5 minutes -- he indicated which table in their crammed together and small dining room. We waited about 10 minutes then I saw the table order dessert. Meanwhile 2 parties came to the restaurant and were seated immediately. One party appeared to know the host mgr and was given the table of their choice, the other party seemed to just saunter up and ask for a table. I, standing right next to them and the waitress, heard her ask how many in the party -- then she proceeded to seat them. SHE DID NOT ASK IF THEY HAD A RESERVATION.

Seeing my confusion, the waitress came out to me and said that our table will be coming up soon and these parties had reservations (a seeming half truth based on my accounting above). Wanting clarification because of what I was told and what I was seeing, I asked her "Are you sure? Because we were told that our wait would be about 5 minutes and it's been 20". She said the table is paying now and it wouldn't be much longer. Then she went back in. I saw no "payment activity" going on inside the restaurant. She came back out with the menu and wine list for us to review which I accepted. She went back in and whispered something to the host/mgr and he came out to "deal" with me. Mind you, I did not raise my voice or express any harsh feelings, I just clarified the situation.

The host/mgr comes out to ask "What is the issue?". I replied that there is no issue, I was just clarifying what our expectation was. He then launches into an excited accented tirade, speaking over whatever I have to say, of how he is not trying to keep us and we are free to go, other parties had reservations, and a few other words that were disjointed and misplaced. Some people might call this a charming authentic accent, I call it INCOHERENT BABBLING THAT IS MEANT TO DISTRACT AND CONFUSE TO GIVE ONE A CHANCE TO WALK AWAY THINKING THAT HE REALLY TOLD SOMEONE OFF AND WON AN ARGUMENT.

Of course, I was not arguing but apparently, this guy had a reason to defend himself  - apparently his own lies. 

We waited a few minutes more, saw our table vacate, then we voted with our feet and wallet and left this very BAD ATTITUDE AND BAD SERVICE Restaurant.
author: A S.

description:
I really wanted to like this place because I've heard so many good things about it.  We ordered a couple of plates from the specials menu and were excited about what was to come; until it came.  My girlfriend got prawn linguini (pardon the spelling) in white wine sauce.  I'm almost absolutely sure that there wasn't a drop of white wine in the dish at all.  Here was however, far too much oil and the bottom of the dish was a warm puddle of it.  The pasta was overcooked, as was the shrimp (these 4 little things aren't worthy of being considered prawns).  They also didn't even bother to properly clean the shrimp, so we had to "de-vein" them ourselves.  The pasta also included asparagus, which, like everything else, was far too overcooked.  The dish tasted like noodles and olive oil, and nothing else....

I got a chicken breast stuffed with cheese and Prosciutto.  The chicken was so overcooked that I had a difficult time getting my fork and knife into to it to cut it.  They attempted to cook the chicken so that the top and bottom were crispy, but it failed as they obviously left it cooking for too long.... so long that the cheese and Prosciutto inside were far from discernable.  The chicken was accompanied with broccoli and potato wedges, which, you guessed it, were overcooked.  There was a thick sauce with the chicken...sort of a marsala sauce I suppose, but it lacked any redeeming qualities.

The service was typical.  The staff didn't return shortly after giving us our dishes to ask if everything was okay (something that any decent wait person has the sense to do---because if something isn't, it's the best time to remedy it.  

We were both bummed out that we wasted a meal and the money on this dinner.  Should have gone to whole foods hot food bar instead.  

I hate to leave a bad review, but what I hate even more is wasting money and a meal on poorly prepared food.
author: Will T.

description: How lucky I am to work mere blocks from this tasty treat of a trattoria. I've only been here for lunch and it's perfect if you're looking for a casual spot to refresh mid-day. The severs are friendly and uncharacteristically attentive for an all-Euro waitstaff. The first time I went, I tried the pasta my colleague ordered, and it was delicious--I don't recall the name, but it was on the handwritten specials menu. On that same visit, I ordered the pizza and have never gone back--truly the only pizza I've ever had outside of Europe that tastes authentically Italian. I'm a sucker for the margherita pizza--it's absolutely delicious (and afordable at ~$10). Invariably, my bf and I split one of these and the endive salad when we go, and it's the perfect amount of food for lunch. YUM!
author: Jasmine F.

description: The people were super friendly, great food, it is a little loud, but overall really enjoyed our experience.  The pizza reminded me of the pizza I had when I was in Florence.  It was really authentic.  Very good!
author: Cindy B.

description:
I was staying at the W Hotel a few blocks away and used the Yelp app to find this place.  It had a nice cozy neighborhood feel to it.  Very welcoming.  The night was chilly so I started with minestrone soup that was good.  Had a magherita pizza next which was nicely done (thin and crisp).

While we were eating the owner came in and made the rounds.  Most people there seemed to already know him, so I think this place has a lot of regulars.  

Seating was a little cramped, but looks like they are expanding into the storefront nextdoor, so that problem should be solved soon.

Bottom line:  Good food, good prices, warm atmosphere, walking distance from the W hotel.
author: russ c.

description:
We were lucky that we were able to reservations for 9:30 on a saturday night.  I tried going to the restaurant before, but the line was out the door and parking was impossible.  

Having said that, this place is definitely worth the effort.  The risotto was delicious and so was the pizza.  The sangiovese was better than the chianti (as far as wines by the glass) and I would recommend saving room for dessert.  The tiramisu was light, fluffy and worth every calorie.

The noise level was loud, but there's entertainment value from listening in to what happened to be a "first date" conversation right next to us (you can't help but overhear them).  The host and waitress were both very nice and helpful and we look forward to going to their sister restaurant in Florence, Italy this summer.
author: Connie Y.

description:
I work nearby Pazzia and have gone for lunch with a variety of people who have collectively ordered nearly everything on the menu. Everything on the menu is wonderful.

I love that I can get great Italian food here without all pretentious fancy Italian restaurant demeanor and pricing.
author: Hilary T.

description: I'm a big fan of Pazzia.  Their pizzas are not the americanized version that you get at Round Table and such, but they are the traditional Italian version with flat thin dough, not in a uniform circle and fresh toppings.   Their Pizza dough sandwiches are my favorite item on the menu.
author: Todd F.

description:
I took my BF the first time last night.  He insisted since it's in the building and as a life long resident he insists that in SF this is as good as it gets.

If like me though, you have spent any time in Manhattan, you will feel like something is missing.   The lasagne is good, but who uses cream in lasagne?  Also, for $15 I really thought they could give me more than the tiny piece delivered. 

But that said SF is really weak on Italian food, so in the world of the blind, the one eyed man is king.  

BUT the espresso was fantastic.  And for $2, a good bargain.
author: Mel B.

description: Best pizza in SF...the prosciutto and arugula pizza is absolutely heavenly!!
author: Reza E.

description: Best Italian pizza in San Francisco bar none. Good service, reliable prices, excellent food, no attitude. Bravi!
author: T O.

description: No me gusta.   I don't normally bash a place because of bad service, but come on.   I have never felt so neglected in a restaurant.   We had a reservation and had to wait 20 minutes to be seated, check that twenty minutes to be greeted by an employee and then seated.   Once seated we sat around for another 15-20 before we could order some wine and got water etc.  We ordered our dinner and the wine still hadn't arrived.  Finally our dinner arrived and the bottle of wine showed up a couple of minutes later!  No apology, no explanation.  Horrible service!!!!   The food was okay, hence the two stars instead of one.   I've had better lasagne at Amici's and you can get comparable ravioli at just about any decent Italian restaurant in SF.  So why put up with the arrogance of these people?  I hate you Pazzia... I hate you good!
author: Raj M.

description:
Hands down one of the best places in the city.  The pizza is awesome.  Yes, it's small and does not have the ambiance of some places, but your meal will more than make up for it.  Favorites include:  Mista Salad, pizza, and the fruit Del mar. 
And you MUST try the pistachio ice cream (or maybe its gelato) for desert.  If I could eat here everyday I would (that is to say without gaining 50 pounds along the way)
author: Kristine D.

description:
"waiters, chairs, food, flavorful, good portions, high 4 stars rating, will come again" 

anonymous
author: Brian H.

description: Great Italian food.  Simple, good ingredients, good food.  The price is just right and the ambiance was bustling, but not so loud you are shouting at your fellow diners.  Definitely coming back again and again.
author: birdabee j.

description: We went there on a friday night. Not super busy. They were able to seat us right away. Decor was poor. My date and I ordered 2 different types of veal. It came out mediocre. I was not impressed with this place.
author: David S.

description: Further evidence that the best Italian food in SF is NOT in North Beach. Let the tourists go down the Columbus Culinary Walk of Shame, this is where I'm going for pizza and pasta. The pizza is the most authentic I've had outside of Italy, with a perfect crispy crust and just the right amount of tangy sauce. Pastas are always perfectly cooked, and their mushroom cream sauce is worth the coronary. For those just wanting meat and potatoes, go for the roasted chicken. The staff is always gracious and welcoming.
author: Aaron L.

description: An unexpected location for such a quintessentially Italian restaurant: Financial District, near YBCA. But location be damned, this is some of the best Italian in the City, served by a courteous and true-blooded Italian staff. Their pastas are cooked al dente, with just enough sauce to add bold flavor but not so much that it masks the taste of the pasta itself. The pizza is fantastic. And there's only one beer on tap (except it's served in bottles), and unless you've been to Italy (which I haven't) I almost guarantee that you've never heard of it. Not that that's a bad thing, of course!
author: Andrew K.

description: We loved this restaurant so much we visited 2 nights in a row.  A warm cozy space with friendly attentive staff.  Delicious food, especially the lasagna.
author: Anne B.

description: Amazing.  Ignore the odd locale, there is no better Italian food for you.  The pizza is incredible.  Order the lasagna special.
author: Keith R.

description: Really random location, and the atmosphere is a bit nondescript and cramped - but the food and the service couldn't be better.  A very nice surprise for a reasonable price.  I called 15 minutes ahead for a table, and it was the right choice b/c there were lines out the door about 20 minutes after we sat down.  The salads were good.  The pizzas were very thin crust and delicious.  The roasted chicken was tender and all dark meat - yummy...The best part of the meal was the pistachio gelato.  Delicious.  Skip the cheesecake - nothing special.  I love this little find.  Well, apparently other people know about it after seeing the wait out the door!
author: Christina S.

description: Pazzia is a real fun place for a casual Italian dinner. It's not stuffy, the staff is super friendly, the ambiance is generally lively, and Massimo the owner is full of personality!  We usually get the caprese, rigatoni, lasagna or salsiccia pizza with a bottle of Il Bosco (2000). For dessert, we would share the affogato with espresso and a few glasses of moscato.  This is definitely one of our local favorites and if you decide to stop by on a Fri/Sat, I would make reservations.
author: TK W.

description: I must be the only one that has had the worst service ever here.  I lived in St. Francis Place, right above here and visited a few times.  Every time it was by far the worst service we have had in the city.  They forgot to put our order into the Kitchen every time!  She would also just forget about us and we would have to grab someone else to get more drinks while waiting forever.  Amazing how one person can effect your opinion of a place so much, but I can not recommend this place because of our past experiences.
author: Pele N.

description: Honestly, one of the best authentic, down to earth, no bs italian rests. i have tried in SF.  Was abs. surprised that this good of an italian rest was in this area, let alone near where I live so I definitely cant wait to go back.  What everyone says here is true, packed but packed in a good way.  All the workers here are literally from italy, the food is superb.  I will reiterate, the food here is awesome.  We tried 2 different pastas and the beer capaccio, all 3 dishes were just delicious, house made pastas, etc.  I really really recommend trying this place if you are in the mood for good italian with none of the bs.  We will definitely be coming back.
author: Charles C.

description: This is one of my favorite local restaurants.  The food is always delicious (the burrata is amazing) and the service always warm and welcoming.  The ambiance leaves something to be desired; decor could be updated and the outside traffic is noisy and distracting.  Other than that I think the food is great for the price and I find myself returning again and again.  Looks like they are expanding to the adjacent space - I look forward to seeing the results.  Wise to make a reservation after 7pm.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I stumbled upon Pazzia when looking for a lunch place during a trade show at the Moscone Center (half a block away)

WHAT A TREAT!!

I grew up in Milano, Italy. This pizza is identical to the pizza I used to have as a kid in Italy. Eccezionale! The most authentic italian pizza I've had in the bay area hands down.
author: Karl R.

description:
A large group of friends and I had a great time at this wonderful Italian restaurant. It is a tiny place with a great menu. I had a shrimp and fettuccine in white wine sauce dish. The portion size is just about perfect for someone on vacation in a hotel without a fridge or microwave to reheat leftovers. 

As good as my pasta was, I was definitely jealous when all of my friends got their awesome looking and tasting (and more reasonably priced) pizzas. This was a nice place to sit and visit with friends while eating for a long while as the check was slow to come and we weren't rushed out.
author: Sara S.

description: I'm going to put a framed picture of the lasagna on my desk. It's been a few days and I still have that floaty feeling.
author: Amy J.

description:
Great pizza.   Once a week, my office gets take-out from here.  Everyone orders even those that brought a lunch.

Update - after 3 sub-par pizzas and one bland pasta dish, I've changed my rating to 3 (from a 4)

Update 2 - food is deteriorating - even the pizza ingredients taste worse. (down to 2)
author: WP D.

description: Fairly authentic Italian and always a full house. As a gnocchi connoisseur, I couldn't pass up the potato knobs. They don't serve it from a frozen bag, but it's not the most tender knobs I've ever had either. Their menu has every single pasta known under the Tuscan sun. And I think most of their pastas are handmade! Reasonable fare. Decent place for a low key, casual, and inexpensive date.
author: Cathy H.

description: So the future-hubby and I have been searching for a good Italian restaurant ... not too cheesy, not too pricey.  We have finally found the perfect place that a colleague of mine recommended, Pazzia!  We started with the Carpaccio, and it was very delicious.  Then we had a vegetarian, yes after the raw meat, pizza - perfectly thin and the cheese was to die for.  My date ALWAYS orders the al von gole dish if it's on the menu ... I'm not a big fan of the dish in general, but wait!  It was not only to his liking, but I LOVED it.  I am actually craving it right now!  Oh!  And the cheesecake ... the best we've ever had!  All in all, this place has been added to our rotation :)  P.s. Make reservations.
author: Jackie K.

description: One of my favorite Italian spots with phenomenal, authentic thin-crust pizza. Also one of the best tiramisus that's ever passed my lips. Great service by stylish and friendly Italian waiters. Yum.
author: Michie L.

description: My husband & I came here for dinner the other night.  It took a while for us to get seated despite the fact that there were 4 empty tables, but everything else made up for that minor mishap.  The food is absolutely delicious & the staff was very attentive (clearing plates & checking in on us).  The bruschetta is an excellent appetizer & their spinich gnocchi is yummy as well.  The chocolate raspberry cheesecake is to die for!
author: Jenny M.

description:
For a quick, local italian joint in SOMA, Pazzia get's four stars.  (YELPers get 5 STARS b/c you reminded me of it!).  Pazzia is one of first restaurants I went to when I moved to SF but unfortunately forgot about it.
My parents were in town from the east coast and we wanted a quick Italian meal after visiting the Metreon's Titanic exhibit.  Pazzia was perfect!
Friendly staff, good wine list, great fresh pastas, salads and pizzas.
Nothing fancy but perfect for a M-Th night after working downtown.
author: kimberly t.

description: yum...never quite had a pizza like that before, i think it's authentic?!?! the crust is fantastic! The pasta dishes looked yummy as well! i'll be here again...no doubt.
author: Paola W.

description: Solid Italian food from great people. Highly recommended.
author: Mark W.

description:
finally tried this place for lunch after passing by a few million times on the way to work. 

i was bold and went for something OTHER than the friggin pizza - a special at that! i splurged on the bucket o' mussels for $10.50. 

now, it would have been fine if the waiter missed our order of bruschetta, but our waiter appeared to be the owner. when he forgot my friend's beer, he was bummed. trying to spend  money seemed difficult?

.... but when my damn mussels as so sandy that i feel i have to take a shower to wash it off of me, we have a problem. i've been meaning to eat lighter - but this is ludicrous.

the gnocci in blue cheese sauce served to companions was fine, as was the Pinot Grigo i sipped on.

i'll just order the goddamn pizza next time. sheesh.
author: matt n.

description:
The roast chicken with rosemary and potatoes is what keeps me going back again and again. 

The only thing I don't like about this place is that it's too small. I like to flare my elbows out when I dine. 

Seriously, try that roast chicken.
author: Khao K.

description: Came back a second time recently and devoured some kind of pasta (penne or rigatoni) with marinara sauce and Italian sausage ... soooo good.  I'm still amazed by how amazingly quickly the food comes out.  We were in a hurry and were able to get in and out in about 30 min.  It was nice to be able to get a table quickly at about 9:30pm on a Friday (although most of the restaurant was still pretty full).
author: Melinda C.

description: oh man this is a great place!! right on the street side so you get a lovely view of passers-by.. i tried a pizza and it was full of flavor.. the crust was just the way i like it, thin and crispy so it enhanced the toppings even more!! excellent waiters and waitresses, very attentive anf always there for you no matter how busy they get.. all in all, loved it!!
author: Rak P.

description: Great food, though it's not cheap, and the portions are a bit on the small side.  They have a really good seafood pasta.  It can be a little crowded there at times, but the food makes up for that.  And the folks there aren't snooty, like some Italian places can be.
author: moosedog i.

description: Stepping inside this tiny gem in SoMA one can easily imagine they've been dump into the middle of Firenze, lots of Italianphile Americans.  The owner is a friendly Italian who will treat you like you're dining at his own home.  You'll find all the classics here.  The wine list offers a nice variety of Italian wines which the owner is more than happy to guide you through.
author: Amber L.

description: I found this place on Yelp which listed the price range as $$, but this did not reflect the costly wine prices. Wine by the smallish glass was around $9.50 for Italian reds.The food portions were on the smallish side. The cappuchino and complimentary fresh-baked bread were delicious, the salad was salty, and the antipasta and desert were skimpy. The restaurant was loud and echo-y with house music throbbing in the background. We ordered a cold cuts antipasta, a braised green salad, lasagna (baked in a deep dish that looks like the kind served at Pizza Hut), home-made tiramisu, cappuchino, Americano, and 3 glasses of wine plus tip, the bill for two came to $100+. Though the food was good, I won't go back there because of the wine prices. Plus, I've found Italian restaurants that are faster, just as delicious or more so, quieter, in a nicer neighborhood, with delicious wines, all for 30 percent cheaper.
author: Lou S.

description: First time I went to Pazzia I had broken my heel right before a huge launch party at Moscone and went to the shoe repair place next door. While waiting of course (and missing the canapes being passed at the party), decided to sit and have a glass of vino and order a pizza at Pazzia. Delicious! Love the margherita (should be the benchmark version at any pizzeria) and cozy atmosphere. Hooray for more great pizza in the city!
author: Mariangela S.

description: Being from Chicago I'm pretty damn picky about Italian food. This place did not disappoint.  Nice, little sorta intimate dark dining room, the way I like it. Nicely sized portions, chill atmosphere. Went here for a work dinner and everyone was pretty pleased with what they had. The only down side is that I booked a table for 10 and only 8 ended up attending, which for some reason merited attitude from the owner.  Ah well, I came there for good food, not to make friends.  Recommended.
author: Steve R.

description: Noisy, noisy, noisy. I could barely hear my friends speak. The block of 3rd St Pazzia is on is sort of a random place for a restaurant, but the food was great. The pizza with arugula, egg, and prosciutto reminded me of a dinner I had in Rome at Pizzeria Baffeto. Note to future diners: remember to bring ear plugs and sign language skills.
author: Richie K.

description:
pazzia is a nice lil place that has a really nice wait staff and a great neighborhood vibe to it.  too bad the food didn't live up to it.  one thing i have to piggy back on that was pointed by other yelpers is that pazzia is loud!  it was hard trying to hear my wife and she was just sitting across from me!

we started w/ the caprese and bruschetta appetizers and though they were decent enough but the entrees fell flat.  i had the seafood risotto and while it was made decently, the flavors just didn't cut it.  the clams and calamari tasted good enough but there wasn't that many pieces of them in there.  my wife had the fettuccine in a white wine sauce w/ asparagus and this was sorta lacking in the flavor department too.  for dessert we shared the cheesecake which was just OK.

oh well, i was hoping for a nice lil italian place on this side of town that could rival both aperto and trattoria contadina but not pazzia...
author: Swarup B.

description: Went there late Saturday, and it was quite busy.  Had a pizza, which was quite good [seond to pizzetta 211 in Richmond, IMO].  Overall good meal and reasonably priced.  Staff is friendly.  The pasti I didn't think were all the special, but were still good..
author: Ken and Yuri Q.

description: Pastas and salads are fantastic! My favorite Italian place in the city. Small place though, and can get pretty crowded on weekends. But it's true that Massimo is very sweet. And funny!
author: Evelyn G.

description: Shockingly good combination of good food, cheap corkage, and great atmosphere for groups in a very unassuming location. The only problem with this place is that I can never convince my friends that there could be a place worth visiting in such a random block. The staff is generally nice and helpful. The one caution is that this place is small and popular with groups, so there are many nights where trying to walk in is hard, especially when the Giants are playing.
author: Charles H.

description: Surprisingly good Italian.  I go here with Keith and we always end up sharing everything.  Try the pizzas - they're incredible.  We've had the bruschetta which is decent and the pastas are all ok - but the pizza is really the thing that keeps us coming back.  The service is true-to-life Italian - and I swear that the owner only hires incredibly attractive Italian women.  The service and wine recommendation were good... but don't eat the bread.  I really don't get it, they have amazing pizza and terrible table bread.  It seems like an easy thing to fix, so I hope they'll take care of it.
author: Jared F.

description:
only got to try the pizza, but i did enjoy it. i am, however, realizing that i'm not a huge fan of thin neapolitan style pizzas... i think they're really tasty and have a nice crispy consistency... but i enjoy my pizza with a little more substance. 

with that said, i still enjoyed the pizza here. and the staff were great.
author: Steven L.

description: I decided to try out this place because of the good reviews.  It's disappointing to say the least.  We waited for almost an hour to be seated, they were busy, which is a good sign.  Our food was unimpressive to say the least.  I think we should have tried the pizza that everyone seems to like rather than the pasta's.  Won't be back.
author: Lisa M.

description: Decided to give Pazzia another try, this time for lunch.  It was a much more pleasant experience than the previous visit, I'm happy to say.  The service was friendly and attentive, the food was good, and there were no flies doing orbits around my head.  I had the roast chicken focaccia sandwich, which I inhaled in about ten seconds.  I think I ate all the bread that was placed at the center of the table, as well, and had an iced tea to wash it all down.  I'll go back.
author: Paul T.

description: tight space (but expanding this year), this place always seems to deliver. great services, atmosphere is great with the exception of current tight space.  had the antipasto of meats for the app.  good selction and ample amounts.  for dinner i had the chicken with mushrooms with potato and vegetables.  very tasty.  good portions, fresh, and not over powering on the spices.  overall, a solid choice.
author: Tim F.

description: Pazzia is awesome!  I find myself constantly craving their pizzas.  And Massimo, the owner is a total sweetheart!  True Italian!  The food is great and the cost is inexpensive.  Make a reservation as this small spot can be hard to get into.
author: Michelle B.

description: I found the food to be the most authentic I've tasted outside of Italy.  If you're craving thin crusted, cheesy pizza from a wood burning oven, this is the place to go.  The service isn't so great but it only makes it seem more authentic.
author: Denise G.

description: Recommend anything with pasta in it, and that's most of the menu. Also the pizza margherite, and the saltimbocca.
author: David Y.

description: Average pasta, risotto is good, bread is good, as is the service.
author: Sydney L.

description: This is one of my main staples in SF. When in doubt, I come here - its simple, I know that whatever I get it will b good.  The pasta al dente, the wine list reasonable, and Massimo makes sure that all the clients are taken care of.
author: Ingrid P.

description: You wouldn't know by walking past it, but this little Italian restaurant serves up very authentic food. Word to the wise, get a reservation. There are only about 13-14 tables for two (joined together for bigger parties) -- like I said, this place is tiny. Service is very friendly and helpful, but slow in a very Italian fashion. We tried the appetizers and the pizzas, both were spot on. The prices aren't too steep, with 2 bottles of wine, 2 pizzas, and 3 appetizers the bill came out to $110 + tip, not bad for 4 people.
author: Girish P.

description: Dear Pazzia, your proscuitto and arucola pizza is fabulous! However the margherita was so-so; I want fresh basil leaves and visible chunks of mozzarella. The lasagna didn't leave much of an impression either, too runny and a bit lacking in flavor. Don't get me wrong, I had a really lovely dinner, but I must attribute some of that to my wonderful dining companions. So here are 3 stars and a note that I'd give you 3.5 if I could! I'll definitely come back, just know there is room for improvement.
author: Will A.

description: I've been going here because my boyfriend likes this place and it's very close to my apt.  We always order their pasta, but since the sauce is always fresh and tasty, I'm sure their pizza would be good too.  The staff is friendly and has european accent making the restaurant feel even more authentic.  The wine list isn't so good though.  And, sometimes, the family crowd could make the place very noisy and crowded.
author: Vivian H.

description: The food here reminds me of my favorite osterias in Rome.  The tagliarine in white wine sauce is my favorite dish.  I swear the pizzas are the best Italian-style pizzas in the city -- and I've been looking for 10 years.  It's out of the way for me, but I find a reason to go here as often as I can.
author: Mat B.

description: The food was really good but the service was SO poor that I cannot help but dock it.
author: Jerry S.

description:
The food:  The capriciola? pizza was quite good.  The oven was hot and gave a good sear to the thin crust.  Quality ingredients.  The lasagna was far and away my favorite dish.  The sauce was amazing.

The Service:  Good service considering the restaurant was packed.  My wife's proseco was flat but 1 mention to the waitress and another bottle was opened and a fresh glass poured.  Very polite.  The bus boys there are really good as wekk.  They obviously clear tables fast and work very hard.

The cost: $70 for 1 appetizer, 2 drinks, and 2 entrees.  Not bad considering the level of food quality and the taste of the food

The only gripe I have about the place is its size.  There were probably 10 more people in the dinning room than the place could hold comfortably.
author: chris h.

description: My favorite Italian place in the city.  I used to work around the corner from it a few years back and drove my colleagues crazy with my constant pleas to go there for lunch.  It was where I had my first spaghetti alla vongole, and no where else has quite compared since.  The wait staff was always super sweet and the pizzas are divine! LOVE this place!
author: Chrys W.

description: A piece of Italy on 3rd Street.  Good pizza, of the thin crust type, true to Neapolitan tradition (although Pazzia's owners are from Florence.)  Btw, when in Florence, visit the sister restaurant "I Ghibellini".
author: Matteo F.

description:
We went here for dinner on our first evening living in San Francisco.  I don't think you can have a better start...

I had the bruschetta and a margherita pizza, and both were excellent.  I didn't try the desserts, so I look forward to trying them later (especially the tiramisu).

Add the friendly service and inexpensive costs, and you know we will be back.

I tried the tiramisu and it's amazing!  Not the heavy, almost uneatable stuff you sometimes get in restaurants, but a lighter, much more tasteful version...
author: Marijke D.

description: The service and food were both great. The muscles was a much bigger than order than we were expecting, which was a pleasant surprise. We didn't have a reservation, but were still able to be seated, on the patio with our dog, immediately (Fri at 7 pm). But, before we left, there were lots of people waiting to get in.
author: Amanda S.

description: The food seemed fairly average, but it was busy enough.  I can imagine if the place got busier it might be a little noisy.  Service was sincere, but not top-notch (I'm not even sure if that makes sense, but it's what I'm feeling).  We had a couple salads and bruschetta and wine to tide us over until my staff party nearby.
author: Pancake ..

description: And four stars it is.  At first we were not so certain about the service, as it started out slow.  However it did pick up and was slightly above average.  The food was excellent.  The pizza was very flavorful and the pasta, which is made in-house, was excellent.  The mussels were a bit too small but the sauce that they were in was delicious.  Dessert was about average.  I would recommend making a reservation since this place is small and was very busy the night that I was there.  We were lucky to slip in.  Just a note, the bathroom was fairly dirty.
author: Scott A.

description: A little more classy than I expected. Food was excellent. The bread was soft and spongy, I'd never had bread like that before. Most meals were around $10-15.
author: Joshua G.

description: I'm more for 3.5, their pizza is good. BUT the pizzaiolos are in the back of the kitchen and the oven is gas, not wood. Nevertheless good place for a pizza on a Tuesday night
author: Alex A.

description: I am very, very picky about pizza, especially when the expectation is about authenticity. So I ordered Margherita (my key benchmark for pizza). It tells you everything about dough/crust, mozzarella, and tomato. The crust was perfectly cooked, thin and crispy, but flavorless. Tomatoes and mozzarella were just barely OK. I was disappointed but I may give Pazzia another try. Perfect pizza is not an easy task, and it varies from day to day if more than one pizza chef is involved. As far as the atmosphere, that is really authentic. This is how pizzerias often look like in Italy (e.g. in Rome). I liked that part.
author: Donato M.

description: Awesome Italian. Pizza is the shit as an app to share, then get some pasta. Pizza is pretty unreal, the closest to good new york pizza as I have had in the bay area. the pasta is always solid. definitely Italian run.
author: Arturo H.

description: The food rocks! I usually get the linguine with shrimp. The waits not too long (not more than 15 mins). The italian waitresses are very cute :)
author: viv k.

description: Friendly service that makes you feel like you're a regular, even if it's the first time you've stepped through the door. It's like stumbling into a Florentine cafe in the middle of SOMA. The food and the servers are that authentic.
author: Oliver O.

description: This is a place that makes me wish I lived in SF so I could back and try a few more things.  We made it here for dinner on the second day of our trip and loved every bite of the Cesar salad, sausage pizza, and creme caramel that we shared.  The atmosphere was surprisingly cozy and it felt like family with the small staff.  It was also a bit romantic...maybe it was all the two-tops.  Definitely glad we found this one.
author: Jenna D.

description: I really love some of the dishes at this place, but you do need to order carefully.  Some of the starters and salads are pretty weak (such as the bruschetta), but the gorgonzola pizza, pasta puttanesca, and the pasta with peppers more than make up for it.  If you're in the neighborhood and are looking for a casual italian meal, I recommend it.
author: Michelle A.

description: Great food.Probably the best Italian restaurant in Soma.the spicy sausage pizza was delicious.this is one place where you wanna go atleast once in a week.
author: Yelp F.

description: Pazzia's a charming Italian restaurant a block south of the SOMA. Excellent home-made Italian food, especially the carpaccio.  The restaurant is not real big, but the decor is quite charming and there are tables outside to sit at on a warm day.  Definitely a must-try if you're in the area (One 3rd Street at the corner with Folsom).
author: Eric G.

description: A 3.5 if I could give it. While SF often overflows with sceney spots, this isn't one of them. It feels like a bit of Italy right smack in SOMA. The bread's really good--don't ask for seconds. The menu is pretty diverse. I usually get the roasted chicken, which is good, or pasta which is handmade and a sure thing. The servers are enthusiastic, down to earth, and authentically Italian.
author: sarah s.

description: I love this place. Pazzia is the perfect neighborhood italian restaurant. The service is oh so italian and the dishes are perfection. The food is simply but extremely well executed. If there are any fresh pastas on the menu I would go for those. The lasagna is simply amazing. Their pizzas are also excellent to share. If you find yourself in SOMA, this is definitely a place to go to.
author: Peter K.

description: Went to Pazzia one night for dinner before a movie.  Was able to get a table without a reservation, but by the time we left, there was a fair amount of people waiting outside.  The food was delicious, service was quick, prices reasonable.
author: Lisa D.

description: Went to Pazzia last night after not having been in maybe 2+ years and happy to report that everything is still great! Great service from authentic Italian people (or at least authentic Italian accents). Stellar pizzas and pastas and a great wine list from the old country. It was a busy night with a regular line of people waiting outside to get in something which may or may not be a problem once the apparent pending expansion is complete. Nice! We were impressed by the bus boy and how quickly he turned over the tables and sad that it was so busy that we didn't get to chat with Mossimo the owner. Our friends who had never been were duly impressed and said it was going to be a challenge not to pop in on the way home from the gym (Club One) across the street. Definitely will have to put Pazzia back on our regular eating out list again. I Highly recommend it for fresh, tasty, friendly service for dates, friends and families.
author: Nathaniel R.

description: Delicious pizza, though a little pricey ($12-14 a pizza).  The pizzas are big though, and very well done.  The space is pretty small, so probably not good for groups during busy hours.
author: Kryzak K.

description: Awesome italian food, they don't have to drown the food in garlic to make it taste good.  The service was excellent and the food was reasonably priced, about $16-$25 for an entree.  Definitely worth the cost.  I would definitely go back again and again.
author: peter k.
